description:
I'm happy to rediscover this place for their habanero miso ramen. It's spicy but IMO very good soup. It's so spicy that the staff warns people when ordering. When there was a Ramen Underground location in Japantown I lived going there for that.

Otherwise the ramen itself is okay but not great compared to other places I go to. There's not much meat included, just a few pieces of sliced chicken.

Also on the menu it says there's a $0.35 fee if paying by credit card. When I came back for the first time several weeks I didn't see it and was unaware until I got the bill for signature when I saw it was added. This past week when I visited again I charged anticipating the fee (figuring I still come out ahead after my credit card reward),  but it wasn't added. So don't know if that fee is still in place or I lucked this past time.
author: H K.

description:
Slightly pricey. ~$13 per bowl and then an additional $2 to add an egg. I guess the ramen here you have to request to add eggs  and it's hard-boiled not soft-boiled which is how I typically like my ramen eggs. 

Size? But the portion is pretty big or maybe I was extra full from the large cup of boba I had before walking in here. 

Taste? I mean it wasn't Michelin star worthy or completely terrible. Tasted pretty good. I got the tonkatsu ramen and some places make it way too salty but not here. It's got the perfect amount of salt. FYI they also have chili oil you can add in for that extra kick. Didn't see any white pepper anywhere though.
author: Justine C.

description:
This place really came thru in our time of need. It was around 9 pm and we were stumbling around sf looking for a quick meal before heading back home. We saw this ramen place and decided to check it out. 
I got the salt ramen, a basic staple. My friends got the tonkotsu and soy ramen. The salt ramen was really good and the broth was flavorful and lighter. The chicken was tender and light and the inclusion of a healthy amount of spinach? Made the meal very refreshing. 
The ambiance was also very nice especially at night since this place is a bit more lowkey. The staff is friendly and fast and the decor is very classic.
author: Lawrence H.

description:
Definitely nothing special about this ramen. It's basically just broth and noodles. I'm ok with that for the price.  Based off of the overall cleanliness of this place I wouldn't really trust them to get more creative with their menu. I do like that this place is close to my work and it satisfies my need for something that is not a salad. 

I will say that you should absolutely never use their restroom. They actually store their garbage and compost bins in there so it smells like a rotting corpse. I seriously almost threw up and had to run back to work to use those bathrooms instead.
author: Jessica F.

description: Don't order takeout - just received literally a bowl of noodles and had to wait 1.5 hours from cavier. Pretty frustrated - this is Tonkatsu Ramen?
author: Maxwell C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile. In the evenings the lines are long. We got here for lunch and sat near the door. They really crowd in the chairs. Not a place for overweight persons as it would be difficult to squeeze between tables to sit on the inside. 

My go to ramen is tonkotsu. The broth was very flavorful but too salty. I'm sure my blood pressure and kidneys were screaming "salt overdose".  The noodles had a nice chew when the bowl arrived and there were bamboo shoots and spinach thrown on top, I added a boiled egg for $1.50. The egg was bland. The menu outside the door listed mushroom in the dish but when you get inside, mushroom was crossed off the menu with a black marker. False advertising.  The slices of pork in the dish were good, nothing fancy. 

I only saw one waiter rushing orders for all the tourists, techies and locals. He wasn't shy about asking customers to leave when they finished their meal, paid and were loitering. That's how we got our table. It's a small place so expect a bit of a wait. I would consider a return visit as the ramen is pretty good given the location.
author: Ry T.

description: Various ramen, great broth. Did not experience the slow service others noted, our food came in less than ten minutes at dinner time...a simple but heart menu. And they have red pepper oil. Pretty yummy.
author: Matt B.

description:
No frills ramen that satisfies your after work ramen craving! Ramen Underground was my first time having ramen! I loved that they had chicken and vegetarian broth (note that they noodles has egg in them). Nothing fancy about the ramen, but it tastes great! The only downsides about this place, is that is expensive for what it offers and usually has a long line of people hanging out after work.

I wouldn't wait more than 15 minutes for a table or travel more than 15 minutes to get this place, but within those constraints, I love going back to Ramen Underground.
author: Divya S.

description: It is rare to have chicken broth in ramen restaurant but it tastes good. The broth is a little bit salty to me.
author: Steven H.

description: Eh. I've come here a handful of times thinking it will taste better than the last time and it never really does. There's nothing I particularly like about this place or its ramen except its location. I guess if you're realllly craving ramen in FiDi, this is one of the few options.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Alright for the location. Nothing to write home about.

I work in the area and came by for a quick lunch. If you come here before or after 12, the wait is not that bad. Peak lunch time right at noon is the worst. There is a board outside to sigh up if there is a wait. 

I've had better and I've had worse, this ramen falls in the middle lather. I did my usual Tonkatsu ramen with an added egg. I'm glad I saw someone else's bowl first and I had them remove the RAW spinach. This is one thing that is hard to get used to, lots of places in the states like to add raw spinach to their ramen and I feel like it takes away from the flavor. The noodles were alright. Just a little chewy and more on the well done side. The broth was okay. Not oily or creamy enough for a tonkatsu, but it was seasoned well. More like a rich chicken broth than a pork bone one.  The pork was tender and sliced thin. Not too much flavor. The egg was ok. I wish they threw in more than 2 pieces of bamboo shoots. I'll add extra next time.
author: Junella T.

description:
Don't be fooled - this place is above ground. 

The ramen is decent and good size portions. Average prices and the place is pretty clean. Both times I was by, it was busy and seems to do well.
author: Ben T.

description:
After our meeting in the financial district, we wanted some piping hot comfort Japanese ramen and I typed in my yelp app for nearby restaurants and found some but they were not quite what we were looking for as they were either take out or no seating.   We saw this place across the street while we were walking on Kearny Street and decided to take a look.  It was small but cozy and warm on a cold day.  There was a table for two with our name on it in the back near the kitchen.  

We were in the mood for some soup noodles so we ordered the chicken dumpling organic chicken noodle soup and the tonkatsu ramen.  Both had plenty of meat (his - chicken dumplings and pieces of chicken, mine- plenty of pork belly) along with spinach and mushrooms).  They were tasty hearty bowls of soup with meat, veggie and ramen, which hit the spot.  We could see where the food was coming from and how the chef was preparing the bowls from where we were seated.  There are seats at the counter for singles and it's amazing how many people are packed into this small space.  We enjoyed our bowls of ramen on this cold blistery day.  Come before 12 if you are looking for lunch
author: Karen W.

description:
Damn - my new fave Ramen place. Sorry Ramen Yamadaya - we have to break up. 

Ladies and gents - this spot is epic. If u love spicy get the habanero ramen. I asked for the habanero to be on the side and half of that was enough to set my mouth on fire. 

House saki: good but over priced for $12. It would be nice if they would give a larger portion or they would cut the price for happy hour. 

Sea weed salad and edemami: pricey for small portions. Small sea weed salad for $8 that's $4 at other places. Meh. 

Staff: polite

My time of visit: 4p - empty restaurant. Warning no street parking near by between 3-7p only garage. 

Broth: excellent 

Will come back.
author: Zita M.

description:
I can see how an "un-trained" ramen eater might find this amazing. But with ramen really having a moment and all the options in town, i really wouldn't waste my time on this place again; we only dropped by because we were in the neighborhood paying our rent on a cold day and for once there wasn't a long wait at lunch hour.

Meat seemed dry and not the freshest; same for the egg...it was hard and seemed like it had been sitting around in a vat with other eggs for a while. Worst of all, we asked for our kimchi to be put on the side, but as the server put our bowls down in front of us, he was like, "sorry, we forgot to put it on the side," as in, "oops we know something is wrong with your bowl but oh well we just can't be bothered to take 10 seconds to scoop it out and make it right." 

The bathroom hallway reeks, probably because - surprise - the filthy trash bins are right there. Lovely way to cap off your meal. Oh and if you didn't know, this place has scored a 70 health rating (FAIL) within the last year and a half, something i was surprised to have read on SFGate recently. Gross.

People probably go here because it seems to be the only choice of ramen in the neighborhood and they don't know any better, which is sad. I personally preferred it when it was in the tiny hole across from where it is now. It's all gone downhill since then.
author: Theresa C.

description:
Was looking for a spot close by work to get a quick dinner. I've worked literally across the street for over two years now, but never went over to try it. Finally stopped by for an early dinner Saturday-- no wait.

Got a tonkatsu ramen and tastes of the spicy miso ramen. The tonkatsu ramen was pretty creamy but not particularly porky in flavor. The pork was fall apart in your mouth tender but cut into different sizes-- there were two thin slices and a giant chunk. Toppings beyond the pork and brown stringy veggies were extra, which definitely made you feel a tad nickle and dimed. Just charge me the extra $2 and throw it all in!

The spicy miso ramen was also just alright. Not particularly spicy, a bit savory. Nothing memorable though. The bar table was definitely a bit too high for the average torso-lengthed person. Service was sparse, decor was similar. Not sure why this place has lines out the door at lunch.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Unlike many of the ramen restaurants in SF, the Ramen Underground has a distinctive and non traditional point of view of how to prepare ramen that as an added benefit tastes good.

I highly recommend getting the habanero ramen - it's ramen with a different flavor and kick.  The Ramen Underground is located in the heart of the financial district and in the evenings there are often long lines.  The exterior and the interior of the restaurant is not as well decorated as other ramen restaurants but the food makes up for it.
author: Mark C.

description:
**Must try in financial district**

Out with a friend , chillin at the SF auto show and lucked out on this place. Apparently it's his fave ramen stop when he's working out here. 

All I know is the ramen/ food is excellent

The old: 
- curb appeal/ easy access for lyft riders 
- modern inside 
- quick service 
- forks for the chopstick impaired 
- food recommendations: 
Gyu don
Teriyaki don 
Spicy soy ramen 

The ok:
- place is awesome but like any bay restaurant seating is limited 
- the tables are midget size/ extra low .... lol the struggle was real for me and my elbows
author: Mariana D.

description:
Ramen Underground is always crowded with people during lunch and dinner especially during fall and winter time. The one distinction is that it uses chicken broth instead of pork broth. The restaurant is small so you do expect a bit of wait unless you come at odd hours or order takeout. 

I actually really enjoy their spicy miso ramen. They give you plenty of pork or chicken as you choose, a half-boilded egg and bamboo shoots as well as corn. One bowl will for sure fill you up without needing to order an appetizer. Their spice sauce is also quite flavorful and has some serious kick. 

I am glad it is nearby my work so I can always go there for a quick bite in the cold!
author: Athena C.

description:
This small ramen spot in SF was recommended to me by a friend. Because it is such a small area, there was a bit of a wait. There are only about 6 or so seats on a 'bar,' 6 seats against the window, and then a few tables that seat 2-4. It was a good sign that the place was full later in the afternoon on a Friday, so we waited about 5-10 min before sitting against the window. 

The menu has a lot of different types of ramen, but the topping selection is not as extensive as others. I got the miso and my friends got the tonkatsu/spicy tonkatsu. The noodles were very good - a bit chewier texture that I really like. However, we found the broth to be a bit salty compared to other places. On the wall, they do have a small illustration with instructions on how to eat/order, and they do recommend getting a bowl of rice to put in the ramen, so perhaps that is the way to go to counteract the salt. Nevertheless, it was a good meal.
author: Margaret K.

description: Ok. Good tonkatsu broth, but somehow my $14 noodle bowl ended up costing me $18.50. Won't be back.
author: David G.

description:
I went into this place mostly because I was partly curious about the reviews on the place, after all, this place is in the middle of the financial district where some of the most amazing cheap eat in downtown San Francisco has to offer, how bad could it be right? 

From the outside, this place looks every bit of a modern gourmet eatery, down to the price of their dishes, cause it ain't at all cheap!

The Ramen noodles itself was not fresh, the pork belly was very chewy and not at all tasty, the broth it used was so blend it tasted more like oil and hot water, I could easily make a instant noodle at home and taste better than this.

This place charges a pretty hefty price for their terrible Ramen, I would have a much much better meal from a worldwide established Ramen house located only a block down the street.
author: Skyler Z.

description:
It was a nice pleasant experience for a Friday afternoon. Kind and fast service. Ordered the Kimchi appetizer and vegetarian soy ramen. Kimchi was nice and cool, not too spicy for my taste. 
Ramen was simple, not too many toppings, have to pay extra for those. Not a big fan of the spinach on the soup, just not used to that I guess. Veggie broth light and a mild flavor. For a $13 soup, I'd give this one 3 stars. It was fresh yet a bit tasteless. Seating was a bit small and awkward but a comfortable ambience. The menu is quite limited. It would've been nice to have more options, especially vegetarian. All in all, it's not a bad place to hang out. Would recommend it. :)
author: Daniela S.

description:
I don't understand this place. Why are there lines out the door everyday during lunch and dinner service? So I thought i would investigate this secret Ramen place and see what it had to offer.

I came here at 4:30pm for an early dinner and it was completely empty sans a handful of customers. The place is actually pretty small as described by some Yelpers, so be prepared to cozy up next to your fellow ramen-lovers. I have been in smaller and more cramped-up ramen restaurants during my time in LA, so the seating here was no problem for me. 

The tonkotsu ramen was very disappointing to say the least. I add-ed on a side of corn and the pork belly. The broth tasted very fatty, not in a good way. While I liked the noodles served here, the bbq pork and the pork belly were chewy and didn't look presentable. The pork belly was nor tender of flavorful. I would have liked it better too if it was sliced in half. You also have the option of adding extra noodles for a dollar, BUT you have to order it when you order your ramen. Otherwise, the noodles will cost two dollars if you add-on later. 

Service was attentive, but maybe that's because there were only two additional single diners and one waitress. I would hate to see what it is like during the lunch/dinner rush. During my meal, one of the workers started rolling out dirty garbage and recycle cans out the front door to the curb, that's a major NO-NO in my book. 

With my tonkotsu ramen plus two side add-ons, I was looking at a bill of almost $20 (including tip) per person. A small bowl of ramen with mediocre broth and meat for $20? No, thank you. I can't imagine even waiting in a 15-20 minute line during rush hour for that same bowl of ramen. During whole dining experience here, I felt I was getting nickel-n-dimed here. Without the add-ons, I felt my bowl of ramen would have been very bare. They even charge you 0.35 cents here if you try to use your credit card! I thought I was going to find a replacement for Ajisen ramen in Ramen Underground, but I came away disappointed and still confused.
author: Philip M.

description:
We found this ramen shop by accident, but I'm glad we did. My bf and I were walking around Chinatown, and nothing sounded good to us, so we decided to go here. Definitely not Chinese, but ramen sounded bomb, since it was cold and all. 

For some reason I expected it to be some what similar to the ramen houses, that we have in San Diego, and I guess you could say that it killed my hopes and dreams. Don't get me wrong, it was good compared to some places I've gone to. 

I got the spicy chicken miso ramen, which was actually pretty good. But I do miss the milky broth that they have at most ramen places. And I was also missing the egg! I hate how it was extra! It usually comes with it! Lol. The chicken was alright, didn't have too much flavor to it. 

My bf got the chicken soy sauce ramen, which was pretty bland. Considering it was made with "spy sauce". And same with the chicken, it also had no flavor to it. 

But we couldn't complain. We were hungry, and it satisfied our belly's for the day. :)
author: Joanna R.

description:
Stopped in here since I was in the area and I remembered it was on one of the 7x7 Big Eat lists. Had the chicken spicy miso ramen. Chicken was slightly off tasting and texture wasn't so great; should have been fresher. Broth was salty and a bit one note, but not enough to deter my hunger. Spice was provided by dried chili flakes...unusual. There was no egg in the bowl...an oversight? 

Service was prompt and the portion was large, however. Not bad if you're on a lunch break and need to stop in for something quick.
author: Ted M.

description:
4.5 stars. One of the best ramen places in SF. Lunch lines can get lengthy but go there after 2pm or for dinner, the line should disappear by then. 

I got the miso ramen (with mushroom, scallion, chicken) and added in soft boiled egg and kimchi and absolutely loved it. The flavor of the broth is just on. The ramen is cooked perfectly - not too al dente not too soft. The yolk in soft boiled egg is cooked to just the right texture. Ramen doesn't get better than this in SF.

I tried spicy miso (they just put spicy sauce in miso) and habanero as base. Didn't like them as much - loosing the original flavor of the broth. Stick to the basics on broth. 

So glad that they moved across the street and expanded the place - so more ramen lovers get to enjoy this on a regular basis!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I don't agree it's tasteless and blank like some of the reviews here said - it tastes like someone accidentally dropped a bag of salt into my 18 bucks ramen, I mean, what could be better than that?

I work a minute away from here otherwise I'd def go somewhere else...
author: Tingjie L.

description: Cool spot over by my work thats always packed. I ordered the spicy miso ramen with chicken and added corn, spinach, a boiled egg, and chicken dumplings. It was filling and spicy without being overpoweringly hot. Service was quick and efficient and it was an all around good experiance.
author: Sean G.

description: Came here with a few co-workers because our catered lunch's good options had been drained by some hungry engineers. Coming here was like waiting for a Yeezy drop and then being slightly catfished with Sketchers shape-ups (like it'll do for almost ironic purposes, but you're not really feeling it). I ordered a spicy chicken miso broth and I feel like I have exceeded my sodium intake for the week. The noodles were flatter than me in second grade. The pieces of chicken floated around like shipwrecked rocks. The spice...well, it was literally pepper flakes, not a dank garlicy spice bomb. Did I really pay $14 for this? I haven't skippped leg day all week long so this shouldn't have been my cheat meal. On the other hand, there is a homey quality to the broth -- it's not too thick or thin, but you wonder if it gives chicken-based ramen a good name. Marafuku's chicken paitan has a lot more legs.
author: Celena C.

description: Walked by and saw empty seats and no line. Was promptly sat and water and menus given.  We had the chicken miso ramen, pork tonkotsu and the pork miso tonkotsu. The pork tonkotsu was definitely better than the chicken based ramen. Only thing it gets pricey as extra toppings are extra. The egg, extra noodles, corn,  even chili paste was extra. The tonkotsu miso ramen was very flavorful and noodles chewy.  Only thing that I wasn't crazy about was the pork belly. It was tender but not much flavor.  Service was very efficient and fast.
author: Alicia A.

description:
The lunch line misleadingly alludes to goodness but Ramen Underground is pretty pedestrian.

Owe the wait to the small space and slower kitchen. That and the takeout orders. The small space gets pretty warm too at lunchtime so not the most comfortable. As hot as it was inside, it's ironic that the ramen arrived lukewarm. In a pinch, it'll do but totally not worth the wait. Better ramen spots in the city. I feel the tonkotsu broth lacked a depth of flavor and complexity that you would expect from a slow-simmered broth of pork bones. Appreciate the addition of fresh spinach though. 

Think they've lost some luster since moving across the street. With more ramen options available close by since, Ramen Underground doesn't have to be your only bet in the FiDi anymore.
author: Jon L.

description:
Food: Had the tonkotsu ramen which was pretty decent. The broth was creamy and hearty, the noodles were well cooked, and the pork was flavorful. Only issue is that there was no egg!

Atmosphere: Super casual. An easy place to grab a quick meal alone. There is a counter top seating as well as table seating.

Service: My only issue with the service is that it seems like the restaurant is really trying to nickel and dime you wherever they can. For example, they not only had spend requirements per person and credit card minimums, but also charged you a 35 cent fee to use your credit card.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This place isnt as good as before. It deserves 5 stars in the past but this is all it have now

Ordered the spicy soy sauce ramen and it was not great. The noodles itself is still very good.  Soup tasted like they didn't have enough soup for the day and just added water. Only got 3 small pieces of chicken, I kept digging and didn't find gold. The bowl did contain a bunch of noodles.

Other ramen places in the area might even be better now (compared to what Underground is now) and less wait
author: Henry T.

description:
3 stars strong.
Everything is average: service, food and interior.


I have tried tonkotsy miso ramen-the most expensive in the menu. I expected some remarkable soup based on the server's recommendation.

In reality:
Broth - nothing special.
Meat was tough- Kakuni (pork belly) had no fat at all, it was super tough. BBQ pork - the taste was good but also tough.
Spinach was fresh, you could taste it's intense flavor more than you should.

Also their health score seem to be 83 out of 100. I'm sure they could do better.  I've noticed that they store the meat improperly - I know the standards pretty well myself.
You can see it in my pic.
author: Sergey S.

description: Monotonic yet unique ramen place I've visited. Fast delivery, excellent spot in downtown area!
author: Moorissa T.

description: It was okay ramen, I probably only liked mine because it was spicy but the pork was a little dry and there wasn't anything special in it and all the stuff to add in was expensive considering it starts at 14$, they used spinach instead of Bok choy which was kinda odd to me, just felt like it was extremely Americanized ramen.
author: Merissa V.

description: It was okay and affordable but the chicken was very chewy and had an odd taste. I wouldn't recommend unless you actually had to. Servers were nice
author: Susie E.

description:
I've now been here twice and it has been great! 
There are two vegetarian ramens (soy and miso flavors). Both times I have gotten the miso ramen and it has been very good.

I have eaten in once and ordered for pick up the second time. It is small inside but we didn't have a wait, maybe because we got there around 12:15- beat the lunch crowd. When I ordered in they said it would be about 15 mins and it was ready when I got there. Great service. 

One complaint is that there should be a spicy vegetarian ramen, siricha, or something to add other than the chili oil. Many spicy options on regular menu. The broth is creamy and tasty for a vegetarian broth, I also love the spinach in it. I got mine without mushrooms because I don't like them. 

For sure will be back!
author: Hayley D.

description:
Do you want ramen you can make yourself? Go here.
Want yakibuta that's not really yakibuta? Go here.
Cool if you want to have a quick SF lunch and you work in a 1-block radius and ramen is the only thing you want. Other than that? Go somewhere else for the same price. It was Ramen Underwhelming.
author: Sean H.

description:
Was there last night with a couple of out of town colleagues, thinking it would be a good spot to fill our ramen cravings.  Haven't been here for over a year.  It is definitely not the same or as good as I remembered it to be.  Wonder if the new location comes with it a new owner.  We ordered the spicy miso with extra
Chasu.  

A couple of things that qualified the 1 star ratings...

It's all about the broth:  the bowls we were served had spicy miso that was blanch (I mean did they forget to season it?... bland).  Where was the
Miso???

They start standardizing  chicken with every bowl.  Chicken was under seasoned, if at all marinated, and again, bland.  Takes away from the broth.

The chasu was under seasoned.

Did this place changed ownership?

Now also seeing the low food safety ratings.  NOT GOOD.

Too bad, this was my ramen fix go to place when it was a small hole in the wall across from its slight less hole in the wall new location. 

Won't venture back to this place again.  Moving on...
author: Ken T.

description: Chased me down for a tip like I'm rich. Very unprofessional to beg for money like that, I'm not coming back anytime soon.
author: Henry L.

description: Probably one of my favorite ramen places! Super fast and friendly service. Gets really busy during lunch for sure because of the financial district. They have to go service too for your convenience. Love the different choices they have for you to choose from! Definitely worth your money because of their homemade broth!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Like some of other ramen places in San Francisco, this place is overly priced (but I understand everything in SF is expensive) but highly unauthentic. The meat from that spicy miso ramen were tasteless also like few days old, even not that warm, just like they were thrown into the ramen bowl right from the fridge. The way they put chili and vegetables in ramen wasn't pleasant either. The only thing authentic was their ramen noodle I guess. The service is nice though.
author: Donduk D.

description: Not my favorite ramen but it definitely satisfies the craving when you're in the FIDI needing a ramen fix. I got the spicy miso ramen and it is just the right amount of heat without having to add siracha. Yum!
author: Emily M.

description: Was craving Ramen so went to this place because it was close by. Was a little disappointed  because the Ramen noodles kind of tasted like spaghetti noodles. I ordered the soy sauce Ramen & the broth was just ok.
author: Mikky T.

description:
I ordered​ the Spicy Miso Ramen with chicken and my friend ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen. They originally messed up my order so I waited awhile for mine. When it finally got to me it wasn't spicy... at all, so I imagine I ended​ up with the plain Miso Ramen? I didn't​ have time to wait for another attempt at my original order so I just ate it. 

I also didn't pay attention when I ordered and didn't realize I needed to add on toppings... for $1 each. 

It wasn't bad, but it wasn't​ the best​. Just Ehh... ​
author: Nicole H.

description:
Very underwhelming, and slightly overpriced. You basically have to pay extra for the things that make ramen... ramen. Will it fill you up? Yes, but it won't satisfy any sort of ramen craving you may have. As for the service, it's neither good nor bad. Definitely not worth the minimum 18% tip recommendation. 

Try it if you want, but there are plenty other, better, restaurants nearby.
author: Carlos M.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend because he's been meaning to try this place. I ordered us both a tonkotsu ramen w/ egg, herb butter, corn, and extra chasu. (Unfortunately everything costs like $1-2 extra). 

Luckily we were seated right away, but sadly the waiter gave us the order of the people sitting next to us. It worked out in their favor because they REALLY liked what I ordered, and kept saying how bomb it was and they appreciated the new ideas they can incorporate next time. This made me feel super excited, like if I'm paying $6 in additions to this ramen bowl, it better be bomb! 

The waiter offered to just flip our bills, (as they got our original bowls and we got theirs), but I wanted what I originally ordered. (The chicken ramen wasn't enough flavor for me). 

The party next to us never got their gyoza and I never got my coke :( taste-wise, I didn't think it was that bad at all, but I wouldn't want to drop $20 on a bowl, you know?
author: Rachel M.

description:
I was extremely underwhelmed at Ramen underground. The broth was very watery, the appetizers were lacking, the dishes seemed hastily prepared, and the ingredients didn't seem to have any substance or quality. Will not be coming back.

To add insult to injury, I had to wait 30m to get in. Service was slow to get us our food and they tried to rush us out. They tried to fit 5 people to a 2 person table ...
author: Sean W.

description:
My colleague's craving for ramen got us to this place. The place was crowded as expected but the line moved pretty quickly. I think we waiting for 15 minutes for out order to-go which is not bad compare to other ramen places in the city. 

I ordered Chicken soy sauce ramen to go which was good but nothing existing. Had good amount of noodle, broth was flavorful but there was hardly any chicken or veggies just few spinach leaves. 

She got the Chicken Miso ramen and she loved it !! I didn't taste it but she was really excited about it and wanted to come back again. 

Service was good and ambience is like any other Asian place.
author: Simran K.

description: Not a good option for vegans. Mind you, I recognize that ramen is not inherently vegan but most SF places have begun offering interesting, creative vegan options. Ramen Underground offers two soy broths, but no vegan noodles. That said, this place is fine for vegetarians, but it's a no-go for vegans...unless you like to eat broth with a side of rice, which is what I did and do not recommend it.
author: Christina M.

description:
Just OK - nothing special!
This is a very small place and plain. Really not much in the way of decorated. Our food came out quite fast and our server seemed to rush us way to much. Each time we laid our spoon or chopsticks down she would try and remove our half eaten Pho! The Pho itself was nothing special and nothing I would want again!

https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g60713-d3652301-r526152399-Ramen_Underground-San_Francisco_California.html#
author: Cinda S.

description: First time here, trying Ramen and I fell in love!!! So delicious and the Sake is off the wall!! You have to try if your in the area :) service was fast even though it was busy.
author: Victoria D.

description: The Ramen Underground used to be my favorite ramen in SF, back then they had a location in japan town which was much bigger then the one in downtown. I also liked the decor much more in Japan town. I used to love their ramen because it tasted very healthy and they didn't add to many random things. A few years back the japan town location closed all of a sudden. I went with friends and we stood in front of a closed restaurant and many other people as well that traveled from the other side of gg bridge just to eat there. I moved to L.a and had a lot of ramen there but I was very excited to come back to SF and have underground ramen again. We went to the downtown location and to my surprise there wasn't a huge line like normally, we got a seat right away. We ordered and to our surprise they no longer offered mushrooms! I have never heard of anything like this before in any restaurant. We asked why and they told us that customers didn't liked them. Ok.. we got our ramens and the where ok. I asked for the red Japanese spice, but they only had the red peppers that you put on pizza not the powder like they used too. I was a bit disappointed. This used to be my favorite ramen place. Now I feel it is really to pricy for what it is. Toppings are very expensive as well. I know sf is an expensive city but I feel it is to much for broth and some noodles. I also really miss the decor from the japan town location and the one from the old downtown location when it was on the other side of the street.
author: Linda M.

description:
Only recently I discovered the joy of good ramen & specifically, tonkotsu broth. Apparently I'm late to the party, so I've been doing my best to catch up. I've eaten ramen at 5 different restaurants in the last few months.

Spoiler alert: best ramen? Ramen Underground.

I honestly can't believe all the nit-picky reviews. What do you people expect? Ramen on gold platters? Ramen made out of unicorns? Where are you getting better ramen? Seriously tell me because I want to eat it!

Recently went to Ippudo that just opened in Soma. It was good, but imo, not as good as Ramen Underground -- and way more expensive to boot. But it's good if you enjoy an extra helping of pretension with your food.

Went to Ryujin Ramen in Sacremento. It was excellent and priced more reasonably, however I still think Underground would edge it out if they went head-to-head. However I guess Ryujin would be a better value because it was much cheaper.xt

Last place I had ramen recently was in Oakland when I was sick. I can't really compare it because they made me an order to-go when they don't normally do that and it was missing some key elements (uhh like chashu).

Also I usually go to Ramen Underground after the lunch rush (around 1:30 or 2), and never have to wait long (ten minutes max). Then once we're seated, I've been amazed at how quickly they slam out orders. We sit, order, and have our food in under 5 minutes every time. I've been there maybe 4-5 times now.

Anyway here's what makes Ramen Underground really stand out:

*TONKOTSU*
First off, I don't really understand ramen without tonkotsu broth. It doesn't make sense to me. Second, the tonkotsu at Ramen Underground is truly outstanding. Creamy, flavorful with great mouthfeel and so much umami it could break the internet.

*PORK BELLY*
Every (other) place I've ordered ramen has mentioned pork belly on the menu. Maybe they mean they make chashu out of pork belly? I'm not sure. But when I get ramen other places, it always comes with 2 thin slices of chashu (round-ish slices of pork). But at Ramen Underground, it comes with 2 slices of chashu AND 2 cubes of pork belly. You read that right. FOUR PIECES OF DELICIOUS MELT-IN-YOUR MOUTH PORK. 

I always add an egg (their eggs are consistency of medium-boiled) and spicy paste.

If you REALLY need to overdose on richness, add miso to your broth. Good god, it's almost too rich to finish that way.

I'm sure I don't really know how to evaluate ramen noodles properly. But it's definitely because I'm too distracted by the broth & the pork. If other reviewers have problems with the noodles, I can neither confirm nor deny. But I will stand by my evaluation of the broth & pork till death. Which will be much sooner thanks to all this bone broth & pork.

Thanks for reading and I'll see you at Ramen Underground.

EDIT: Worth noting that the ramen here ain't cheap. It's 2nd most expensive behind Ippudo. ~$16 for me typically.
author: Steve H.

description: It's more than likely the ramen I ordered, which was vegetable soy sauce ramen, but it was beyond plain. The noodles were okay, broth literally was just water. At least to me. Overall it was okay but, would I go again? Probably not.
author: Anthony U.

description:
I've been to Ramen Bar, Kiramachi, and Kan Ramen, but Ramen Underground is my go-to ramen spot in the area.

Price-wise, all these spots are the same. Total is about $17 after tipping. Some people have complained that you get fewer ingredients at Ramen Underground for the same price. It's true that the ramen bowl here is pretty basic. Standard bowls come with just chicken/pork, spinach, and onions; there is no egg, which is a deal-breaker for some people (I personally think the egg is overcooked in a lot of the ramen shops). 

However, the broth here is delicious! I'm not into super-creamy soup bases, and I think this place can do broth just right. It's flavorful without being overly-filling. The spicy miso ramen also has just the right amount of spice. For that, I can forgive the lack of egg and 2 squares of seaweed that people seem to care so much about. 

This place is tiny though. Tables are big enough for just you and a lunch buddy. Any more than that and you'll probably have to wait for the bar area to free up (which is pretty uncomfortable to sit at because the counter-top is so high). From what I've seen, this place is packed from 12-1pm, so I recommend coming here before noon.

TL;DR - Good, basic ramen with tasty broth; not good for large groups; come early.
author: Taylor K.

description:
This place had 4 stars on google and 3 on yelp so I went to investigate! 
Value: Ehh. It was almost $40 for my husband and I to eat! After adding dumplings and an egg to our ramen we were looking at $16 and change each. Not sure if it was just the area or what but it felt expensive for ramen.
Food: Delicious! The pork belly was SO flavorful and the spinach really brightens it all up. The dumplings were good but nothing extraordinary. I was definitely completely and utterly full after my meal and we didn't even get apps! 
The Space: Super small! But seems to have plenty of seating. Cute comics on the wall and you can see the chef at work. My biggest complaint was the woman next to me skyping her boyfriend and being obnoxiously loud.. thanks lady! Who Skypes while eating ramen?? So if it's busy be prepared to share the space with potentially annoying customers. Like I said it is close quarters.
author: Akiko S.

description:
Actively disappointed. Got the Miso Ramen to see if they can do a basic ramen right before I ordered anything expensive or extravagent. Had to order the things that make Ramen Ramen extra. Was just spinach, noodles and chicken.

Chicken was cold in center, which is a huge red flag. Had hard bits of something in the Ramen which is an even bigger red flag. Potentially thought it was plastic, but not really sure. Flavor was decent but nothing out of the ordinary. Could use more noodles.

Service was OK but not very good. Charged me 35 cents to pay with card regardless of price, that sucks.

Won't be coming back, it's just bad ramen folks.
author: Dawn H.

description:
My dish was 95% noodles - this isn't ramen in my view, it's noodles with a hint of broth and 1-2 pieces of meat. I'm sure they are making a killing selling packet noodles you could buy for 99 cents and putting 50 cents of toppings on them. 

Quite possibly the worst ramen I've had outside a food court. There are a lot of better places to give your money who make ramen with skill and passion.
author: Adam F.

description:
I finally had an opportunity to try this place.  I ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen.  It came with the organic chicken broth, chicken, mushrooms, green onions, spinach and noodles. Total cost around $14 and some change.  I will tell you what I liked, the noodles were delicious.  The chicken tasted normal vs the disgusting chicken you typically get with Ramen soup.  The veggies were also a good add, fresh and tasty.  The broth was underwhelming and for the price I wouldn't go out of my way to go back here.  It was also not spicy at all.  If you like to add stuff to your soup like egg, etc. it will cost you.  I'd like to mention the service was great, the kitchen staff was fast and really nice and sweet.

Overall basic soup, a little overpriced
author: Samantha S.

description:
The tonkatsu ramen was serviceable. The broth wasn't too flavorful, but the pork and the noodles were quite good. The egg was overcooked with a hard yolk. The spicy paste added a fair amount of flavor--it saved the dish. 

You definitely feel "nickel and dimed" by having to pay for extra toppings that are standard in most ramen shops. But the total price is still reasonable, given the location. 

Service is friendly and speedy. As you might expect, it's crowded and loud, but that's fine.
author: David L.

description:
Decent choice for a cold and rainy day in the city but I feel like they could do a bit better. 

I was back home in the Bay Area and decided to grab an early dinner with a friend. It was raining so the weather was perfect for soup! Did a quick yelp search and decided to walk to Ramen Underground. 

Their menu is decent. You can choose from a variety of chicken, vegetable, or pork-based broths. Of course Ramen Underground offers the usual shio, shoyu, tonkotsu, and miso types of ramen, but you can also find more intriguing options such as soy milk or habanero miso. Most toppings here will run you $1 each while extra meat will cost $2s. 

I ended up with the tonkotsu miso ramen (1 piece bbq pork, 1 piece pork belly, green onion, mushroom, and spinach). Sure, the order was pretty filing and such, however, I just wasn't feeling it. The broth was saltier than I'd like. Additionally, they include pork belly in their ramen which helps add flavor the broth, but I prefer more meat in my ramen as mouthful of pure pork fat doesn't sound that appetizing. I also prefer noodles to be al dente--I blame my old roommate from Yokohama for this--whereas the noodles in my ramen were a bit soft. 

Honestly, Ramen Underground was a little more expensive than I would like. I paid about $2-3 more than what I would expect to pay back home in the East Bay. Damn those SF prices...
author: John B.

description:
This ramen joint is quite small, and probably not the best for a comfortable meal, especially if you're in a big group. But we went because it was in the area. Ramen places for the food, and so here we were!

- Miso ramen: the noodles were fine, and the soup was ok, the shredded chicken was normal, but the mushrooms were undercooked... Even after trying to cook the mushrooms by burying them underneath the noodles, a lot of them were not so cooked. 

The server also kind of kicked our group out because we didn't leave right away after paying by saying that other people are waiting in the cold lol. So much for the mandatory 18% group tip. I don't think I'll be back. Hoping to find a better ramen place out there!
author: Joanna C.

description:
The noodle+soup combo has been one of my default go-to foods ever since the art was taught to me as a teenager. So, a restaurant that names itself Ramen Underground while offering tonkotsu* proved a little too difficult to pass up on a cold February night. I walked in on a Wednesday night and sat down in this cosy establishment, looking forward to fill the belly.

Well, it wasn't bad. Soup base? Ok. Noodles? Good. The BBQ pork slice was fine, but the pork belly was tough and stringy. I added an egg, which had the impressions of being soft boiled in soy sauce but ended up a bit salty.

A more labour intensive prep will pan-fry the spring onions, mix up the soup base a bit more, and double down on several 紅麴-encrusted BBQ pork slices without the belly. We're not in the right country/price range for that, I guess. So a 3/5 for a fair deal.

* Milky soup base from pork bone. Originally a Hokkaido, Japan speciality.
author: Poker C.

description:
Just so-so. We're in the area and needed a late night dinner place. Ramen underground showed up on my search results, and just went for it.

The place is really small, and not very clean. Their staff chats a lot and does not pay close attention to customer's needs. I was sitting almost next to where they were standing, and it took a few minutes for them to realize I've been trying to get their attention. 

Their food is just okay. We ordered a few rice bowls and a tonkatsu ramen.  Not sure if we'll be back.
author: Kathleen Y.

description:
Attention is really nice. Really kindly waiter. The space are clean and functionality. The food is nice, feel with too much oil. All the menu is explained by the waiter and they teach you how to use the tools to eat and how they prepare the food. The bathrooms are cool and clean. 

Is nice the schedule because many places of ramen close between 3-5 pm that's is frustrating. This place is open all the afternoon so it's a good stop.
author: Karolina L.

description: Ok. So I haven't read any of the previous reviews so I am not comparing to those. This ramen, I had the spicy chicken ramen, is amazing. Don't read the rest. Just trust me. So amazing.
author: Shelley F.

description: Passed by this place a few times, since it is close to work I decided to give it a try. I ordered the vegetarian ram with soy sauce noodles and was completely underwhelmed. Ambiance was nice, restaurant is small. Experience was meh. The food was where they lost a lot of points. The mushrooms were hard (tasted like maybe they were dried), everything else was okay until I found chicken in my dish. Unfortunately Ramen Underground has lost my vote.
author: Elle H.

description:
Came back recently, despite the low food score warning.... and was disappointed. 

- Broth (2 stars): not served piping hot, just warm and with a thick layer of oil on top, very salty 
- Chicken (2 stars): very fatty chicken, not very tasty
- Toppings (2 stars): very stingy portions of toppings, didn't like the raw mushrooms and spinach.. prefer those to be cooked as others have said. 

Get here early if you don't want to wait, this place generally has quite a few people. 

-----

3.5 stars really, but super friendly service - rounding up. Surprised this place only has 3 stars, organic chicken ain't cheap people!!

~$11.95 pre-tax for organic soy sauce chicken ramen with corn. 

The food:
- Broth: rich and flavorful, organic, MSG-free
- Protein: chicken was a bit sparse, but you can get extra chicken for $2
- Free toppings: spinach and mushrooms are kind of tossed in, but I don't mind it haha, it's not that off-putting like some reviewers mentioned
- Corn (+$1): canned corn, but it's a ramen place for relatively cheap. what can you expect?

Overall, this isn't a bad ramen joint for relatively cheap! I'm a bit spoiled though, as the ramen bar has white meat chicken and I'm really a sucker for that. 

Ambiance is very fun - lots of people, often a line, visible kitchen.  Service is quick and friendly.

Tip: they DO accept credit card (mastercard and visa)
author: Kristie C.

description:
Yep, I'm a fan. If you're looking for a solid ramen place downtown, this is definitely worth a try. Just a heads up, there is usually a line but you can sign up for a table on a small white board next to the front entrance. I would recommend arriving no later than 11:45am, if you can, to be seated in a timely manner. 

Ok, the food. I've had the soy, salt and miso ramen. I prefer things on the spicy side and for that reason, request it to be spicy. I've also had the organic cold tofu. The food is hot (lukewarm ramen is a pet peeve) which brings me great joy. The staff is consistently courteous and nice if I'm having lunch there or getting my order to go. They are busy and aren't really open to much chit chat...that's fine with me, let's get the show on the road and start eating. 

Anyway, try it out. I'm not a ramen snob so don't relate to the other posts that say San Francisco doesn't have good ramen.
author: Julio L.

description:
My friend and I are trying to eat on a budget.  I suggested Super Duper but that was denied because "I already had it a few days ago"...bologna.  My friend suggested Ramen and I knew that if I didn't agree, we would be starving for the next hour deciding where to go.  Right when we were seated, I yelped this place and oh hello, POOR FOOD SAFETY SCORE.  

Me:  Umm, look bro (shows pop up to friend)
Friend:  So what does that mean
Me: That means do you want to die?
Friend:  I ate here last time and thought it was okay
(looks at each other) *shrugs*
Me:  Well, if both of us have massive diarrhea, let's call in sick the next day and hang out

Tonkatsu Ramen - honestly, I was hungry AF and when I'm at that level of hunger, anything and everything usually tastes good.  The broth was bland. the meat was chewy

Friendly staff.  Left content. No diarrhea if you're wondering.
author: Linda N.

description: I got their chicken ramen and it was pretty good - it was no tonkatsu ramen but I'm sure if I had gotten that, it would've been just as good if not better than other SF restaurants.
author: Joanna L.

description: We showed up very hungry and wanting to try some delicious Ramen but unfortunately the business was closed. This was on a Thursday at 6 PM even though the website says they close at 9:30 PM.
author: Sonia C.

description:
As the name suggests, it's got a hipster, grungy atmosphere. This place is tiny! It's not the most brightly lit, and with the low ceilings and tight space, it really feels more like a basement than a restaurant (if you're one for personal space, don't come here).  

You have a choice for your soup base to be either chicken, pork or VEGETARIAN (yes, vegetarian's, unite). But just FYI, like most vegetarian soup bases, it's not the most impactful or tasty (or at least from what I could remember when I first came here years ago). 

Tonight, I decided to give a new broth a try (I wanted flavor dammit!). I ordered the Habanero Miso Ramen, which is in a chicken broth, and it's toppings came with chicken, green onions, mushroom and spinach- I know, I know, not your most traditional ramen. In addition, I added an egg, corn and slab of herb butter. First of all, the Habanero miso is no joke - my mouth was on fire! It was almost painful eating my ramen (and I have a pretty high tolerance for spicy food). The herb butter? Yea, didn't do or taste much since the lower half of my face was numb, but I imagine it would add a nice flavor to the whole mix. Can't say much about the chicken since I gave it to my non-vegetarian date, but he said that "it would've been better with cha-shu". All the veggies in my soup was a refreshing take on ramen instead of the usual bamboo shoots. Overall, I was satisfied with my ramen (or from what I could eat and taste). Next time, I'll stick with the vegetable miso ramen, just so I could taste my food in peace (and that herb butter).
author: Rebecca L.

description: Feeling like you're coming down with a cold? Need something tasty but mild to soothe your body? This is the place! I came here last week when I wasn't feeling well and was shocked. I didn't know soup could taste this good. Maybe I'm a Ramen novice, but this was so so delicious. Will be back again and again.
author: Ayanna A.

description:
Sometimes a short line out the door, and place is a little cramped. I usually get the ramen and gyoza for dinner. Overall taste is just ok, because it tries to be a little too healthy. The broth is chicken based and ramen has a handful of spinach and sliced mushrooms. 

So I recommend this place if you want some warm healthy soup on a cold day, but if you are a ramen fanatic, prob won't hit the bar for you. And for the record, I do come here semi-regularly. Enjoy!
author: James S.

description: I love Ramen. I went two nights while in San Francisco. The first night I had the Habanero Miso Ramen. It definitely had a kick and at times too much of a kick. The next night I had the spicy miso ramen which I wish had a little more of a kick. Not a fan of the chicken that they put in it. I would rather have the bbq pork. Overall, a decent ramen spot.
author: JeVaughn W.

description: One of my faves and often have enough to take home! Nick is fabulous and always welcoming!!
author: Nikk M.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the whole world!  I used to live in the city and would eat here almost every weekday for lunch.  Now that I live out of state, I make sure this is my first stop every time I get to come back for a visit.  I have yet to find a restaurant anywhere else that comes close to the flavors I get here.  My favorite thing to order is the spicy miso ramen.  I love the dumplings (pot stickers) they put in.  The spicy miso is the perfect level of spice, enough to feel a kick, but not so much that that is all you taste.  The wait staff is great, too.  Most of the time you will have to wait for a table, but it is definitely worth it.  And once you're inside, you get served pretty quickly.
author: Megan M.

description: Good ramen, divers choices. Quick service (we went on a weekend / mid afternoon). There was nothing wrong with the place. I will be back.
author: Morea P.

description:
Good place for a quick ramen fix, but it isn't my first place to go. The prices are a little more steep than I've experienced,but I figured it's because they're located in the smack middle of FiDi on Kearny competing with other lunch joints in the area. What I find a little funny about this place is that their basic toppings are a little out of the ordinary, especially the spinach and mushroom. They don't include an egg in basic toppings! (extra egg is +1.50) :(. I usually end up ordering an egg and corn to add in the bowl.

The thing here is that the portions are HUGE. They aren't cheap about the noodles and the broth is pretty good. They generally use MSG free chicken broth which isn't very common, but some people like it. I tried their tonkotsu ramen the other day and the first time I had their miso. Not bad, but I wouldn't come out of my way here. They do offer tsukemen though! I'll definitely be trying that next time.

Expect to spend about $15-$18 for a good bowl of ramen. Also during lunch hour I've seen a crowd outside the door waiting since the restaurant itself is pretty small. If possible, go after 2pm or before 12!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Ah so disappointing - expensive, bland ramen that was a waste of carb real estate. Came here based on the recommendations of my coworkers, but definitely did not get the hype. Ramen is supposed to be many things - hearty, warm, satisfying, rich. It's not really supposed to be healthy, which is what Ramen Underground tries to do, sucking away everything that makes ramen so enjoyable. Either that or they're just being cheap with ingredients. 

I got the tonkatsu ramen because it came with pork. Otherwise, standard toppings are spinach, mushroom, and chicken. Extra toppings such as egg cost anywhere from $1 to $2.50, and you can quickly spend $20 just trying to get a decent bowl of ramen. 

Broth was watery and lacked the rich pork flavor of tonkatsu. Noodles were okay, but on the hard side. Toppings were a disappointment - I put spinach and raw mushrooms in salad, not my ramen. The pork slices were hard and too salty, with none of the melt in your mouth tenderness you expect. The only saving grace was the kakuni pork, which was savory, creamy, and delicious. However, the piece was tiny, not the long strip of meat I've gotten at other ramen shops. 

Top it off with a crazy long line, and you have over-hyped, expensive, not tasty ramen.
author: Hali M.

description: Ramen wasn't that good. Pork was cold so had to put it under my ramen. Soup also tasted way to thick/oilly feeling.
author: David M.

description: This place used to be pretty solid...what happened?  Maybe it was since we went near closing time but there were just so many things wrong.  Our order wasn't correct....and my noodles were lumped together (so not spread apart when they were cooked)...seriously ?!?!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This place looks like one of those cute hole in the wall restaurants. There is very limited seating so I would not recommend coming here with a group bigger than 4 people. There was a line out the door the entire time that I was there, and the entire time I was eating. 

Maybe it's just me, but I don't find this place to be very authentic. When I asked for mine to have spicy paste, what they gave me was chili flakes and the spicy garlic paste that people use more commonly in Chinese and Vietnamese cuisine. I've had my fair share of ramen places, and not one place has ever given me spicy garlic paste to flavor my broth. The meat that they gave me was so dry as well, the texture was just offputting. 
The broth was decent, a little bit salty but decent. However, the noodles were over cooked. I could have looked past all the other factors, but having overcooked noodles was just the deal breaker for me. 
This restaurant just wasn't for me.
author: Lydia L.

description:
As others have said in these reviews, only come if you're in the neighborhood and have limited options. I've been here twice and both times have been mediocre. The ramen here isn't like other shops -- there are no eggs or bamboo shoots included. I got the habanero miso the second time and the broth was much better than the soy sauce one. 

Seating can be tough to get sometimes because the shop is on the smaller side.
author: Lucy G.

description: Great ramen, had the habenero miss and blew my mind. Broth was good, very spicy, and the noodles were perefect. 10/10 would come again
author: Sam M.

description: Ordered the Tonkotsu soup and it tasted like water. My friend got the soy sauce ramen and it was the same. Broth was so bland that we had to ask the waitress for soy sauce.
author: Christine N.

description:
Long line, small space but the their habanero miso ramen is delicious & of course spicy!

Went there again though & it wasn't as spicy so not really sure which is the norm. 

Will have to find out next time I go, straight cash homie!
author: Roger D.

description:
I've passed by this chalkboard-laden venue many times, along the border of FiDi & Chinatown, but I have actually only dined at the former J-Town location. 

$12.95 Tonkotsu Ramen w/ bbq pork, kakuni, green onion, mushroom, spinach - 
added a boiled egg for $1.50
I received a large bowl of thick, chewy noodles immersed in milky pork broth. The soft-boiled egg was nice and runny. The fatty chashu melted apart in my mouth, but I could have used a couple more slices. The flavors of the kakuni cubes also bled nicely into the broth. It was topped with spinach leaves and sliced button mushrooms. I'm not used to button mushrooms, nor am I a fan of them. Also, the spinach looked like it was thrown on top as an afterthought as opposed to being cooked in the broth. As much as I enjoyed slurping all the noodles, I felt it was considerably saltier than most bowls of ramen.
 
I give this bowl of ramen a 7/10. If I could lower the level of salt and swap out the mushrooms for some bamboo shoots instead, then it would be more of a solid 4/5, but I'll round up.

Now I haven't actually dined at this location, because there's always a ridiculous line at lunch. Another deterrent is their cash-only policy. When ramen costs about $12-$14 per person, I don't see why they can't just operate with a credit card terminal. How much cash do restaurant owners think people are walking around with these days?
If I did have the opportunity to dine here without having to wait a long time, I'd probably try the more interesting options, like the Tomato or Soy Milk Ramen.
author: Joy W.

description:
Oh Ramen Underground, what happened to you? You're like that young child star that had so much promise and I couldn't wait for you to grow up only to see you turn into a junkie.

Ramen Underground used to be the ramen place in the Fidi area. Their noodles had good bite, their eggs were softly boiled, and their broths were rich and tasty even if they didn't have the tonkotsu option. The only thing lacking was that the chicken they included with their ramen was dry. 

Now they've gotten bigger and expanded their menu to include chashu and stewed pork with tonkotsu, but their quality has gone down. The noodles are too mushy, their eggs practically solid in the middle, and their broth too salty without any complexity.
author: Judy C.

description:
I don't understand the hype of this place and judging from the reviews - I'm not the only one. FiDi has it's share of overpriced and lackluster food - Ramen Underground fits that bill too. 

The noodles were too firm, broth was thin and lacked the rich hearty flavor found in most ramen broths, the toppings were scarce and unauthentic (regular button mushrooms and spinach??) to add an egg was $1.50 more - for 1 egg?! 

The tonkatsu ramen came with 1 microsized piece of pork - granted it was stated on the  menu but for $13 a bowl you think they could spare another piece. The spicy miso ($12) was decent but again - soup flavors were thin and lacking. The chicken wasn't shredded or cooked with the ramen - just a chunk of lukewarm chicken that was probably premade - refrigerated then heated with the hot soup when thrown in. 

Most ramen places have the normal japanese dry chili spice available - here their version are the chili flakes from your local pizza joint - yes pizza chili flakes and hot oil are your options. Either that or you pay an extra dollar for the spicy paste which seems to be chili flakes mixed with miso and hot oil.

The service was quick and friendly which was nice. But the food and the payment policy for subpar ramen gives this place an air of undeserved pretentiousness. The minimum charge per person is $11 which is equivalent to their lowest priced bowl of ramen. They do accept visa and mastercard but will charge you 35 cents to use it. Do a quick search on yelp and you'll find other ramen options close by that seemingly have better food and policies. 

Skip
author: Brenda L.

description:
This might be one of my favorite ramen places in San Francisco. Hands down!

The line is long. The wait is long. But I was craving for that ramen! We went during lunch hour and the rush was no joke. We waited for about 30 minutes til our names were called, but it was worth it!

The ambiance is very clustered and can get a bit loud. I appreciate the bar seating having custom cubbies for people to put their personal belongings.

I had the soy based soup with extra pork belly and an egg for $14 total and wow... It was so amazing! It was my first time having soy and it was very flavorful. I definitely had food coma after this meal but I have no regrets! I can't wait to come back!
author: Linda K.

description:
Been here twice now when I was craving some ramen around the area. I had the pork tonkotsu ramen both times. 

The broth is flavorful but not as fatty or creamy as some other ramen places. The mushrooms are a little too raw for my taste and it feels like the ramen just has too few toppings in it. Standard toppings that come with the ramen in other shops cost extra here. The chashu BBQ pork that comes with the tonkotsu ramen is a bit tougher than I would expect. The pork belly was good but not exactly melt-in-your-mouth either. 

Overall, it's a decent place if you're craving ramen but the price for a bowl definitely racks up if you want toppings that are standard at other places. I'll be on the lookout for something better next time.
author: Jason W.

description:
What a terrible experience! Since they use chicken, instead of chashu like a real ramen place, and their chicken is never tasty, I decided to order a spicy soy sauce ramen without chicken. However, I do like spinach. So, while asking to have no chicken, just like at some other places, I asked the server guy, can I have more spinach and maybe mushroom instead? Oh yeah, he AGREED! 

The ramen was served. Honestly, the 'extra' spinach or mushroom wasn't really noticeable. Maybe they forgot, I thought, oh well. 

When the bill came, guess what? They charged me for both spinach and mushroom. $18.45 for a bowl of ramen, before tips! 

Clearly this business uses every opportunity to charge customers. In addition to that, their receipt doesn't have itemized charges. Do they do that on purpose??

I don't like to give one star as I understand small business is tough. However, today's experience at Ramen Underground is very disappointing!
author: Jasmine W.

description: Totally sad and underwhelming. I ordered the veg miso ramen cause it came recommended by the server. For $14 (more than their meat ramens) you get miso soup, with spinach and two pieces of cold tofu. There is nothing more to it, literally just miso paste in water with some raw spinach dropped on top. The soft boiled egg, which was additional, was hard cooked. Never coming here again. The waitstaff were also not accommodating at all--don't waste your time when there are so many better places right around the corner!
author: Mathew S.

description:
My friends and I came here one night for dinner after a few happy hour drinks and we were craving some ramen. We knew this place was small so we put our name down and patiently waited. The server told us that for a party of 8 would just be 20 mins. 20 mins? That's not too bad. Little did we know that we had to end up waiting over an hour to be seated. 20 mins...ya right! They only have a few tables that can be pushed together and we even offered to split our group up because we were really hungry. Instead they ended up seating several groups after us right away in those spots. They completely forgot about us until we complained several times. I even overheard a server say, "Oh no, where are we going to put them?" Maybe you should have thought about that when you first quoted us an hour ago!

We ended up getting sat at the bar area which wasn't too bad because we were starving and all we wanted was some ramen. Something that I like about this place is that they have different broths to choose from. They have chicken, vegetable, and tonkotsu. Most places just have the regular tonkotsu or pork broth, but I don't really eat pork all that much so this was a great alternative. I ended up ordering the Spicy Miso Ramen with an egg ($1.50 extra) and organic tofu ($1). It also comes with chicken, green onion, mushroom and spinach. The ramen was average not awful, nothing too special. I could barely taste the spicy miso, I should have gotten the Habanero Ramen. Maybe it would have had more flavor.

The only thing that saved this restaurant was that the servers were pretty fast and attentive once we sat down. They also had pitchers of beer here so that was good. However, they ran out of hot sake for the day, which seemed silly to me. Oh well, probably not coming back here.
author: Theo T.

description: Recommended ramen place just outside of Chinatown-- downhill!  Vegetarian, pork, and chicken with different topppings available. Also a few apps.
author: Joe E.

description:
I've been here a few times with my co-worker and wasn't sure what to expect, as it seems like a popular spot in the FiDi. I pass by this place often and find that it's always so packed with people. Sometimes there are even people waiting outside for a table. The inside is fairly small, but I think there are enough tables for the size of the place. But the place is definitely busy during lunch, so I would stay away or come back a different time (closer to the end of lunch).

I get tonkatsu flavor at every ramen spot I go to and I hate to compare it to other ramen spots I've gone to, but the flavor here is decent. It's salty, but I don't taste the tonkatsu flavor as much as I would like. I did like the meat. It was nice and tender. Soft and easy to eat. The meat was pretty tasty. The prices are a little high for a smallish bowl of ramen, especially when you have add a dollar for each topping (like green onion, corn, mushroom) and $1.50 for a boiled egg. It all just adds up in the end.

It's a decent ramen spot. I would probably want to come back for the convenience, but would probably make the trek for another ramen spot with tastier broth.
author: Meghan J.

description:
This was the first time I've see a "Poor Food Safety Score" on Yelp and it kind of freaked me out a little. There were a decent amount of people eating here and we decided to take the chance. I got the Spicy Miso Ramen and it was decent. The flavors and noodles didn't blow me away, but I don't know if it was because I had the poor safety score in the back of my mind that I couldn't enjoy it as much as I could. It wasn't bad though - the broth were decent, the noodles were decent and the meat was decent.

Overall, it was okay.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Came here for lunch with my co worker, decided to try Ramen Underground, since we usually go to the one across the street.

We came here around 3PM so no wait. Service was fast and staff were attentive. Environment was pretty small. I ordered the Soy Milk Ramen that was recommended by my friends. It was OK, the broth was pretty good, not drizzled in MSG and sodium. Chicken was kind of rough however the noodles were good, chewy and fresh. The toppings were spinach, mushrooms and green onions. It was kind of eh...I have had better. Mushrooms were like not cooked, its what you would put in salads. Wasn't feeling that. 

Overall experience was OK, I rather go to the ramen shop across the street, Sushi Bay.
author: Natalie L.

description: Ok ramen with interesting selection of broths, however lacks flavor and ingredients don't add much.
author: V V.

description:
No respect for vegetarians !!! I found some peaces of chicken in my bowl !!!
After a wrong order were a choose a chicken ramen instead of a vegetarian one, they kindly propose to change but they just took away the chicken from the bowl and add some tofu. 
Disgusting !!!!
author: Gaël M.

description: Over-hyped, over-priced, and I found A BUG in my ramen. Safe to say I won't be coming back anytime soon.
author: Carl W.

description: I've become somewhat of a ramen snob lately. There wasn't anything spectacular about it, except for the pork belly. It's definitely a place where locals frequent because it was never empty and had a line of people waiting. If you want some good ramen with little to no wait this is the place for you.
author: Angela R.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place only because it's close to my work. To start off, there's definitely not a lot of room inside so I definitely recommend not going during lunchtime. I think it seats around 20 people, if that. 

Everything from the atmosphere to the taste to the service was average. I paid $12.95 for the tonkotsu ramen plus $1.50 for the egg. It came with 1 piece of chasyu, 1 piece of pork belly, spinach and mushrooms. You have to pay extra for literally everything else such as corn, sprouts, etc. We even had to pay $1 for each serving of spicy paste...

The meats were decent, but some pieces were extremely dry. The whole boiled egg was still cold inside - I assume they don't cook it to order like other places that make sure the yolk is still runny in the middle. I'm not sure if they add spinach at other places either but I've never seen it done and definitely didn't like the addition of that and the mushrooms. I would've much preferred just one piece of seaweed and some sprouts. The broth was not as rich and flavorful as ramen should be either. 

For $16 a bowl altogether I'm not quite sure it was worth it. It's in a really great location and is an okay fix if you're really craving some on a random day but I'm sure there are plenty of better ramen spots elsewhere.
author: My N.

description:
The soy milk broth is probably one of my favorite ramen broths I've ever had. It was so milky and savory! And the noodles were really good too. Different from the normal ramen noodles.

The meat I wasn't too much of a fan of. I tried the pork belly, the cha siu, and the chicken--all were overcooked. The ramen bowls are pretty bare bones with whatever protein, spinach and mushrooms. Everything else costs extra and eggs are a whopping $1.50.

Now the broth... I wish they bottled it because that would be my new water.
author: Shannon L.

description: This is the best Ramen Bowl I've ever had in my entire life.
author: Traun L.

description:
Yo, for starters it's CASH ONLY. The entire place is small...but larger than the old location. There is almost always a line too. You walk up, write your name on the whiteboard then wait to be seated.

They have various flavors to choose from and on this particular day, I was feeling fierce so I went with this Spicy Miso ramen. It comes with chicken, spinach, and mushrooms. I added corn and an egg because why not. It was a pretty quick turn around from my order to receiving my food.

Yes, it was hot in temperature...it was not necessarily spicy though. Probably for the best. It was flavorful though and I really loved the chicken. I'm not exactly able to pinpoint why I loved it so much, but I did. I might skip the egg next time and ask for no spinach. The portion was HUGE. I really couldn't finish it all...and I can eat.

Most of the seating are bar stools. There's a few tables.  As a solo diner, it's a great place to go and not feel like the weird, cat-lady, that's dining alone again.
author: Sierra R.

description:
I've passed by this restaurant many times and I had high expectations. So one day, I came here with my friend and I was super disappointed as to what I got. My egg was overcooked, my chicken was served in big cubic chunks, and I got raw mushrooms & raw spinach. I never envisioned pizza toppings to go alongside my ramen like this.

When my bowl of ramen came, the broth was warm rather than it being piping hot. That's definitely a let down. The pricing was OK though. The ramen was alright, but this place lost me with all these weird toppings. There are definitely better places to get ramen than here.
author: Victor L.

description: Amazing Fukuju -Junmai Ginjo- Yeah, ok, that's sake and not distilled there, but when drank in the atmosphere of this little hole in the wall it is a very special experience, indeed.  The ramen looks tasty.
author: LA S.

description:
So today I came here for lunch and luckily I got me a seat at the bar right in front of the cooks. This place is pretty small with seating; come early to sign up for a seat.

The place was packed and I automatically smelled the ramen and appetizers straight from the kitchen and middle section where the cooks were cooking up. I ordered the regular soy ramen ($11) with a side of Kukuni (pork belly, $7). The ramen was amazing. It had a nice balance between the soy base and the regular taste of the broth. The unique thing about their ramen here is that, the ramen is topped with bright green spinach. The ramen noodles are buried underneath while the chunky cuts of chicken are spread out. The ramen is simple and tasty which did the job for me. 

The kukuni pork belly is amazing too! The thick slices of pork belly is cooked to perfection with a nice tender texture. The fat is cooked right to where it's consistency is like butter; it just melts. This is one of the best appetizers to pair with any of the ramen. 

The service here is attentive and will get to you asap. They will do anything to get you a seat. They are on time with refills, orders, and bill pay. Ramen Underground is one of the best ramen I've ever had. It's def one of my top three.
author: Allister D.

description:
The poor food safety score is definitely real, my friend found a weird circular object (like a magnet) in his soup!!! The restaurant did deal with it very professionally, offered to give him another order of the ramen and took it off our final bill as well.

Before this incident, I have come here a couple of times for lunch. Food is decent and reasonably priced. I usually get the Spicy Miso Ramen w/ a Boiled Egg. The portion is great. You won't feel too stuffed afterwards (it would be terrible to be in a food coma while trying to work...), but definitely fulfilled. They don't have a lot of seating, so if you are a big group you might have to wait for awhile. Same thing goes if you come during lunch rush (12pm - 1pm). I have had no problem getting seated right away after 1pm.
author: Angel C.

description: Taste a bit different but still nice ramen . Maybe because I didn't add miso. Would come back again.
author: Jun Z.

description:
Ramen Underground is okay but lost its novelty along with some of its quality when it moved across the street. Maybe that's why it's less crowded than it used to be.

The prices have gone up and they include less toppings than other ramen places. Meh. Well, at least they accept credit card now? They still have the wooden boards listing food and prices from their old location posted on their wall. I personally don't like seeing them since they show their ramen used to be $9. With their ramen being like $13 now, it's unfortunate how the taste isn't as great as when the ramen was $9.

Soy milk ramen is good but has a... nuttier taste than what I remember. Maybe they use a different soy milk now, who knows. I tried the tsukemen the last time I went and it was okay; I'd order it again perhaps. It would have been better if the broth was hot since mine was just warm. The chili oil and pepper flakes they have available gives your ramen a kick if you want. The highlight for me were the noodles; they have a delicious amount of chewiness.
author: Liana F.

description:
I would have to say that when we first arrived on a Saturday mid-day...the line outside was not too long. We were second in line, but on the inside of the restaurant, it was packed.
