So we literally waited a good 20 minutes to get a table.  My party was a table for 2 and like the traditional Ramen houses Ive been to....... this is usually the typical theme.  "EAT AND GO".  

We were lucky to get a table.  If you dont get a table, you will be sitting at the counter/bar with the chef.  Which is cool too.

The environment inside was pretty clean.  Bathroom looked pretty clean too.

Simone ordered the Veggie Ramen - which had a mushroom broth and Habanero sauce and Boiled egg

I ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen with Boiled egg with Chasu

All Ramen dishes all have the typical green onions, spinach, noodles and shitake mushrooms. 

I really enjoyed my Ramen.  The broth tasted very deep and yummy.  I ate the whole thing.

Just know that this is not the place to go to have long conversations with your friends.  You will get the bill when they see your Ramen is "ALMOST" gone in your bowl.  It may seem rude to people who want to sit long and have conversation with their friends.

Just keep in mind......this is the way it is in Japan.  You eat and go.  People got things to do and fast pace back in Tokyo.

I dont feel like I want to give a full 5 stars because I havent really tasted another Ramen dish yet.  My experience was not spectacular but I really still love the Ramen.  I recommend you try it.
author: Grace B.

description: Haven't been here in a few years, and it's definitely has gone down in quality since the last time I went when they were still in that tiny space across the street.. pretty sure ownership has changed? All signs point to it no longer being Japanese. They didn't get my order right, and my wife's noodles were all clumped together. Amateur hour stuff.
author: Kazu O.

description:
This place is small place and on a hot day like the day I came by it was 99 degrees outside.   Upon walking in we were kindly greeted from the staff and had the choice to pick which seats we wanted.   Since it was hot inside we decided to take the table close to the door so we can feel any type of breeze coming in.

On this particular day I was with a friend and we decided to order some ramen.  I take a quick glance on the menu and I usually order the tantan  ramen, it was unfortunate but I did not see the ramen available.  But it's ok I'm a mad genius and will find a way to make this bowl spicy.  My buddy ordered his tonkotsu chicken bowl and I get the tonkotsu pork with extra pork and a hard boiled egg. Before I go and modify my ramen I decided to take a small taste test of the ramen.  I must say this is a light tasting ramen.  The simplicity of the ramen is here but I did not get something to separate this ramen from any other ramen place I have been to.

We finish our bowl and left this place.  We only wish that the a/c would have been working  during the odd days where it's to close to 100.  If your in a hurry and want some ramen this place will serve you quickly.  They only get a 3 star from me because they didn't really try and stick out from the rest of the ramen place.
author: Anthony M.

description:
A nice little ramen place stored away by the financial district. When I say little I mean little. There's probably enough room for about 20 or so people.  The prices are a bit on the higher end for ramen .. the bill came out to $30 for two, but it makes sense because of the area. I got the tonkatsu and added an egg. Broth was pretty good,  not the best I've had but definitely far from worse. 

I'd definitely revisit the place if I was close by. But I'd really have have to be craving Ramen to pay the price they are charging.
author: Milton F.

description:
I was recommended this place by a colleague. They are famous to have the best ramen noodles in the town. For me, I didn't find it that great. 

Food: 
We tried Soy Sauce Ramen and Miso Ramen. Soy Sauce was supposedly spicy but wasn't much. May be one needs to tell them. Miso ramen was pretty okay. May be the non-vegetarian varieties are good but nothing much for vegetarians. 

Ambiance:
It is a relatively small place for a restaurant but they have good seating capacity due to the layout. A bit noisy as lot of things going on in a small space. Largely the office crowd during lunch and dinner hours. They have a board outside where visitors who wish to dine-in can write their names and the number of people to get into the wait list when the restaurant is full. 

Service:
Service is good and fast. The people are nice and helpful. We had takeaways both the times but had good interactions.

Overall, nothing much for you if you're a vegetarian.
author: Jay M.

description: A dingy place with a queue and whiteboard outside for names... what could go wrong!? Nothing... we were recommended to come here and wow was not disappointed, I had the chicken miso spicy ramen and it was great, the noodles actually had bite and chew... by the end of it even though not that spicy my brow was chilli sweating! All in all an excellent lunch... full of the office crowd at lunch time and is tourists were in the minority for sure... I will be back...
author: Reg B.

description:
I only came here because the Japanese curry restaurant across the street was super packed and my friends wanted a place to sit and eat. And of course I saw the reviews for this place so I was super hesitant but decided to try it for myself. 

Anddddddd it's exactly what the others have said. The ramen is super Americanized :( It didn't taste authentic at all. They put raw spinach and mushrooms that you'd put in spaghetti in their ramen. If you want to add spice, they have chili flakes...like the ones you put on your pizza. Thankfully they also have chili oil which I used instead. What I can say is that their pork belly is super tender, the boiled egg was cooked perfectly and their ramen noodles had a good texture. Broth was meh, I got tonkatsu ramen with an egg added ($12) but it tasted more like chicken. I guess since they use chicken broth? 

Oh and this place is cash only! The service was ok, pretty quick but overall I wouldn't come here again. I've had better ramen elsewhere and considering how many other options there are to eat in Chinatown, I won't miss this place. It's better than your packaged ramen forsure but doesn't compare to most ramen places in the city or even along the peninsula.
author: Shelly W.

description:
It's Americanized Ramen made here.

Their veggies and mushrooms were diced as if it's from Costco supply and there wasn't a Japanese feel to those ingredients.  The chili peppers are like those sprinkled on pizzas.  Not the peppery ones for Japanese goods.

Ramen noodles were aye okay.  I liked the tonkatsu broth.  Beef was tender and pork slices were nice. 

Cash only.
author: Tiffany D.

description: I came here for lunch with a girlfriend around 1pm. We got seated right away. After looking at the menu for 10 minutes, I decided to order the tonkotsu ramen, which only came with spinach and mushroom. I added side order of the boiled egg, corn and Kimchi. Most places includes the boiled egg for you, so I was surprise this place didn't but it is probably because it is located in the financial district. The noodle came after 10 minutes. The broth had taste to it but it was nothing special to me. The noodle was also decent. It did get soft after 10 minutes of eating into it and that I didn't like. I like it when my Ramen stay chewy. The Kimchi and corn was good. The boiled egg was a little cooked. I like mines more raw.  Service was good. Decor was simple and nothing too fancy. Overall this is a decent place for a quick lunch.
author: Sandy A.

description:
What can I say except that I've had better ramen. I'm fond of this place out of convenience. It's super close to where I work and nothing beats ramen when it's cold/rainy outside. 

Broth: The broth lacks flavor. It didn't taste bad, I enjoy it for the most part but it was lacking the richness and savoriness I usually find in good broth.

Noodles: Okay. It was chewy which I liked.

Pork: Overcooked. Not great and I actually was a little bit glad that they didn't give that many pieces. 

Things I did like about it was that they actually give you vegetables (spinach) which I very much appreciate! The portion size was pretty good and their service was quick.

They do charge $0.35 cents for using card so if you don't want to pay the extra fee then make sure you have ca$h on hand.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Haven't found a better chicken based ramen soup than the Underground and had been recommending this place to friends for healthier alternative. I always visit this place whenever I am in the city. Today I ordered 3 orders for to go, the server was good enough to separate the spinach, onion and mushroom but mix the noodle in the hot soup. When I asked to separate the noodle the server said it's too late and hurried to pack the food and hand over the food, he could just easily drain the soup to a different container but not willing to help. Bad service and disappointing (even-though I gave him 15% tip). When I get home as expected the soup was completely absorbed the noodle expand to a full bowl. I hope they will do better next time.
author: Paul T.

description:
Was looking around for a place to eat and Ramen Underground just happened to be on my route back home. I was a bit confused with the messy menu design on the wall inside. It was hard to read and just... there.. 

SERVICE: Honestly i thought the service was fast here. The servers were friendly and kept looking around to see if anyone needed refills/napkins etc. 

FOOD: I got the miso habanero ramen with chicken broth and it tasted exactly how it looked. BLAND. The miso flavor was not there and the toppings were just kind of thrown on. Im not sure if this place is purposely trying to branch out from what real Japanese ramen is suppose to be but this was definitely not it. All the ramen came with was a couple of slices of tough, overcooked chicken breast with spinach thrown on. Another thing i have to ask is whats up with the sliced raw button mushrooms? One thing i was surprised by was the habanero in the broth. Im a girl who LOVES spicy foods and the spice level was there but thats about it. I added corn on top of my ramen which came out to be an additional 1$ MEH. Oh forgot to mention that instead of Togarashi (japanese chili flakes) they have crushed red pepper.. like the one you put on your pizza.. what? I would be offended if i were Japanese. Actually.. im not Japanese and im even offended. What did i just eat?

This ramen spot was ridiculously pricey for what it was. 18 bucks for something that i could have made at home.Not coming back. Lesson learned.
author: Samee M.

description:
This was a convenience stop, as I was in town, had a free evening, was hungry, and needed to grab a quick bite before heading out later. I was within a block or two and knew that a bowl of ramen would be the perfect fit, so I ducked in and ordered a quick bow.

Indeed, my instincts were correct and this was a workhorse ramen spot. While other places have taken the last five years to make ramen a big more precious while it rode the food trend wave, this spot doesn't take itself too seriously. Yes, you have a lot of load-in options with veggies, meats, flavors and styles. Kudos for the creativity. But it's not served up in some fancy boat of deconstructed made-for-photo earthenware over pomp and circumstance. Nope, it's just ramen in a bowl.

I can definitely dig the simple and no-frills approach. It came a long with a hefty bit of efficiency, too. I got my soup quick (I've never understood what could take a long time with soup at restaurants--it's been stewing for a day or two... it's ready!) and I have to give them props for that. Flavor, however, was kind of a disappointment. I had a bowl of pretty straightforward tonkotsu and it really could have used more flavor, more seasoning, and more body. It seemed pretty thin. Maybe it would be better to go with something bold here like the habañero miso that I've read about? I finished the bowl a little disappointed, but I finished it nonetheless. It hit the right spot on the right night. But with so many other ramen spots in town (precious as some may be) I'll probably explore them first before returning to try different dishes.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
For years I have been meaning to come to Ramen Underground but always ended up going elsewhere intimidated by the long lines in front. But nothing like a consumer alert about a poor safety rating to think out the crowds. Hey, I am known to take some chances and saw this as a chance to finally try their food. 

There was no line and we got a table very quickly. I ordered the chicken ramen which soy sauce broth and the gyoza. It was good but not great. The order took surprisingly long even though there were not a lot of customers.  Service was efficient. My title for this visit is "Much Ado About Nothing"
author: Sunil R.

description: This is authentic ramen in the way that seitan is authentic meat. The quality of the ingredients is on par but the flavor lacks everything that makes ramen so great (aka thick, creamy, porky broth)
author: Alexander Z.

description:
Ugh this place. A friend suggested we go here as it was nearby her work but it was a disappointment. The prices are pretty high for how grungy the place is. 

It was a typical cold and windy day in SF and I went to close the front door and the waiter said no because they had no air conditioning?? Another patron tried to do the same later on and was told the same thing..

I got tonkatsu and added an egg (shouldn't it come with at least a half?) and it came with no nori but fresh spinach??? The ramen was fine but not very flavorful, I added chili oil and salt and still felt underwhelmed.

Skip this place and go to Slurp Ramen nearby!
author: Alexandra H.

description: Underground really makes the place feel grungy, but without hidden elements. The ramen is a let down and taste closer to instant ramen and the broth isn't particularly clean, rich, or unique. There are many other better food options in the area, but I would almost treat coming here like going to a fast food chain with not super high expectations.
author: Dion L.

description:
Another bad ramen place. Janky place serving gross ramen with an expensive price tag gouging the business crowd. Ordered the tonkotsu ramen. Broth was super salty and the pork belly was chewy  and tough like beef jerky. The ramen was the same kind that you can buy at the Japanese supermarket. There was raw spinach (weird) included with the ramen. Gave an extra star because the portions were bigger than the other lame ramen places in the city. $13. 

They had the nerve to charge an extra $0.35 for using a credit card, and even writing 18% on the recommended tip list for zero service. Ramen Underground lives up to its name...everything here is comparable to underground sewage.
author: Cheri S.

description:
This place is so small and gets so crowded all the time! Not worth the price eating here. 

I ordered the tonkatsu miso ramen with a boiled egg. The broth is disgusting, taste and smells like old water from the sewer pipes. The noodles are hard and there's definitely more noodles than any other items in the entree. Only 1 piece of bbq pork?!? What a rip off. The bbq pork was dry and hard also. Too much mushrooms, was that really necessary, they weren't even cooked. Everything was just thrown in and didn't look and taste fully cooked. So disappointing!!!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
This is not usually the typical type of ramen that I crave but I think it has its own good things about it too. I got the miso ramen which came with the standard organic chicken, mushrooms, spinach and green onion - none of which are included in my usual ramen palate so this was an interesting change. We also added a soft boiled egg which was just slightly overcooked. I thought the chicken was much too dry/chicken is not my choice of ramen meat and in general I'm just not a fan of raw mushrooms in the soup but I have to say that the miso broth tasted very clean and pure without too much of the saltiness and the fattiness found in the more traditional broths. I would come back if I happened to be in the area but it might not be a place that I would wait in line for.

Cash only which I hate....because a bowl of ramen with 1 or 2 extra toppings will easily put you over $15. General life rule - cash only should only be for places under $10.
author: Evie H.

description:
Way too expensive for mediocre ramen. Remind myself never to come back. Ajisen and Katana-ya are miles better and they're not even great.

Chicken Miso Ramen: 2 stars
miso chicken-based broth not flavourful, maybe tonkotsu might be better but it costs $13. Noodles were like the waxy instant ramen, poor texture not springy enough and didn't taste fresh or delicious.

Also, what's with the spinach they tossed into the soup?  It's very kind of them to care about our health, but it just shows how inauthentic of a ramen shop this is.  At least go for seaweed, leeks, scallions, and shiitake / enoki / other Japanese mushrooms instead of the canned button mushrooms if you want to add some veggies to the noodles.

Kakuni Corn Miso Ramen: 2 stars
Kakuni was boiled meat, they shouldn't charge extra.
author: Letitia L.

description: My new favorite ramen place in the financial district. Their noodles are fresh! The spicy ramen is perfect. Quick service. Convenient location.
author: Sarah D.

description: Good vegetarian ramen options: miso and soy ramen
author: Artem R.

description: Overpriced so so ramen. Seriously don't waste your time or money going here. So many great spots for ramen in the city and this is not one of them. Dissatisfied and disappointed.
author: Crystal B.

description: Total local place. Awesome ramen. Get there early and put you name on the list outside. Then be prepared to wait. But it's worth it!  Spicy miso is the best!
author: Troy T.

description:
My son and I were in San Francisco for a mother-son bonding day & ended our SF visit with dinner at Ramen Underground. I had the spicy soy ramen with chicken. My son had the spicy miso ramen with chicken.

The broth was flavorful. They charge $2 for extra noodles, but I can't imagine needing to order extra noodles because the amount of noodles that you get is pretty generous. 

We both enjoyed our food, and would recommend this restaurant to others.
author: Laura M.

description: This was the whackest ramen I've eaten in my entire life. I wish I could get my money back. Actually, I'd be happy if I could just uneat it. The soup tasted like water and the pork was so dry and had no flavor. Also, Y'ALL OUTTA POCKET FOR PUTTING PEPPER THAT'S USED ON PIZZA OUT AS A TOPPING.
author: Elle D.

description:
I walked by Ramen Underground and seeing everyone bending over their bowls while slurping in ramen got me excited. The place was packed, but when I peeked inside I was lucky to find a seat at a table in the back. The food seemed to be served fast, a pretty simple menu... Perfect for a late night dinner. I checked in via my Yelp app and ouch... Consumer Alert: Poor food safety alert! Now what? I decided to man up and take this one for the Yelpers. 

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen (1pc BBQ Pork, 1pc Kakuni, Green Onion, Mushroom and Spinach) and added a boiled egg. It was good, nothing too special though. It definitely works if you crave ramen. I like to add some extra soy and now and then even some sesame oil to my ramen, but Ramen Underground only provided a bottle of spicy oil on each table.

So.. 3 stars. A-OK. (plus inserting an emoji that's shrugging its shoulders).
I have a pretty sensitive tummy and I didn't get or feel sick afterwards. This place works for a quick dinner with friends, co-workers, or just you by yourself.
author: Kirstin G.

description: They have really tasty bowls with californian twist. Dumplings are yummy too. Good value for money.
author: Fikret D.

description: How incredibly disappointing this place has become.  I'm not sure what happened but 4 years ago when I tried this place when I first moved to SF the toppings, soup, and pork belly were A LOT better.  Now, everything is almost a joke and to be fair I guess this place is ok if you are really craving ramen and there was NO OTHER option.   Very very mediocre food and I would almost rather go to Aijisen at westfield instead.
author: Vince L.

description:
Convenient location in Fidi. Came here after work with a friend and had to wait about 15 minutes before we got seated since it's a small shop. Since it has limited seating you find yourself quite close to others in the restaurant. 

Really wish this place was more memorable since i'm a big fan of ramen. I got the miso ramen and I liked how rich the broth was, but I felt that the noodles were too soft and not chewy. I tend to like my noodles on the harder side as well and the noodles were too soft for my liking.  Added corn and pork belly to my order as well and thought it paired well with the entire dish. 

All in all, it's a decent place if you're craving, but there are definitely other places you can try in the area that are more satisfying.
author: Keizzel C.

description: My girlfriend takes me here on her lunch break from time to time. This time we came in at a much later time (around 4pm) and we had the pleasure of dining in. The food is always delicious as expected! I love the spicy miso and spicy soy sauce ramen! It adds the perfect amount of heat to my liking.
author: Michael C.

description:
A meh dinner following a meh date.

I had just left a date at RickHouse (good drinks, cool place, meh date) and figured might as well grab dinner while I was in the area. A lot of places were already closed and when I walked past Ramen Underground it was packed. Coldish night, warm ramen, a crowd usually means yummy = I'm down.

Fortunately I didn't have to wait and got seated at the window counter. I made it right in time, as a minute later that whole counter was full. The staff was on point, and quickly ordered a Tonkotsu ramen because I love pork. While I quickly received my order, the window seat did allow me to see a crazy homeless person. I love living in the City.

It was bland. The noodles weren't that great either. Both types of pork were great, however, plus the fresh spinach was a nice touch. And in Ramen Underground's defense, their go to ramen might be soy or miso based. But I wasn't exactly impressed with the tonkotsu. 

I could see going again if I was in the area and it was cold, but there are better ramen shops in the city,
author: Michael C.

description:
San Franciscans like to think that they have good ramen. It's a hearty dish, best eaten piping hot, and has tons of umami and fat. Giving it the SF-style treatment by trimming down the calories often mutilates and transform this dish beyond recognition. It's not that people haven't succeeded, but just not here.

I got the salt (shio) ramen. It came with chicken, mushrooms and spinach, and I ordered extra corn. First rule of soup noodles: your broth better be piping hot so the fresh uncooked ingredients you throw in it will be softened up quickly and lose their grassy taste. This was not the case and my spinach and mushrooms remained somewhat raw. That is especially offensive with mushrooms because it is *never* ok to consume raw mushrooms with their growing conditions.

Other than the toppings, the broth was light but nearly tasteless. The noodles were unimpressionable. There amweren't a whole lot of seats but there was an unreasonably long line at lunch - seriously, people. There's no way I would wait for this again.
author: Alice C.

description:
Pit stop here to fix my ramen craving before heading to SFO. It was around 6pm on a Wednesday night so it wasn't super crowded as I came in to wait for my friend, but it got pretty crackin' shortly after we got our ramen. She ordered the tonkatsu and I got the habanero ramen. Our waitress was super friendly and happy to explain to me that the habanero was supposed to really spicy, even by "Asian" standards and that the miso was the more salty broth compared to the soy sauce based one.

Maybe my spice-receptors were off duty, but I didn't think it was terribly spicy. Definitely delicious though! Ramen noodles were acceptably chewy and the portion of shredded chicken was substantial. The dinner rush made my friend and I a bit guilty for chatting too long after we finished our meal, but at no point did the waiting staff make us feel rushed or unwelcome. Excellent service! =]
author: Yen D.

description:
Most delicious Ramen downtown for sure, don't expect great service or a small bill though. 
It's small inside, but fast as most ramen places are. 

This is my favorite place to go after I've stayed at bar a bit too long after work on a week night and I need something to soak up all that booze because I don't need good service to fill my boots with noodz, ya feel meh?

I get Tonkotsu Ramen with an egg and though it's a bit more expensive than most of my regular ramen places, it's worth it if you're in this part of town on a weeknight.

They accept cards so don't be deterred because of that.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Craving ramen in Fidi? This is your spot! Great place to catch up with friends over a warm bowl of the ramen we all know and love. Here are the steps to dining in.

1. Put your name and party size on the white board by the door outside. Wait for your name to be called and study the menu.

2. After about 5 minutes (11a on a friday for 2), we were seated with two sheets of paper and pens to mark our selections.

3. Choose your own ramen! Base model comes with a variety of soups and all contain chicken, spinach, mushroom, onion staying at $9.95. Add a dollar or two for add-ons like spicy, egg, pork belly, etc. I got miso broth with added pork belly (~$12) the pork comes in tender cubes. You can also top your bowl with their chili flakes and chili oil available on your table.

4. Pick up a spoon and chopsticks. Slurp away!

They offer takeout as well but can't speak too the quality as of yet.
author: Tammy T.

description: Pretty overrated ramen and not sure why there's such a long line. Sure, come here if you're craving noodles and in downtown, but if you're looking for more authentic ramen there's definitely better in town.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
A lot of the locals raved about this ramen spot, and I'm not sure if I'm just spoiled with great ramen in Hawaii but I thought that their ramen was just alright.

The flavors weren't amazing. I did, however, enjoy the vegetables that came with the dish. Also, portion sizes are big enough to fill you up. 

Overall, it wouldn't be my first choice for ramen but an okay choice if you're in the area.
author: Kristian G.

description:
The short: disappointed in the ramen and charging procedure

Coming for a late night dinner after a visit to the bar, we put our names down on the sheet outside. After a couple minutes, we were ushered inside. Thank goodness the wait wasn't that long!

I decided on the tonkatsu ramen, which was brought out relatively fast. I had just come back from Japan 2 weeks before, so I had a strong sense of what I really liked in ramen. Of course it's not the same as what it would be in Japan. However, Underground's soup base lacks flavor (my friends and I even added hot sauce for a kick) the meat was overcooked. The saving grace were the noodles which were somewhat chewy. The ramen lacks what other SF ramen places does better. I definitely would go to Mensho Tokyo over this place.

Then the awkward part. My friends paid in cash and I paid with card. Nobody was taking our payment, so I went up to the cashier and I said I would write in the tip. When I was about to sign, I realized the payment charged was off - it should have been the total minus the cash, the payment due was off. Then I realized that they already added the tip for me! Ugh. Not wanting to create a fuss, I left the tip at 0 and vowed not to return. Yeah, in retrospect, I should have brought the issue up or charged the bill to my card and kept my friends' cash.
author: Catherine W.

description:
I really thought I would dislike RU. Too much hype, too trendy looking and poor reviews usually bodes poorly for a restaurant. I was pleasantly surprised by my experience here.

Chicken gyoza - 2/5 - Average gyoza. Would probably pass on this in the future.
Spicy Miso Ramen - 4/5 - I would have liked to have ordered the habanero broth, but I feel obligated to try anything that makes the 7x7 list. The broth was rich and tasty and the noodles were decent enough. I'll say that this making the list is acceptable to me.

Options - 5/5 - I really liked the choices that were available to customize the ramen here. There was a good amount of broth choices, as well as the usual topping options. I went with added char siu, pork belly, chicken and egg. The chicken was surprisingly good and came in a very generous portion. The pork belly was delicious as well. My favorite part of the customizability was the option for extra broth, which came in a side bowl. Many places offer extra noodles, which I'm not interested in, but this is the first time I've seen extra broth as an option. I drained both bowls and loved the sheer amount of rich broth this meal provided.

Overall, I look forward to trying some of their other broths, and I will definitely be back. For ramen shops that offer added broth, this is the only option, and therefore is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Always a line here but never had the chance to try it until now. I waited about 30 mins for my table with 4 parties ahead of me. Not too bad during dinner service. 

I wish they had more appetizers. We got the cold tofu. Probably the most expensive few pieces of tofu I ever had. I assume they just cut the tofu from the cold pack and drizzle some ponzu sauce on it. ugh! The ramen was pretty good. Normally ramen would come with pork but their comes with chicken. Pork will be extra charge. I added egg, corn and pork belly to mine. I like the soup base but over all nothing special. 

If you get there slighly before 7, free parking in front =)
author: Sandy B.

description: This place used to be amazing. Now it's over priced and gives a smaller portion. Why is the veggie ramen more expensive then the chicken?? Makes no sense. The guy serving during lunch is always really on top of it though, which can make up for the price I guess..
author: David M.

description:
Just an average place for Ramen. 

Nothing like how they do it it JAPAN

Good
Cold beer

Ok ramen. 

Nothing to write home about at all.
author: Benji W.

description:
Pretty decent ramen. I had the tonkatsu miso which was delivered quickly. The broth was good, but a bit on the salty side and there was a good amount of meat in the bowl. Noodles were cooked well.

Service was a bit sullen, but I did enjoy sitting at the window and people watching.
author: Amy S.

description:
After dealing with a cold last week (the perils of Bay Area summers), I was in need of something hot and soothing to comfort the throat and tummy. Thankfully my work let us out early for the long Memorial Day weekend last Friday. I knew this would be the perfect opportunity to beat the dinner crowds by going in around 3:45PM. 

I walked through the door and my hunch was right! Only a few people in the restaurant and I was able to grab a roomy table for myself. The servers were quick to bring me a menu and glass of water.

I ordered the SPICY MISO RAMEN. It comes with complimentary mushrooms, green onions, spinach, corn, and a slice of BBQ pork. It's been a long work week and sometimes you just gotta #treatyoself -- I added a soft boiled egg ($1) and some pork belly ($2) to my dish. Five minutes later I was already slurping down on my bowl of piping hot soup (after the obligatory Yelp check-in and picture taking of course).

What do I LOVE? All the veggies are very fresh, especially the corn. I have a soft spot for soft boiled eggs, and this one was cooked perfectly! Soft and gooey on the inside. The miso soup was rich and spicy enough to soothe my throat and clear my sinuses (is this TMI?). The noodles are thin but still chewy (however I still prefer the thicker, dense noodles at Shalala -- review to be written soon!). Not sure if I'd splurge on the pork belly again, but the BBQ pork was very moist and fulfilled my carnivore cravings.

I'll make a note to visit again during weekday off-peak hours...maybe a late lunch or early dinner after work.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
After a night of drinking, noodle soup always sounds delicious!

I'd been to Ramen Underground when they were across the street. This location is larger, so the wait wasn't too bad. Probably about 15 mins on a Monday night.

I got the Tonkotsu ramen ($11.95). All bowls come with basic toppings: bbq pork (1 slice), green onion, mushroom and spinach. I typically need more in my ramen to feel full, so I added a Boiled egg (+$1), Spicy paste (+1), Corn (+$1) and Kakuni (+$2). I loved the soft boiled egg. Nice oozy yolk. The corn was good as it always is and the spicy paste gave it a subtle kick. I'd skip the pork belly next time as it was hard and chewy. Not the soft tender pork belly I was expecting.

We were a group of 4, so we also ordered:
*Tomato ramen ($11.95), add Boiled egg (+$1), Corn (+$1), Kimchi (+$1)
*Spicy soy sauce ramen ($10.95), add Kakuni (+$2)
*Spicy miso ramen ($10.95), add Boiled egg (+$1), Corn (+$1), Kakuni (+$2)
Everyone seemed to enjoy their bowl.

My first experience with Ramen Underground was kind of lackluster. I got the Habenero ramen and didn't think much of it. The Tonkotsu ramen was definitely better, but be careful with additional toppings. My bowl ended up being $17. Good, but a little pricey.
author: Elena N.

description: Their staff was great.. very helpful. I didn't know what to ordered they were very patient and helpful. Thank you Ramen Underground. Wonderful experience!!
author: Jose D.

description: I was surprised by the low Yelp ratings at first, since back when they were in the tiny original location, I thought the ramen was pretty good. But I tried them today and wow, the food has gone downhill. My broth was bland and not even hot, the corn and spinach practically raw, the egg was hard-boiled instead of soft-boiled, and the pork belly was dry and tough. Luckily there are plenty of better ramen options in the Bay Area.
author: Janny J.

description:
I would not call this place ramen at all. I was told that this place was amazing and was super excited to try it. But when we got their, it had apparently changed drastically.

I think the restaurant just tried to make the healthiest ramen possible. The broth is basically just chicken broth, or at least it just tastes like chicken broth. The meat is just really dry chicken with no real flavor. And they just throw in some spinach at the end.

The food didn't taste bad, but it was really bland and did not really taste like any ramen I've had.

I would not recommend this place if you are trying to find a new ramen place.
author: Adrian Y.

description: Oh man, SF does NOT have any good ramen places!!! This place was way overpriced. Almost $20 for a bowl of ramen?! Really?? And it wasn't even that good...hmm...I was craving a hot bowl of ramen on this cold day...it was okay.
author: Sachiko K.

description: My neighbors told me about this place, so I thought I'd give them try and order food for delivery for a small dinner party I was hosting. I made the mistake of assuming they have their own delivery service. When I called, I was left on hold for 15 minutes; when she finally picked up, I could hear the crazy crowd noise in the background and she said that they actually don't deliver. She suggested I use Caviar. Then, I went to Caviar and signed up, took a bit to fill in required info, to then discover that the Caviar menu is extremely limited (about 8 items). Ugh. Now my guests are about to arrive. Thankfully, my friends were good sports and waited while we simply walked down and got the food ourselves. It was great, but a hassle if you want to order from the entire menu and eat it at home.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Meh... For all the hoopla and long lines, I was expecting much more out of Ramen Underground.   I grabbed a Tonkotsu Ramen here on Tuesday because I was hungry and wanted an early lunch.   While I've always walked past seeing huge lines, there was only one other patron at that time, so I figured I'd give it a shot.

As I said, I got the Tonkotsu Ramen and asked for an egg addition.   They forgot the egg, and I of course only realized this when I was sitting back at my desk at work.   The pork belly was actually a little too chewy for my taste, and the broth wasn't all that delectable.   The Kimchi appetizer I got certainly didn't seem homemade and was most probably from Costco.

There really isn't anything wrong with Ramen Underground (other than the fact that they forgot my egg... not sure if they charged me for it) but I just don't think it's worth all the hype.
author: David O.

description:
There ain't much that's underground about Ramen Underground anymore now that they opened an izakaya in J-Town (review: http://bit.ly/1KgsWIh) and then moved this operation to bigger digs aright across the street from its original location. The irony is that a new ramen house opened in the old closet of a space, the eccentrically named Sushi Bay since they don't serve sushi (review: http://bit.ly/1EWrf1I). Ramen Underground took over the execrable Miyabi Sushi, which was a fast-food spot for Mickey D-style bi bim bop. It retained the harsh lighting and tired floor tiles but otherwise the owners made sure it still attracted their core customers, noodle-crazed hipsters, with its claustrophobic tables, chalkboard menus and servers with attitude.

Actually this last feature is new, and that's the one ding I'd give it now. Before, the Japanese sistuhs were racing around and very polite, but now they have young, glum-looking guys with attitude pretending to wait tables. They still did their jobs, but I felt like I was intruding on their space. Fortunately that really didn't prevent me from enjoying my ramen. It looks like they extended the menu judging from their laminated placards (photo: http://bit.ly/18DA7Pi). I suppose I could have tried the Habañero Ramen or maybe even a Tomato one, but I ran true to form. Excuse me, rather I waddled true to form and ordered the $11.95 Tonkotsu Ramen with the $2 premium for the Kakuni Braised Pork Belly (photo: http://bit.ly/1wNRsJD). Spoiler alert, I know.

And of course, this being the FiDi and all, there was an extra dollar for my beloved corn kernels and yet another dollar for the boiled egg. Care to ask me if I want it hard-boiled or soft, sonny? Eh, can't hear ya, boy. So the real price was $15.95 all told, but hey, it was good and the broth decadently creamy without really being creamy. That hasn't changed since the original location and neither has the melty-good pork. Probably in an attempt to frustrate the hipsters staring at me though the front window, I also ordered the $4.95 Seaweed Salad and ate it rather slowly (photo: http://bit.ly/1EwONNk). Not so much to savor as to have something to do to stare back at the hipsters. It tasted like something from the refrigerated section of Nijiya Market. Bring cash and be prepared to wait for slow near-geriatric eaters.

FOOD - 4 stars...the ramen still rocks even if the attitude doesn't
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...hipster haven maximus...my guess is that given their druthers, no one over 40 would be allowed in
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...unsmiling young bucks with 'tude...missin' the sistuhs
TOTAL - 4 stars...bigger digs and surly servers don't enhance the ramen though the creamy tonkotsu broth remains intact
author: Ed U.

description:
Meep. I literally do not understand why this place has a constant line for both lunch and dinner. I find this to be constantly mind blowing because I was so underwhelmed by my experience here. I made an effort to show up at 9pm on a week day night because I figured that would strategically place me at a time when I didn't have to wait in line. I definitely succeeded. You don't need to wait in line if you come in that late.

I got the shoyu ramen. The soup was okay--I do like that it's the organic chicken broth so it's not as fatty and oily/heavy as typical tonkotsu ramen. the broth feels much cleaner and healthier when you drink it. I guess okay this is basically like healthy ramen ... the noodles are meh. Mine were a little on the harder side so that was meh and the soup was underwhelming. Idk I mean from the standpoint of a bowl of ramen.. the soup and noodles were both underwhelming so there's really not much redeeming after that. They also give you the bare minimum with your bowl of ramen so I can see how people can easily stack up the prices with add-ons. They also serve spinach with their ramen which I think is really interesting but doesn't add much.

tldr; I seriously cannot comprehend why the lines here are so long. the ramen is just like... okay. typical noodle soup but not very flavorful and just meh. also cash only !!
author: Jasmine X.

description: Craving ramen on a typical foggy SF day, my friends and I decided to try this place out. The restaurant was pretty small with maybe 10 tables or so, but they managed to seat us pretty quickly. The menu consisted of mainly pork or chicken ramen. I went with the pork tonkatsu. The wait wasn't too long for the food thankfully, since we were starving. The pork in my tonkatsu was really tender, and I liked how they put spinach in the soup because it felt really fresh. However, the soup wasn't very flavorful. My friend ordered the spicy soy sauce ramen and the spice was more sweet and sour compared to the typical spicy ramen. The food was decent, but I don't think I'd try it again.
author: Lanna T.

description: Solid 3 stars. Nothing amazing or horrible. Eating veggie these days so had the miso veg ramen with added egg. Overall yummy. This place needs a deep clean though. Sat at counter and stared at sticky dust.
author: Angela F.

description:
Not that good. Overpriced. Shitty service. 

It was merely okay. Not sure why this place is rated highly. The service was pretty non-existent and the food was merely sort of okay.  

They also have a ridiculous minimum charge per person and charge extra to use a credit card.
author: Jason F.

description: Great hole in the wall-esque noodle shop.
author: Joseph S.

description: The ramen was very good! I got the spicy miso with chicken and it was not too spicy. I left full and satisfied.
author: Naya J.

description: I like the food.  I like noodles and have to say they have good ramens.  I work in the area and see the place gets really busy during lunch hours so always go late.  Not sure the reason, maybe they are changing shifts, the same waiter always rushes me into paying after I just start enjoying my food.  This gets really annoying after every visit.  I have an hour lunch break and would really like to enjoy my food and quiet time without being disturbed.  And they charge percentage for using credit card!  Places like coffee shops and food trucks take credit cards regardless the total amount spent, even just $4.  These two are the key factors of holding me back from going there again.  Otherwise, the food is good, served fast if you go outside lunch hours, and convenient, I could see myself going a lot more often.
author: Gretchen Y.

description:
Somehow ended up waiting 0 minutes for Ramen Underground, so now I'm a fan. I got the soy milk ramen, which was what I read on Yelp as a good dish! I'm glad I did, because it was the perfect combination of creamy and salty :)

I wouldn't try this place unless it's an off-night (Mondays, Tuesdays) because the wait is usually at least 20 minutes.
author: Kerry G.

description:
Monday lunch, line forms before noon but moves pretty quickly. It's a quick meal. Food comes out pretty quickly. You can check out the menu while waiting and decide what you want to order first to save time. You check boxes on a sheet indicating what you want. You can also get to go. 

I got the spicy miso broth. Standard ramen comes with spinach, mushrooms, and green onions. I added egg and corn for a dollar each. The spinach and mushrooms are thrown into the soup raw. I would have preferred them cooked, or at least the mushrooms cooked...

Wasn't amazing but nothing to complain about either! I liked the soup- it was a good amount of spicy. I wish they had bamboo offered under additional toppings though. Noodles are good. 

Oh yeah, and it's CASH ONLY.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I used to eat at Ramen Underground awhile ago when it first opened and was in the smaller space across the street.  Tonkotsu ramen wasn't a regular fixture on their menu, in fact it was quite rare with only a few bowls offered at random times.  And I remember it was just kinda ok.  Well, they must have spent a look of time working on it because a few years later and it is awesome!

Chicken Gyoza: Standard.  Good if you're in the mood for gyoza, but nothing that will rock your world.  The texture was right with a crispy bottom and soft top.

Tonkotsu Ramen: My benchmark tonkotsu ramen is Ippudo NY, since it's not really fair to compare against some amazing bowls I've had in Tokyo.  Even still, Ippudo NY is a very high bar that most San Francisco bowls fall short against.  The tonkotsu ramen here was probably the best broth I've had in San Francisco (...though not quite up to snuff against my NYC favorite).  It has that nice white cloudy look.  Each sip was full of fatty rich realness.  After you're finished, you feel a bit of cholesterol overload.  It's great!  The meat seemed to be pretty generous (for ramen) with two big pieces of pork belly and two pieces of roast pork.  The pork belly was tender with some melt-in-your-mouth fat layers.  The roast pork was a bit too firm for my liking.  Noodles were nice and chewy.  Can't really remember the veggies much, except that the raw spinach tasted much better when softened a bit in the broth.
author: Adam B.

description:
Craving ramen one night and this was the only place nearby and open.  We placed an order to go because we didn't want to wait- getting hangry!  It was ready very quickly.  I got the soy sauce ramen, which was very bland.  Disappointing cause I was starving!


CASH ONLY
author: Lyn C.

description: Ramen underground had the tastiest soy ramen I've had in a LONG time! All I can say is YUMMMM!!!
author: Nikki H.

description:
The ramen was surprisingly good! I ordered a tonkatsu ramen and at first when I got my bowl of ramen, I was skeptical of having mushroom and spinach in my ramen...but it was okay! I thought I would only get one piece of chasu pork but I had three big juicy piece with a big chuck of pork! I also ordered a boiled egg, I wish the yolk wasn't too cooked in mine.
Although the ramen was good, I don't think it was worth the price because it's pretty expensive for ramen in my opinion.
author: Grace Z.

description:
Cold weather + flu season = a good call for a big bowl of Ramen! 

Rumor has it that this place was pretty good and my friend and i's expectations were not set too high. We ordered 2 bowls of TONKATSU ramen, with an extra egg($1.00); his extra noodles and braised pork ($2.50), mine extra soup. Food came out in a fast and speedy manor. To our surprise, the broth was extremely flavorful and milky, the pork was tender (both the roasted and braised) and the accompaniments were perfect. Needed no additional condiments. 

Overall, service was pleasant, food was quick, and food was executed tremendously! I will definitely come back to get my ramen fix!
author: Brittany B.

description:
I love a bowl of hot and steamy tonkotsu and ramen underground can hit the spot on a cold work day but it is nothing to rave about.

Don't expect flavorful broth or excellent service.

Mediocre on food and service but you can be in and out in an hour during lunch.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Too many good restaurants with good service to have people closing the check out in the middle of the day and coming back to check twice in less than five minutes whether I had signed it.  Decent ramen, but not good enough to feel like they're doing customers a favor by serving them.
author: Christopher M.

description:
An ok place. Good to see ramen in the neighborhood tho.

Pork and soup were normal, gets the job done. Wouldnt wait in line for this place.
author: Philip L.

description:
I've been here a handful of times and it has been progressively worse. After tonight's meal, it's safe to say I wouldn't be returning again. Both my BF and my ramen tasted like it was stewed in salt. There's not really any other way to describe it, like drinking sea water broth and each bite of noodle was brined in salt. 

These are pretty strong statements coming from me since I'm usually pretty generous with adding salt to my meal, but I couldn't each finish my bowl of ramen. 

In addition to drinking sea water, other reasons I wouldn't come back:

-I ordered the spicy ramen. It was literally a sprinkle of pepper flakes, not a paste or anything.
-The vegetables were like haphardly thrown on- raw spinach and sliced mushroom. 
-It comes automatically with chicken and you could add pork slices. The chicken, no surprise, was also quite salty, while the pork was hard and cold even in a bowl of hot ramen.

Save your time and money, plenty of other options within a  block, from super duper to sushiritto.
author: Jessica T.

description: Good ramen place with professional staff. Had the tonkotsu and the broth was tasty. The pork kakuni also very delicious. Ordererd also the appetizer organic cold tofu. More of a small portion green leafy salad with limited slices of tofu. Nice casual yet hip ambience. Will come back for the chicken ramen.
author: Brown D.

description:
This is a cool, hip, gaijin Ramon shop. Crowded when all the surrounding restaurants are empty. The water is tap same as the beer. The chicken goyza is tasty. Can't tell it from pork. 
We ordered the shio miso ramen. Apart from the spinach topping. (Strange) it was YUM!.

Not a Japanese person working here. But I can tell they were trained by a Japanese chef. I feel like I'm in Tokyo except all Americans inside. 

Yum!!!
author: Tj F.

description: Honestly the best ramen noodle experience I have ever had. Me and my husband wanted to come eat here every single night during our stay in San Francisco. The line would always reach around the corner from the main entrance. The atmosphere is very nice and friendly. We stayed at the Park Central Hotel just a few minutes away from the restaurant it's about a $7 Lyft ride and about a 20 min walk. It's a small restaurant but they move quickly and get you in and out in no time.
author: Ty-Lin G.

description: First time to this place and i really love it. The space is a little small and during rush times I noticed its packed, but I came between rush times and got the spicy miso. Really flavorful and really good. Some of the best I've tried on San Francisco so far.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
This restaurant is small and cozy, and I thought was reasonably priced for a restaurant in the city. 

I ordered a spicy miso ramen and my boyfriend ordered tonkotsu ramen with spicy paste and corn. While I liked the broth, I wasn't really satisfied with the noodles. The toppings were a little lacking and their chicken was really dry.

My boyfriend liked his own broth more in comparison of the two.
author: Reika Y.

description:
I find the RU's "organic chicken, no MSG" broth to be really delicious. On my 2nd visit, I got Tonkotsu Ramen again but I asked them to make it spicy which was $1 extra & I also asked to not put spinach. The outcome was really great as they added a good amount of spicy sauce on top of the ramen & since I asked for no spinach, my portion looked much bigger with more noodles & soup. The ramen was spicy but it was even more delicious compared to the regular, not spicy one. This was very fulfilling for dinner on a cold night. However, a big disappointment for this place is their lack of better quality ingredients as their toppings. They only give plain mushrooms & spinach that are probably used to just take up space. 

The issue this place has is with customer service. They usually have only one worker who seats people, takes orders, serves food, & handles the checks. This becomes a big issue especially during peak hours as the tiny place fills up & has a wait in front. & customers must bring cash or they will be redirected to the nearest ATM.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Oh myyyyy goodness.. never again!!

- I ordered the spicy miso - it had a good kick and I loved all the green onions. 
- Pretty good service... we came in a group of 6 and had a pitcher of ice water. We were checked up on once, which is better than none of course.
- Annnnnnnnd that ends all the positive comments! All 6 of us left disappointed.
- Noodles look and feel like spaghetti noodles
- Default toppings are dried shredded chicken (apparently it use to be 1 slice of bbq pork as stated in the menu), mushrooms, and spinach. What... in the world...?!?? Is this suppose to be ramen!? LOL. Shredded chicken was so unappetizing, dry, chewy and bland. Mushroom and spinach are served like a garnish... raw (yes, mushrooms are raw too) and just chillin on the top. And yep, that's it. Not even half an egg or any other garnishes; not really any substance to the bowl except for a huge portion of al-dente spaghetti noodles. Grreaaat.....
- I ordered a boiled egg for +$1, and it wasn't even the "ramen egg" type of egg. A hanjuku ramen egg has its own characteristics... marinated, cooked perfectly, and has a distinct texture. The one I had was nothing near a hanjuku ramen egg. 

This place seems to always have a crowd during lunch hours... probably only because it's one of the few ramen places in the financial district/area. Don't be fooled!!
author: Kris C.

description: such a great hole in the wall... had the chicken miso ramen and chicken gyoza (aka potsticker) delicious is the understatement of the century. My friend and I were seated immediately, the water came out right away, and we didn't have to wait all day to place out orders. Appetizer came out relatively quick, followed by the ramen. Prices are fairly reasonable.. I believe the chicken miso ramen bowl was about $10. Can't wait to go back!
author: Mo S.

description: Quick friendly service fun atmosphere great food savory Ramen cold brew and fast service
author: Shane S.

description:
I got stomach poison twice at this place, very poor quality and safety.
Not recommended stay away!
author: Francesco G.

description:
In an effort to have me try San Francisco cuisine, a friend I hadn't seen in years who lived in the Bay Area, recommended we meet at Ramen Underground for dinner.

Sign of a good restaurant? All the tables are occupied and there are a dozen people waiting their turn outside the door. 

The wait wasn't bad at all. But then again, we had strategically chosen a weeknight. Our waitress was friendly and informative. When I told her I don't eat pork, bacon or ham, she was very helpful in recommending options.

You can't go wrong with any of the selections. For people with dietary restrictions, the Vegetarian Ramen is a good option because you can still add a ton of extras. And that's exactly what I did. The bowl was enormous, the broth hearty and the vegetables fresh and crisp.

It is a cash-only place and quite small. I recommend not carrying giant bags when you visit.
author: T.E. M.

description: I'd been meaning to try this place for years. Recently, I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen for takeout and realized at home that they'd given me the wrong soup base--chicken instead of the pork broth.  As someone who had previously worked in the food service industry for many years, I completely understand that mix-ups happen and would never (ever, ever) write a review for this reason alone. I found the chicken ramen broth to be very, very bland--but it might be good to order if you've got a stomach ache. The toppings for the Tonkotsu do not include boiled egg; you've got to order it separately (+1.50).
author: Michelle C.

description:
Ramen Underground is dope. Crowded and small? You bet. But absolutely worth the wait.

The Spicy Miso Ramen comes with shredded chicken, instead of the usual pork. Which is a awesome. Because pork is icky. It also comes with a little bit of spinach, so you can blast back into your office like a slug from a .45 rocking your tight new Popeye-esque brain muscles. And all for only $10.95.

Naturally the menu offers opportunities for customization through additional toppings. However, skipping the frills won't impact your experience in a negative way at all. The fundamentals here are well executed, with a rich tasty broth that feels lighter than other ramen places in the area, and noodles that are certainly a step or three above those same joints.

Ramen Underground is worth the dive, assuming you have the time. I've paid a lot more for ramen that was a lot less tasty than this. Gotta love that white meat!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Busy and a bit crowded place, definitely not great for huge crowds. Not complaining since it's in FiDi, so just eat and leave kinda joint. Service was ok, not overly friendly, but just there to take the order. Again, not complaining, since they are super busy.

I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen ($12). The ramen was the thin kind which I had before and didn't like it. This one had that chewy texture and al dente. Broth was good, rich, milky and yet not salty at all. However, the meat was a bit disappointing. It was dry, unflavored and nothing close to being tender as it should be. They were also a bit stingy on their toppings, almost at a bare minimum. Small portions in a big bowl makes it a bit deceiving.

I guess if you are craving for ramen and don't have high expectations, this would be a good place to stop by.
author: Em T.

description: Please don't come over lunch time. There is only one staff working at the restaurant and the waiting time is ridiculous.
author: Greggy H.

description:
The ramen here is edible, but I have definitely had way better ramen at about a dozen of other ramen restaurants in SF. The place is super crowded too during lunch hour and service is so-so. Seriously, if I ask if the egg is soft or hard boiled, and a server tells me it's soft-boiled, then I better get a soft-boiled egg in my ramen and NOT a hard-boiled egg! I paid extra for that egg too. :(

Do yourself a favor and upgrade yourself by walking an extra block or two to Slurp Ramen instead if Slurp is open. Ramen Underground just isn't worth the time or money.
author: J L.

description:
We had the spicy miso noodle and habanero miso noodle and both of them were great (hot and spicy). 
The only downside of this place is the long wait time and the cash policy. They do accept credit cards and charge 35c extra for that.
author: Prasanthi R.

description: My friends usually rave about this place... Now I can't understand why... The ramen was the same as any other ramen place. Nothing special. What I hated was the wasabi Tako... Is this wasabi Tako with greens or greens with a taste of Tako? Why so many leaves? The dish isn't a salad that I know of anywhere else in the city. It usually wasabi Tako with you know, Tako...
author: Nathan D.

description:
I found this place by searching for a ramen restaurant near my hotel. The reviews were so-so -- and for a good reason.

I ordered the tonkotsu -- always my choice. The broth was rather bland, but it improved dramatically with chili oil and shoyu. (A lot of both, actually.) I was a bit surprised that a ramen shop would serve shoyu in little packets, but at least they had some, right? I've never had mushrooms or spinach in ramen, but both were actually damn tasty. The biggest downfall was the pork. It comes with chasu (BBQ pork) that wasn't very good. I didn't know this when I ordered, so I added kakuni (braised pork belly). It was decent (certainly better than the chasu), but some of the less enjoyable I've ever had.

Overall, it was enjoyable enough, but -- if I were in the area again -- I wouldn't return.
author: Lillian D.

description:
I'm being generous with my two stars.

Let's start with the Chicken. Over cooked, dry and tasteless with a slightly funky scent. I was happy to see all the chicken but it was so dry I'd have to stop chewing halfway through just to take a sip of broth to help wash it down.

This brings us to the centerpiece of what Ramen is to me, the broth. Put simply I've had better from a can. Needless to say I didn't eat most of the broth. 

The noodles were ok. Nothing special but not bad.

All the veggies were good.

I'll never be back.

Oh, then there was the entire thing with the guy they made move three times.

The price at $16 was fair for the area.
author: Justin S.

description:
Ramen Underground was underwhelming.  My husband I had spent the morning traipsing around Golden Gate Park and were on our way to City Lights.  We parked in a nearby lot and decided to walk around and find somewhere to eat.  I didn't check Yelp before deciding, bad idea.  

We walked in to the restaurant and were seated immediately.  The staff was efficient and friendly.  Less than 10 minutes after ordering , our two bowls of soy sauce ramen were steaming in front of us.  

My first thought was that the broth was very salty and that was about it.  The ramen comes with chicken, raw mushrooms, raw spinach, green onions, and noodles.  The chicken piece was fatty,  but my husband ate both or our slices.  The soup really needed some spice, but the provided red pepper flakes did very little to add heat or flavor.  

I decided to see what fellow Yelpers thought and wasn't surprised to see a mediocre 3 star rating.  What did alarm me was the fact that many people mentioned that it was cash only.  Of course, I had none on me.  I was about to send my husband running to the nearest ATM, but he decided to ask the hostess since we didn't see any signs posted.  Fortunately for us, they do accept cards at a 35 cent charge.
author: Kim L.

description:
Summary:
A solid lunch spot that is worth waiting in line for.  Very fresh and tasty!  Reminds me of the ramen spots on St. Mark's Place.

The Food:
A hearty portion of soup and noodles with just the right amount of spice.  I got the spicy miso with green onion and the chicken dumpling.  Let me say, the noodles were very fresh and cooked just right, al dente.  I highly recommend the dumplings as they were not very fatty or filled with dark meat (looked like white meat).  Solid, solid ramen.  Well done.

The Service:
It is a bit of a wait but the host is very diligent and expedient.  We were in and out very quickly for lunch.  Well done.

Tips:
Bring cash, they don't do CC's.
author: Paul H.

description:
What the heck happened to this place? When it was located across the street at the original 355 Kearny Location, it was one of my all-time fav ramen joints that my BF introduced me to a few years ago. The pork was melt-in-your-mouth, the broth was frothy, and the noodles were chewy.

As of this summer, the new location at 356 Kearny changed their menu a bit. No more pork (although the menu still deceivingly said the normal order without extras comes with 1 piece of Pork) and totally replaced with crappy, shredded chicken. I was really disappointed! 

Even the Pork Belly extra (+$2) that my BF got was just mediocre. I'm genuinely disappointed Ramen Underground. I hope you'll go back to your original recipes of delicious-porky-goodness. 

Overall - just an okay ramen spot now  with more chairs/seating than before. Basic Ramens are $11-$12, Toppings are an additional $1-2 per topping. CASH ONLY!
author: Veronica S.

description:
Food: 1.5/5.0
Service: 3.0/5.0
Value: 2.5/5.0
Decor: 3.0/5.0
Overall: 1.5/5.0

The old Ramen Underground was a great cozy spot to warm up over a delicious bowl of warmth.  The new Ramen Underground instead is a larger format restaurant that serves up something that tastes like... well, let's just leave it at that.  The noodles were terrible as were the pork and the broth.  So what does that leave us with?  Not a whole lot.  Go somewhere far away from Kearny & Pine for your ramen.
author: Damian W.

description:
Visiting from slightly local Sac for the weekend of the Superbowl I was expecting a big crowd, but the place was relatively empty, and small. I read some decent reviews and the place was within a mile of my hotel so a friend and I trecked our way through the drunks and homeless for a big steamy bowl of ramen.

This was really a flavorful bowl of ramen. But I just don't think it was worth $17. Not even in San Francisco. It's just...the noodles were so weird. I really wasnt expecting a spaghetti noodle, which is what these essentially were. No wiggle, no chew, no classic ramen snap back. Maybe the noodle is a style that I have never heard of. I am not an expert, but I know what I like and dislike.

The tonkatsu miso broth was lovely. Its the most expensive broth on the menu. But it made up for the creepy noodles. I added dumplings and egg. The egg was lovely. The dumplings were not worth the extra $. The pork was tender, and the other toppings were average. 

There was some bland chili oil and soy as seasoning and that's it.  

After a beer and a bowl of ramen my bill was around $25. That's just too much. Thank you for the tasty broth, but that's not enough to bring me back.

Looking forward to trying other places when I'm back in town.
author: Katherine H.

description:
Has this place changed ownership? My recent experience was very different than my first, about a year ago, at their original location. I remember eating a hot bowl of ramen in a tiny place - hot, stuffy, scent of rich tonkotsu broth rushed through your nose every minute. Wasn't the best ramen but boy did that bring me back to Tokyo and its alleyway ramen shops fitting only a handful of people each. 

In their new space, Ramen Underground felt nothing like a legit ramen place. I ordered the spicy soy sauce ramen - soup had no depth, noodles were mediocre (thought I was eating al dente spaghetti at one point), chicken was dry. Noodles INSPIRED by Japanese ramen at best. Quick fix, fine. But I'd probably be disappointed next time I crave ramen and decide to visit this place. 

I ordered their chicken gyoza and unfortunately it wasn't impressive either. Wish I didn't get it. 

Service is great at this place but sadly its food has gone wayyy downhill. Probably a pass for those looking for a quick lunch in the financial district.
author: Jackie C.

description: The broth here is really lacking. They use chicken base for their soup, which is fine, however, there really isn't much flavor. It's like they give you the broth and a tiny bit of seasoning. While the ramen is decently priced, they don't give you an egg, and I mainly come here for the egg, and the noodles. Portion wise, I think the bowls are a bit small, I always order extra noodles here but it doesn't really seem enough. Mind you, I have a really big appetite so for those who don't eat that much you might be okay. The service here isn't great either, and they tell you to tip the servers on the menu. A little weird don't you think? The thing I do like about this place is the egg. It's perfectly seasoned and perfectly boiled with a sweet taste to it. I have yet to find a ramen shop in the bay area that has a better soft-boiled egg.
author: Cheryn L.

description: I loved that place than it was small and on another side of the street , they didn't take cards previously , so to go there I always was making sure to have some cash with me ( you know, little silly rituals)and ramen was truly great . Visited it couple days ago , first time since they moved and réalisé that everything what I liked about that place is ended . Plus they charge 35 cents for card payment ( but not telling you about it , yes, they have that note on their little clips for bills , but still - never hurts to tell your client little things like that ) little silly things , but I ended up paying for a bowl of ramen - $14 something + tips. I know it's SF , but at least they might do an effort on quality . Another thing , that I can't get now- the line to this place , like come on? How? 3 starts because of old memories and servers were nice )
author: Viktoriya Y.

description:
The chicken broth seems thicker than any ramen broth I've had. It doesn't taste good compared to a simple tonkatsu broth, either. Also, their noodles might as well be spaghetti.
Never returning.
author: Tylor L.

description:
The ramen here OK. Fast service. 

BUT their waitstaff need to learn a thing or two about etiquette. 

Firstly, five out of seven of our party was there and they acted like we were hurting their business since two people weren't physically there. I get it, but they were en route. 

Secondly, when the bill came, they crossed out the total in pen and highlighted the tip guidelines at the bottom. If there's a mandatory tip for parties of a certain size, be upfront! I don't mind paying it, but if you're going to be passive aggressive about it and scratch out the total, I'm never coming back. 

Wish I took a photo because it was extremely tacky and rude.
author: Jessica S.

description: Long waits during lunch time but well worth it if you have at least an hour to kill.  Got the miso tonkotsu ramen, broth was exceptionally thick, yet also deep and savory without being too salty or overpowering.  Lots of noodles and toppings, be ready for large portions.
author: Sarah N.

description:
Absolutely delicious! 

I ordered the soy sauce ramen, it's really good never ate a better ramen soup.

Service is great!

price is fair.

Very recomended
author: Ivria S.

description: One of the few places I know that serve ramen with vegetarian broth. Loved my ramen with spicy chili paste. I think 18$ for a bowl of ramen is probably a little pricey. Not to forget it's a cash only place. However, amazing food.
author: Reema B.

description:
Did I miss something here? 
TL|DR - over priced, flavorless noodle soup, with mediocre service. Don't bother.

My 2 friends and I were downtown last night doing some shopping, and we were ready to eat. As we are coming around closer to 9pm, we knew our options were waning, and given SF's rather bi-polar weather recently, one of my friends wanted soup. We talked about the merits of different kinds of soup, I suggested Ramen Underground with the warning that I thought the place was overrated, but it's always busy, so let's give it a try. We get seated quickly, and after being asked to shift over one seat, we place orders. My friend was surprised at the lack of toppings in the soups given the prices, and how $$ the add-ons were. 

I ordered the miso-tonkatsu ramen with an egg. I haven't had more tasteless broth in memory; there was neither the porky richness that one associates with even a decent tonkatsu broth, nor the savory-saltyness that comes with miso. Noodles were overcooked, and didn't have the appropriate chewiness. (If you want to REALLY nerd out on ramen, it's components and structure, read Oishinbo's manga on the topic. You'll learn quite a bit). Toppings are both ood (spinach) and run-of-the-mill. The only good thing (and merits one of the two stars) was the egg was cooked to perfection. 

Service is choppy - and they charge 35 cents to use a credit card (which, after doing a quick google search, is illegal in California). Definitely not worth another visit back unless they do some major turnaround in food quality & service.
author: Jessica S.

description:
It's okay . Got the spicy miso chicken ramen w/ spinach and a boiled egg. 
Would probably go back.
author: Stephen A.

description: Ramen Underground used to be small and cramped but I'm glad they've moved to a bigger location. I've had the spicy miso ramen and the spicy soy sauce ramen here, and while it's nothing phenomenal, it's flavorful/delicious enough for me to come back again and again. The ramen itself is pretty cheap (~$10) but once you start adding different toppings, you may find yourself paying for a $20 bowl of ramen. Remember to bring CASH (they don't accept credit cards)!
author: Helen P.

description:
This place is STILL DELICIOUS!! I live 6 minutes away and I'm here all the time. I've been to both establishments. The spicy miso ramen with added corn and tofu is CRACK to me!! Sooooo good. I'm seeing a lot of cry baby complaints .. They are in the 1% population. This place is crowded and making a killing $$$$. BECAUSE it's GOOD!! Why do you think they expanded?? Because it's good!
Congrats on all your locations !
Huge fan
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Usually super busy, but worth the wait. One of my favorite ramen spots in SF.

Have tried a number of things, and haven't gone wrong.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Food Poisoning!!!

I went to this place for lunch on Aug 15th, since then, I got very serious diarrhea in the afternoon, and at night I got fever. I think it's not only bad food, but food poisoning. Today is second day, fever is fine after medicine, but I still got serious diarrhea, I have to take two days off work. So regret to go to that place.
author: Zhaoyang D.

description: Was excited to try this place out. We got in quickly even though there were a couple people ahead of us. I ordered the spicy miso ramen, it wasn't super flavorful and I expected it to actually be spicy. They also charge you for an egg, any other ramen place I've been to usually includes an egg. Overall I did enjoy my meal.
author: Carly B.

description: Really good food! Simple and delicious, got the spicy miso ramen w added boiled egg. Broth had great flavor. Was really nice  to have a hot soup on a (surprisingly for me as a first time visitor to the area) chilly San Fran day. I was a little annoyed by how the servers offered no explanation of the menu (no clue what half the ingredients are and the menu is not easy to decipher) but *whatever* felt I couldn't go wrong w what I ordered. Price is slightly higher than what I expected from a hole in the wall type ambiance. My bowl of ramen cost me 16$ incl tax and tip. Extra Tips: bring cash, know how to eat w chop sticks, look up what the different broths are, come at an offbeat hour (post 230 pm) or expect to wait for lunch, don't expect a lot service wise.
author: Ann P.

description:
Ramen is never a bad idea in cold SF. 

- Cash only. 
- Always busy on working days. So get there early (by 11.50) and put your name in the list.
- Best for 2 people. Larger group == More wait time. 
- They have counter tables. So single people too can comfortably enjoy their food.
- Service is fast

FOOD:
- Best broth - tonkatsu broth or spicy miso. The both is flavorful and rich.
- Soup comes with mushrooms, green onions and spinach. 
- Must add extras - braised pork belly ($2) + soft boiled egg ($1)
- The regular ramen bowl comes with NO pork slices at all, just served with shredded boiled chicken. This is not what ramen is! A lot of customers are totally unhappy with this. Everything needs to be added as extra!
- Portions served is quite filling with a lot of noodles. Mostly have to get the leftover to-go.
- This place is expensive. Any regular ramens (no extras has only boiled shredded chicken) is $11.  Add any extra its approx $15.
author: Payal B.

description:
I work nearby and was hoping to have a solid Ramen option.  The pluses:  the broth, toppings and # of choices.  The minuses:  the noodles didn't have enough chew, the price ($16 w/ tip, otherwise $13 take away).  They offer a really good # of types of ramen, with differing broths (veg, chicken, pork) along with spicy, miso, soy, salt options to personalize your favorite ramen.  But it's extra if you want a soft boiled egg (really?).  The serving size was ample.  However, the noodle is pretty key...i felt the noodle didn't have enough chew and was on the skinny side for ramen.  That coupled with the high price only allows for 3 stars.

If I'm going to spend $13-$16 for ramen, I like the Ramen Bar better.
author: Jen F.

description:
I was psyched when I heard that their store got expanded, but meh.. Could just be me, but I honestly liked it a lot better when they were still in their small little shop.

Their miso and spicy miso broth is good but tasted a little different than before. I wonder if the owner changed after they moved location. 

But I mean, yes their ramen sufficed SF Financial District people. Good broth and average price $10-$12. Toppings were $0.50 extra.

Great service! When I went, it wasnt lunch hour rush, so no wait and quick service.

If you really crave ramen bad and this is the only place to go, then yes it's pretty good! Otherwise its just okay. 

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
My roommate absolutely loves this place so I come here pretty often with her. I think it's great as well but I might be biased because I stick to their spicy  miso ramen. (Add an egg and some corn.) 
It's a quick and cozy home in the wall for sure but can get amazingly busy so service is alright. Servers are quick but courteous.
author: Samantha S.

description:
I've been here a few times for late lunch, which is the best time to go if you want to avoid a line. I've opted for the tonkotsu each time, and the broth is rich, porky, and unctuous. I took leftovers home one time, and it cooled into a gelatinous block--a sign of great broth!

The noodles are fine, nothing too stellar about them. I do wish the pork toppings were better. Both the kakuni and chashu were dry and hard to chew, which is disappointing given that everything else is so good.
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
Bring a friend!

My first encounter with Ramen Underground at their old location came about due to a recommendation by a very hip friend. With its walls painted black and specials written in white chalk, it felt grungy and peculiar. When I dropped in to grab a quick bite, I fell in love with their kakuni (layered fatty pork)--it tasted just like how grandma used to make it, broiled for long hours, tender and delicious.

At their new larger location across the street, a similar setting is preserved, with more seating space. I recently went there with a good friend, and my favorite classic kakuni with tonkatsu ramen yielded two pieces of kakuni and two pieces of chasu. The soft boiled egg was also on point. We left very satisfied. ^_^
author: Vicky J.

description:
CASH ONLY.  

This is a chicken broth ramen shop. And I made the mistake of ordering the tonkotsu. The tonkotsu was ok, but the broth was too greasy for me. IN addition , I asked for the pork belly as well.  So I was overloaded with porky goodness. 

Everything is pricy in SFO. This place is no exception. 3 guys - $85.
author: Luke T.

description: Fast, friendly service, and best of all yummy ramen. I've been here a few times now and it always hits the spot. I order the vegetarian miso ramen with kimchi. Can't complain!
author: Alanna L.

description: Based on service, this place would get no stars but the 2 stars reflect their ramen.  Good flavor and well marinated meat.
author: Michelle H.
