description: Unfortunately changed their awesome pork ramen to bad chiken ramen: WHY?!? so now you get dry chiken which doesn't really taste like much and not really traditional Japanese just to save 2$ on production cost? This place can do better than that specially since they used to have such a great reputation! Suddenly they maybe don't care about reputation but I think you should all know that!
author: Irina P.

description:
Ramen Underground is one of the best things San Francisco has to offer. It is the best example of old San Francisco pre-tech boom- it's great, it's simple without being basic, + it's cheap. It's a hole in the wall, no reservations, wait in line like everyone else restaurant that will keep you wanting more. A perfect spot for a cold night in the city. Don't recommend going on a rare hot as hell day; no AC. 

The food was awesome! Had potstickers with a spicy soy sauce for an appetizer + paired it with a pint of Sapporo. The spicy veggie Ramen was very delicious, also tried the spicy miso Ramen with BBQ pork which was just as tasty. Great spot for a date night, not a first date though- it tends to get loud even though it's small. Decorations and ambiance match the restaurant's underground taste! Doesn't look like much from the exterior but totally worth the wait!
author: Isabel F.

description:
Worst ramen I ever tried!  Please don't bother paying $13 bucks for salty organic chicken ramen and dried hard chucky  pork cube and slice.  I was so happy to see big chuck of meat that seemed worth the money I paid for, but it was painful to chew it all down.  You got to pay $1.5 for 1 boiled egg.  Noodles seemed dried from instant noodle bags.

No, definitely not coming back.  Should have tried Ramen Bay a few doors down.
If you don't see Asians eating in there, then not real ramen.
author: Bay Area S.

description:
This used to be one of my go to places for some ramen. Especially in the downtown sf area. Before the service was great but today for some reason it made me change my mind about going there. 
  First she told us we will be seated in 10 min and while we waited she seated other people and we were a group of three. Literally, a customer came up and asked her if his group can be seated and she seated them automatically.
     Second, we were not asked how we were, and not given refills on our waters. 
  Lastly when leaving we decided to not giver her a big tip since we had bad service she came out chasing us demanding we give her a $6 tip. 
Horrible experience and will not being going back there any more.
author: Moises G.

description:
DON'T GO HERE! 

I originally tried their location in Japantown and was disappointed but thought I'd try their main store on Kearny since it's a block from my office.

OMG so bad. It's so overpriced for what you get - For $9.95 you get one piece of pork, mushrooms and SPINACH - not seaweed....

I ordered the miso ramen, and added pork belly and corn. Upon receiving my food, I was like "why does it look like chicken in here?" It's because that one piece of pork you originally get is now swapped for chicken. The pork belly was literally just a huge hunk of fat- I mean, pork belly has a lot of fat to it, but it was not edible at all. The broth didn't have a lot of flavor either. 

Do not go here when Katana-Ya is a few blocks away. Save your money!
author: Mandi W.

description: Lucky to catch this place at 7PM and it wasn't too busy .. found by chance and pleased with tonkotsu ramen and can now go home happy
author: Whirrrp L.

description:
I am a ramen lover and I crave ramen almost everyday! This place is delish and definitely up to my standards! I absolutely love their broth variety here! My favorite is the habanero tonkatsu! 

The service here is pretty good for being super busy during lunch. They get real busy here during lunch time since its in the FiDi. If you're coming here for lunch on a weekday, you definitely need to come early to beat the rush otherwise you will be waiting for quite a bit. Besides the rush, This place is pretty pricey for ramen, but it's expected since its around the FiDi area. 


Tip: Parking here is non existent, so be prepared if you are driving to eat here.
author: Grace T.

description:
This place used to be pretty good but I'm not what sure happened.

Ramen had spinach and mushrooms, I'm no expert but I don't think that's what normally comes with a bowl.  Broth was mediocre, nothing special at all.  I have never had ramen this bad. It's sad, a couple of years ago the ramen was really good.

Seats in this new location are uncomfortable, staff isn't exactly friendly.

Not sure why anyone would come here really.
author: Leslie L.

description:
I got the soy milk broth, which isn't as weird as it sounds. It's a light version of a chicken-cream broth, which I enjoyed. Other than that, the ramen was middling. The noodles are thin like spaghetti and the chicken was sparse and dry. The pork belly was tougher than I was expecting. The mushrooms and spinach tasted fine, but they don't hold up their texture well in a bowl of soup. This is why menma and even kale are better options for ramen.

The location is excellent and we were in and out quickly at 5PM. But, there are better ramen shops in the city at the same price point.
author: Andrew G.

description:
Awful. 

Came here due to the fact that I wanted some ramen. I've heard that their food isn't the best to begin with but the idea of warm soup with noodles just sounded divine. It was moderately packed, I've seen lines out the door before. When I walked up to the register the woman at the front out her hand out and said "we're too busy for to go order".....what?!

How would that take any longer than a regular order? All you're doing is throwing broth and noodles into a plastic container. So I suppose in addition to shitty food you can also potentially expect shitty service as well. 

Guess they ultimately did me a favor their health score is low, low, low.
author: Janine J.

description: My wife and I really loved both vegetarian ramens that they serve here. Both the soy and miso bases vegetarian ramens were super tasty. Added corn, spicy sauce, egg and extra noodles to mine. Fantastic.
author: Jonathan N.

description:
First of all, I think the staff had tried their best to serve every customers. Very little service but it's ok at least one of the waiters had smile on his face. 

Change of ownership or chef? This place was used to be my must-go whenever I crave for ramen. The soup was rich and cha Shu was tender. Yesterday I brought my friend over,  who was visiting the city for good food, and we were totally disappointed with the quality! Shredded chicken??? No...they were just too dry...eggs were overcooked... corn was tasteless... Sorry to be mean but this was one of the worst ramen I've ever had.
author: Alice Y.

description:
This is one of the best ramen places I found in Bay Area. I had Spicy Miso ramen with chicken and its awesome. 

Until 3 months ago they accept cash only, now they accept all credit cards, sweet!

Recently seen a notice that this place got a poor food safety rating for SF city, not sure how hygienic food is, but I still see loads of people in line for hours on a weekday.
author: Nani N.

description:
Perception-wise, not really connecting SF with good ramen.  And especially with the great ramen we can find in Hawaii, I wasn't expecting much either, but Ramen Underground delivers!

BROTH - RU prides itself on no MSG--hard to find ramen spots that don't use MSG!  6 weeks removed from my visit, I don't remember the details, but I do remember loving their broth!  Not much fat or oil floating which is a big plus!

NOODLES - Again, 6 weeks later, can't recall my impressions of the noodles, but I didn't have any complaints!

CHASU and KAKUNI - More lean than fatty...  Tender with good flavor!

PORTION - WoW!  Bowl was huge!  At least compared to Hawaii standards!  Immense!

SERVICE - Delightful young lad helped us throughout our meal.  Free refills on our beer?!  Ahhh!  Found the easy way to get on my good side--with free beer!  What?!?  A second refill offered?!

You won't be disappointed if you come here!
author: Mark H.

description: Very good ramen. Both the soup and noodles are really good. It's a very small place and very crowded during lunch. Lots of add-ons choices but cost extra
author: Umer M.

description:
There is often a huge crowd outside of Ramen Underground, especially for lunch. I went on a random weeknight and waited 15-20 minutes for a table which seemed like too long for the quality. 

You can walk away spending a lot of money at Ramen Underground because a base bowl of ramen costs ~$10 and then each item costs extra, a few dollars for meat, a couple dollars for that. Most other places "package up" their ramen offerings and they are more reasonably priced. The base ramen comes with one wafer-thin piece of pork. 

The soup was nothing to write home about but the noodles were good and chewy. 

Cash only.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Not my favorite ramen place.
Tried both the soy milk ramen and a bit of my friends tonkatsu ramen.

The tonkatsu lacked the flavor and creaminess of other places. The soy milk ramen really just fell flat... it tasted a lot like soy milk, but lacked the umami I typically find in a bowl of ramen.

Also... what kind of ramen place doesn't include a soft boiled egg in the ramen? It's a $1 extra.

Waited 20 minutes on a Saturday... came out disappointed.
author: Michelle L.

description: Not terrible but not great. I had the tonkatsu ramen and added corn ($1 extra). The broth had some flavor, but it didn't come close to other tonkatsu broths I've tried at other places. Noodles didn't seem to be made in house-- I'd be very surprised if they were. Overall, kind of pricey for just an okay meal. I'd come back if I had to, but I'd try to convince myself to have a burger at super duper next door first.
author: Ruth R.

description: I had the Tonkatsu ramen and was completely underwhelmed. The broth was bland, the noodles were ok, the egg was overcooked. There are definitely better ramen joints in the city so, if you can avoid it here, I suggest you do so.
author: Selena L.

description:
Stopped by staff on the way out the door to be informed that I did not tip their minimum suggested gratuity. Really? You want an 18% tip for a 2 person party that ordered two items? You're lucky you got a tip at all with the 0 service provided beyond seating us and taking our order.

Never again.
author: Casey D.

description:
This place has really good ramen...the broth is super flavorful and the miso is super rich. I got the habanero miso which if you like spicy will satisfy a spicy palette. I added kimchi which added some good flavor as well.

The place is small and there is limited seating so sometimes you have to wait a while for a table. The place also gets HOT. We went at night (granted it was a warm night) and the restaurant was warm even by the window.

It's also a rather pricey bowl of ramen once you add all of the toppings you want. Still, good sized soup that will fill you up. 

If you are really hungry, just add extra noodles for $2 extra. I also heard adding the herb butter is really good but I didn't actually try it myself. 

Overall, GREAT spot for a big bowl of ramen but be ok with waiting in line and sitting in a warm, small restaurant.
author: Loryn F.

description:
Not friendly at all. Don't even refill our water or bother to ask if everything is okay with our meal. It's a tiny restaurant with three wait staffs working at the hall. Its the location that brings people in since this is the only Japanese ramen place near by and it's fast. Food wise really I would say their broth is just okay. It's very basic and tiny amount. Over priced for really what it is. Also, They charge you for extra everything. 
I ordered spicy(it's a extra charge) And what they did was just add few drops of chili oil.. So..you can just order plain flavor and just add chili oil that's on the table for no charge lol 
Note:There's Minimum charge for kids & minimum cc bill(which I understand) but there's additional35 cents fee for if you making purchase with your credit card. 
Just done with this place.
author: Stella K.

description: I do like this place. The ramen and broth were really flavorful, but all in all, not too memorable. I'd come back if I was in the area and did not feel like looking around for other food spots, but I think this would not be my go-to spot.
author: Sarah L.

description:
In the last 10 times I've been here for take away, they've:
- Lost my order twice.
- Gotten my order wrong thrice.

That's 50% of the time.

It's my favorite ramen downtown, but I don't know that I can keep coming here if they can't keep track of orders, or they can't get orders right (but charge for ingredients they forgot to include).
author: Matthew G.

description:
Cold, badly reheated chicken on a thick, unidimensional chicken stock--with extremely low grade chicken and cheap miso, way too much salt and added lard.  Noodles were limp, but properly heated.  Toppings were sparse.  Expensive.  Overpriced.

This barely qualifies as ramen.

Feels like getting hit in the face with a mallet of fluorescent orange grease.
author: Matt L.

description:
I come to San Fran every month for work and I don't go more than 2 trips without coming here to enjoy some fantastic ramen. 

The habanero miso ramen has a lot of spice but equally as good flavor with all the ingredients they pack into each bowl of ramen. 

The small room packed full of people gobbling up their ramen adds to the unique, no frills experience. Just great ramen!
author: Mike W.

description:
Recently moved across the street to a bigger place with more seating, Ramen Underground is one of my favorite places to eat for lunch. Very casual, has quite a few choices for the broth (I always get miso or spicy miso), and some (although limited) choices for toppings.

(+) FOOD: Big hefty portions, I always get miso or spicy miso with chashu (bbq pork) and boiled egg. The broth is absolutely delicious, perfect balance of spiciness (if you spicy miso) and taste. Chashu is well cooked, not too fatty, very flavorful and mouse-watering.
(+) PRICE: I think the price is pretty reasonable for the taste. Spicy miso is $10.95 (miso is $9.95). Premium toppings (like chashu bbq pork, pork belly, etc etc) is $2.00 each, whereas the other toppings (boiled egg, corn, mushroom, green onion, etc) is $1.00 each.
(-) SERVICE: Very long wait. Don't come with big groups, or you'll be waiting forever. You can also call in and order for pickup/to-go if you don't want to wait too long. Average wait time is around ~15-20 mins for a group of 2. This place is CASH ONLY, so bring cash!
author: Xin W.

description:
Based on reviews I expected to be disappointed, but I wasn't. Ramen was a solid 3.5 stars and service rounds it up to a 4.

I got the tonkotsu and it was pretty good once I added the spicy paste for a little more flavor. Loved the spinach and mushrooms. It was also big enough for two meals. 

I would go back again if it wasn't crowded and I was craving some quick ramen.
author: Sara M.

description:
Very pleasantly surprised by this ramen joint.
This gem in the heart of the FiDi will provide a killer bowl of noodles for less than the Hipster-demanded $15!
Go, enjoy, repeat.
author: Wendell A.

description:
Like most people, we came to Ramen Underground because the nearby restaurants had long lines and we just wanted a quick bite. First of all, the ramen is not bad but definitely not worth the price. 
Ramen Underground's specialty is that it uses chicken broth. Traditional ramen places uses pork broth, where it's oily and mouth watering delicious. But chicken broth is a clearer style of broth. Regardless, it does not make up for how average the ramen here is. I got the miso and they sprinkled spinach and mushroom. Those two toppings did not go well at all with the broth or the noodles at all. I added the corn for a $1 extra. The broth was thin and salty. Nothing went especially well with each other. Yes, the noodles were chewy but that was about it. I still can't believe I paid a little over $13 for this average bowl of ramen. Extremely overpriced is my main reason for this rating. It'll probably be better to wait that extra half an hour for better tasting and better priced food from the other restaurants.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I got the Tonkatsu Miso Ramen for $13

What I tasted & saw was angel hair noodles, pre-cut mushrooms that come in a bag from a grocery store, canned corn put into a not as tasteful broth with meats of different flavor.

But I was hella hungry today so it was just a fill-me-up... Did not enjoy nor think it's worth the price. I could have probably made something better at home from scratch.

Sorry dudes, need to step up your ramen game.
author: Abigail V.

description: Back to four stars. Still would prefer pork, but at least the chicken isn't stringy anymore. Liked Ramen Bay better, but with that gone, I'm back to waiting in your line, RU!
author: Erica W.

description:
For my first review, well, update, of the new year, I gotta throw it back to Ramen Underground. I went in for lunch today with Jeremy P and his two coworkers. He has been feeling ill and suggested pho from Pho Express, which you know ya girl Crys is literally always down for, but he begged and pleaded so we went to RU. 

I'm all for authentic food and mom 'n pop shops, but $14 + $2 tip for a bowl of ramen is just unreasonable. IT'S SOUP. It's flavored water with noodles and maybe some protein. I mean, it was good, don't get me wrong, I love me some pork belly, some soft boiled egg, and a topping of spinach and mushrooms, but the price is always a deterrent for me and my measly sheckles. 

Anyway, that's that, and I will now be packing my lunch for the next two weeks. The end, and  Happy New Year.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I'm no expert on ramen, but I've had my share of delicious (and not so delicious) broths over the year to know what I like and what I didn't like about the ramen here. I will be honest and say that I've never made my own ramen from scratch nor my own tonkatsu broth, so I can only make comments on other aspects of execution. Came here for lunch while visiting the bay area. It was busy, but that is no excuse for some of the problems in basic execution that I noticed. We ordered the tsukemen and gyoza.

I'll start with the gyoza. The flavor was to be honest meh and the gyoza were lukewarm and dripping with oil. Maybe too much oil was used, I don't know, but let the gyoza drain before putting them onto a plate or the oil will reduce the dumplings in a soggy, oily mess. One could tell that the gyoza were served after sitting out too long after being pan-fried.

Onto the tsukemen. My disclaimer is that the first and only tsukemen I had was at Tsujita and this is what I'm comparing Ramen Underground to. The broth was a touch too soupy for my taste when I imagine a tsukemen. I would prefer the broth to be reduced further to concentrate the flavors and to nearly be considered a sauce. The broth served by Ramen Underground was thin enough that the noodles would not pick up enough of the flavor and not reduced enough that I was able to drink the broth by itself, grimacing only barely at how salty it was. The broth was served lukewarm and the noodles slightly below room temperature. Serve them both hot, especially the noodles. Dipping cold noodles into hot (not to mention lukewarm) broth will only cause the dish to taste and feel like leftovers. Flavor-wise, I enjoyed the broth, though I think it would be better as a soup ramen than a tsukemen.
author: Joe L.

description:
One of my favorite Ramen joints. 

Not a fan of the Chicken ramen bowls, but the Tonkatsu one was delicious. Great toppings to add, including silky tofu, one of my favorites that not all Ramen places offer. 

When in the FiDi, this is my go-to place.
author: Crystal A.

description: From a loyal customer to never again.  This place use to be awesome and I would come here VERY frequently.   However, in the last year or so they totally fell off and fell off hard.   I gave them more than enough tries thinking everyone has a bad day  but sadly have been disappointed each time I go.    Noodles are good,  that's about it.  They def water down the broth as it's not even close to as flavorful as it use to be and you have to pay xtra for stuff you would typically expect in ramen soup  especially the egg!! Which for the most part is either over cooked or super cold in the middle.  I feel this place has totally lost the passion to make good food and now is just another money grab type of restaurant.  You will get more satisfaction eating the $.25 ramen packs you can get at the super market!  There are so many other places that are worth the price and the wait.   I would not recommend this place to anyone!  Sad cause You had a good thing and ruined it.  You lost a very loyal customer as I will no longer waste my time or money on this 1/2 fast ramen spot.   step it up guys,  put some love back in your cooking.
author: Vito L.

description:
Passed by many times and saw lines.  Today, my coworkers and I finally decided to have lunch here.   We ordered three pork tonkotsu ramen.  One order had corn and the other order has a spicy paste.  My order was regular which came with the fatty melt in your mouth pork belly, one slice of pork, spinach ,  mushrooms, onions, and noodles.  Broth was tasty. 

$12.95 tonkotsu ramen 

$13.95  tonkotsu ramen with corn 

$13.95  tonkotsu ramen with spicy paste
author: E. C.

description: I am by no means a legitimate ramen connoisseur, having been raised on the artificial, preserved, "microwave" version of the food. This was my first real ramen experience. Super popular, and my friend and I had to wait about 40 minutes for our dinner. The wait was worth it, ramen was pretty excellent in my book. Broth was a bit salty. The meat included in the soup was delicious - tender and flavored to perfection. Service was a bit lagging; the place was small and my friend and I were seated in a relatively hidden corner where the waiters couldn't see us amid the throngs of other people.
author: Katherine Z.

description: I ordered tonkostu ramen; the broth was quite salty and the chasu was very dry. I was there myself for my lunch. I understand that lunch time is pretty busy, but getting the bill right after a bite of food and demanding moving seat from server in the middle of meal wasn't really good experience.
author: Jeanne O.

description:
Still good! Glad they moved to a bigger place. Well, it's still not big enough, but better than where they were before.

This is my favorite ramen place in SF. I recommend it to all my friends and they all love it. 

I recommend ordering the soy milk ramen. The broth is so rich and creamy. My mouth is getting watery as I type this.
author: Hina W.

description:
I heard of this place for a long time. But didn't have a chance to give try. And finally I decide to give this place a try after work. This place is a very typical ramen place, small, crowd but quick to be seat. With only around 10 tables and bar, I was seat at the bar after 5 min of waiting. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen with extra egg. After about 15 min I got the ramen. The soups tastes fresh. Most toppings are expected, the only one different is the mushrooms. They add some mushroom slice in the soup. I guess that's why the soup tastes pretty nice. 

This place is probably the best place around financial district. Deserve a try if you work or live around.
author: Wei X.

description:
I hear about this place non-stop. Finally gave this place a try during a weekday and I thought to myself, I'm going to have some really great ramen here. The interior is pretty nice and inviting. The customer service is better than most that is for sure, smiles everywhere. I think I came in on a bad day or I just put them under high standards, but Ramen Underground did not make a good impression on me. I thought the soup could be more flavorful and maybe having those white mushrooms wouldn't be my first choice for ramen. The broth is the main thing that sets different ramen places apart. I wasn't really feeling the broth sadly. I also didn't fancy the spinach in the ramen. I'm usually not that picky with ramen, but this place was didn't really make me want to come back. I'd go back if I'm in the area and if I want ramen. 

A Plus for having a variety of ramen and a variety of toppings though :D
author: Cynthia D.

description: Got the Tankatsu Miso Ramen, add Habanero and corn.  Thought it was absolutely amazing, some of the best ramen ive had.  Noodles were fresh, and the pork belly had great meat.  I dont understand all these people complaining. Yes it was $20 but it was also 1. Amazing, 2. HUUUGGEE, 3. Amazing.
author: John L.

description: Meh. Noodles are pasty and don't have that bouncy feel to them. Broth is subpar. Prices range from $10-$12 for the basic noodles, broth, and flavorings, but if you want any extras like onions, corn, tofu, or kimchi, expect to add on $1 each. Want any shavings of meat on top? $2 each. Wildly overrated and there are so many other competing places at better price points with more flavorful authenticity. Don't waste your money or time waiting in line.
author: Alison A.

description:
I really like this place, but it's not over-the-top good. building your own ramen is nice, but the extras really add up. it's not as long a wait since they've moved to the location across the street, which has a few more tables.

service is okay, but seems like it should be a little quicker for a lunch spot in FiDi. I will keep coming back, but just once in a while.
author: Bob U.

description: Pretty dang solid tonkatsu ramen and Sapporo on draft. Definitely hit the spot on a cold, rainy day.
author: Chris H.

description: Not sure why folks are so critical. Their signature chicken broth was very hearty and the ingredients were very healthy. Egg noodles were done just right.  Good for a quick lunch.
author: Eric C.

description: It's tiny and always has a wait/line.  Walk up and write your name on the board.  The line goes pretty fast though!   It's also Cash Only.  Add the egg and the Pork Belly to your Spicy Ramen bowl...Trust me! .   My spicy broth was pretty tasty but I wish I would have tried to much raved about soy broth.   Only a four stars  cause I don't believe a true ramen bowl has any  spinach in it.  It seemed a more "Americanized" version of my usual faved Ramen Noodle places.
author: Claudia V.

description:
I thought it was really tasty and really solid.

Did spicy miso + kimchi (YES!) + chashu (pork was tasty and perfectly salted, but texture was too tough/dry) + spinach (generous)!

Wait wasn't too bad.

Overall: a win!
author: Andrew K.

description: Good ramen!!! I came here for a mid-workday lunch, ordered the miso chicken ramen, and was not disappointed. Then again, disappointing ramen is basically a crime because you have to mess up noodles and meat, which is almost always a delicious combination. It does get crowded past 11:30 or so and it says CASH ONLY in giant letters on the wall, though the menu says you can use a debit card if you meet the minimum ($12, I think). It's a lot of food and salty, so kinda heavy. One of my coworkers said it best, Ramen Underground is the type of place you go to for lunch once a month.
author: Connie Q.

description: You went from awesome, to A-OK, to meh. Your pork belly sucks now. It's overly priced, overly chewy, and under seasoned/marinated. With so many other options in the area, I can't think of a reason why I would ever come back here again. You guys need to figure out what you used to do before moving into the location you are in now. Ever since you moved, you increased your prices and decreased your quality. It's really a shame. I really miss your pork belly the way it used to be.
author: Noneya B.

description:
I am a straightforward ramen eater. Let's not get too crazy. Not too fancy.

I am going to enjoy my ramen preferably tonkontsu style. I would like an egg. The ramen here is good but sometimes is a bit salty. I like to lie to myself too and put in vegetables (they add spinach to the broth) and tell myself that I'm eating vegetables, but that's really just a lie so that I can justify shoving delicious ramen in my face.

Whatever. No regrets. I still like my spot in Japan town better (Waraku) but this place is good for a late night, on the way home fix.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
I used to make a similar tasting dish in my college dorm. It included one package of instant ramen, spinach, and a bland broth. 

To be honest, this place is just doesn't taste good, the ingredients are sub-par and it's fairly expensive for what it's worth. I would definitely go somewhere else if you're looking for good ramen.
author: Lauren L.

description: Pretty good for what it is. I got a shoyu ramen with char siu, dumplings and an egg. The broth is nice and rich a little salty but I guess that's to be expected with a soy base. Noodles stayed al dente thought my meal which is great because no one really like soggy ramen noodles, the pork added a nice taste to everything and was a nice texture compliment to the noodles. The dumplings seem like an after thought to be honest as they don't really add a whole bunch to the dish but I couldn't pass up a dumpling! All in all a really good meal and nice, although cramped, atmosphere. I will probably go back if I'm ever in the area but be aware that additional items such as the egg and dumplings cost extra and are in different price tiers.
author: Jonathan V.

description:
With a huge line every day, I decided to check this place out. I ordered the Tonkatsu Miso Ramen, which is kind of my litmus test for ramen joints. The food was okay. Noodles had spring to it, and the broth had flavor (though it was way too salty). Toppings were sparse, and the meat was a little dry.

So while the food was okay, the prices were a bit high. $15 for ramen is considered highway robbery from my Asian mom. In fact, if I told her how much I spent, I suspect she'd spend $15 to make enough ramen to feed a family of 10.
author: Alexis N.

description:
I was craving ramen today but was too lazy to get dressed up to go out and eat some. Thank goodness for all those food delivery apps. And in this case, Caviar.

I decided to try Ramen Underground bc I've heard about it before (albeit not bad or good things but just that I recognized the name). I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with an egg and a side of potstickers (2 pieces). 

The ramen was just meh. The broth did not taste like tonkotsu at all - and tasted extremely salty. The chasu was just a thin and small piece. And there was nothing too special about the ramen noodles. I expected a bit more for this $15 bowl of soup.

With that said, this will probably be the last time I will order from Ramen Underground.
author: Lisa Marie R.

description: WTF? Since when was this "Salt Underground" and not "Ramen Underground" - salt galore to the point of overkill. Completely overpriced, good not great flavor, living off of past hype. Pass.
author: Sai S.

description: 20+ min wait to be seated, 30+ min to be served, $1.50 extra for an egg (which was cold), a fee to use a credit card, and $15 for a bowl of ramen. You can do much better elsewhere.
author: Jon A.

description:
I'm writing this review because if I can help them to improve their service. Due to the bad service and bad experience, I won't go back there even though they make a good ramen. 

This was my experience this evening. Finally we sat at the table, the server start taking order who sat way later than us. We were very patient for our order.

Ordered two glass of beer and food. The server completely forgot our beer. I asked the server nicely to not forget our beer.

Finally beer and ramen came and enjoyed dinner. Waited the server's attention to pay the bill, but took too long so we just went to pay at the register. The other lady was at the resister all time while we were there so we thought we can pay with her. The server came told us to sit. We sat other 5min and paid with cash. She said "tip isn't included" to give us back the change and waited us to give her tip. We always give 20% tip even we get a bad service, but I wanted say she wouldn't deserve any tip with anybody. 

Restaurant wasn't busy when we got there. This place is very small restaurant so two servers can handle the tables very easily. Good server deserve a good tips and restaurant make a good sales. Hopefully they will survive in competition world.
author: neko c.

description:
Their tonkotsu ramen was good, but not great. Their rice ball was also only average. 10 years ago I would probably give them a 4 star, maybe even 5 star if I was super hungry. But the bar for ramen is much higher these days in the Bay Area, so they are just a 3 star now. 

One thing that really annoyed me. I sat by the bar near the door, and the hostess refuse to close the door. It is freezing winter, flu season and I was very cold. She simply refuses to close the door because she want to quickly call names of people on the wait list.   This was very inconsiderate
author: Beer W.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better." is a pretty good summary of how I felt about this place.

Service was fine, a little slow with the check at the end but pretty okay for other things.

Overall, the broth wasn't too flavorful and the noodles were decent. It was, however, pretty salty. I will admit I just came back from a stint in Korea where foods, in general, are less salty than they are in the States but...

Honestly, it was fine/meh. Not worth the money, in my opinion. I'm sure there must be better places in the city and I'll be on the look out.
author: Michelle K.

description: Ramen here comes as a defult with chicken, mushrooms (regular champignons, nothing inspiring Japanese) and fresh Spinach. It's tasty but not a typical ("real") nor excellent bowl of Ramen, and my table was a bit dirty, therefore only 3 stars. Service was prompt, and I was seated immediately even during lunch hour. All in all, I had a quick tasty lunch.
author: Hanna M.

description:
Dear Ramen Underground,

You have some really good flavor going on here, I come back frequently because the taste is good, but you have a really glaring flaw that NEEDS to be addressed.

You HAVE to stop screwing up orders. This is the second time I've ordered extras and didn't get them AND had items I asked not to be put in inside the soup. So you charged me $4 for these addons, but I don't get them. This happens too much and is making me consider going to places with less quality ingredients because they can actually LISTEN to the order.

Additionally, when someone requests something not to be in the ramen, say people who are allergic to mushrooms, you really should make sure these things are not placed inside the food. For some people, you have made the food inedible as they could be killed by eating it. People with milder reactions will have to choose to suffer if they want to eat here.

Pay closer attention, it doesn't matter if you are tired or busy. You should not harm people because of your negligence.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
So we'd seen the endless queues time & time again & wanted to try it. Today we did & were we impressed! Ordered easily over the phone & it was ready in 5 mins. The flavor far surpassed the pictures on yelp. The depth of flavor was evident & it was the perfect amt of spice! Absolutely loved it & would add boiled egg & pork belly next time as one slice of pork just didn't cut it...but it was the most delicious pork ever! Much better than katana-ya...

Cash only though :(
author: Nicole E.

description:
I actually came here to go to a ramen place across the street, but I saw it is cash only. I decided to try ramen underground for vegetarian ramen (egg added) and oh my god it was amazing broth. The noodles were nice and chewy and thick, perfect. I ate the whole bowl and felt great afterward, not junky or oily like some places.

The only thing is they should be seriously ashamed at the toppings it comes with-a bunch of raw spinach and some raw cut up brown cap mushrooms. The least they could do is use some nice mushrooms, would make a huge difference. You can pay $$ to have other toppings added. It quickly adds up though. For that I take off a star.
author: A S.

description:
Lesson: NEVER come here during peak lunch hours. Otherwise, you'll be competing with 20+ parties on any given day. 

Organic lovers: this place is for you! 

Decent noodles and broth! Especially the broth on the soy sauce ramen I ordered, which was very hearty, sufficiently oily and piping hot. It went well with the kimchi and spinach also. Although you do have to pay extra for the lean chashu pork, egg, and other items, the portions are quite generous. That being said, I think this place will do for a good, piping hot bowl of ramen on a cold SF day (which there has not been a lot of recently). 

However, DO NOT try the green tea cake. It was very dry, tasted almost stale, which they attempt to cover up with whipped cream.
author: Viet N.

description: Love the ramen here. Great quality and friendly service. If you're into ramen and in the area, I'd definitely recommend stopping by. Especially during a rainy day :)
author: Mali E.

description:
Tsukemen is not a true tsukemen. It's literally a bowl of their tonkotsu broth, and a bowl of noodles with the toppings. 

Tsukemen SHOULD be a bowl of noodles with a smaller bowl of salty, thicker, flavorful broth. What I got was their standard tonkotsu, which to be honest is a bit bland. 

Overall pretty disappointing.
author: Phil L.

description: Yuck! I saw the waitress pour the remainder of customer water back into the pitcher. Then use the pitcher to pour water for someone else. WTF! I know we are short on water but that's just nasty.
author: Micah B.

description: Rude staff. Dirty place. Avoid at all costs. There are so many better places to eat around here and where the people treat you graciousness and respect and plus know how to clean the kitchen.
author: John T.

description: Best Ramen I've ever had in the city! I got the spicy miso vegetarian soup. The wait was a bit long but well worth it.
author: Karine P.

description:
We were looking for something quick and good and stumbled to this place. It seemed busy so we decided to give a shot. If you are looking for quick decent ramen- this is pretty good place. Definitely not a date place... there were too many little "rules" that threw me off. 
We got tonkotsu ramen and asked to make it spicy- server said "of course we can!" So I was excited for spicy customization... except that they charge you $1 extra and it was not spicy enough! I had to order extra spicy paste (so another dollar was added). They didn't let me know this until I saw the bill. Also additional .70 (.35 each) was added for using card. 
Note you can't split if your order is not over $12. And two cards maximum splitting for party.
We had two ramens and it costed $36 (with tips..) 
Too much rules for mediocre taste ramen but if you are tourists or have no time- this place wouldn't be that bad, it will do the job.
author: Eunsoo J.

description: Cheapskates! 35 cent charge for credit card use. Ramen a la carte. Charge xtra for each ingredients. Worst part was that it was quite average Ramen. Not cheap either. Avoid.
author: Alfred S.

description:
Super long wait, especially at lunch time. Accepts cash only. 

Broth was okay, not super wow. Noodles were the thin type (I prefer the thicker type). I had the spicy miso with egg. I really like that the egg had a runny yolk like traditional ramen egg instead of a hardboiled egg. Also, I found it weird to have spinach in my ramen. Erm?? 

Service was decent, though slow. The moved across the street from their previous outlet. The new place is only slightly larger but still cramped.
author: Christina N.

description:
I went there few days ago. Tonkotsu ramen was super duper! I tried three ramen place but didn't like them at all because of salty broth. But this place had just right taste broth and so much meat inside! The noodle was also so fresh and tasty ! My husband is such picky person but he said all food that we ordered was good. 

So sick of American salty food but this place gave me a break from saltyness.
author: Jiyoung L.

description:
I've tried to eat at Ramen Underground twice in the past month and I've ended up leaving both times, once after being seated. 

The top reason that I left is the terrible, rude service that I've received upon arrival. I despise being told that I have to put my name on a list when there are no other people on the list and there are more than 6 open seats in the small restaurant. (I've been going at around 5 pm or 6 pm immediately after work - I know this kind of availability doesn't exist around lunch).

When I asked why I should put my name on the list, I was told to "just give me a minute, okay?" NOT THREE SECONDS after putting my name on the list, the waitress wipes my name off and seats me. She watched me write my name down to immediately wipe it off.  

The second reason that I've left is that the base meat is now chicken. Sorry, Ramen is NOT chicken noodle soup with spinach and mushrooms. 

I wouldn't go back to Ramen Underground, not even for free.
author: Christine Y.

description: Mm if you are looking for something to warm up your tummy, you've come to the right place! But make sure you have cash b/c this is a cash only restaurant. This place is one of the few ramen restaurants that actually tastes somewhat healthy. Bonus points! And I loved how they have a cubby for your purse if you sit at the bar. The only thing I didn't like about the bar was that it is so high up, making it difficult to eat your ramen! But other than that, everything was great.
author: Michelle G.

description:
It's busy, it's lunch hour, it's a weekday.  I'm hungry and I don't have much time before I have to head back to work.  It's now been 35 minutes and I am hangry.  The entire time that I've been waiting outside watching, the host put many smaller parties ahead of us. We have a party of 5 and you want to seat as many people as possible.  I get it.  But what I don't get is when you have a party of 4 that's in front of us on the wait listing list, that's been waiting for the last 35 minutes just like us and not seat them immediately when there are 4 seats open at the bar.  Instead, what you end up doing is place this 1 girl in the middle of the 4 seats, only to realize later on, oh shoot.  There's actually an open space for that 1 girl elsewhere and could've sat your party of 4 sooner.  The whole thing ended up with an additional 10 minute wait, which could've been avoided had the waiter done a better job managing his tables.  It's a lot of time when you're on a tight schedule for lunch.

Anyways, enough about the waiting.  The ramen and broth is okay (I had the spicy tonkatsu with extra pork and egg).  Pork is semi-over cooked and very dry even after it's been sitting in my tonkatsu broth.  :c  The noodles aren't thick and are more angel hair-like (but asian version, haha)  It's a quick fix for lunch if you're craving for ramen.  It's close by and it does the job.  I wouldn't go out of my way for it though.  Meh, it's whatevs, nothing to be psyched about.
author: Carena N.

description: tried the salt ramen. wasnt bad, but wasnt great either. the soup (im guessing) stock is heavily based on vegetables. almost tasted like regular chicken noodle soup. taste is very westernized
author: Kazuma T.

description:
No friendly vibes from the staff, Came in on a sunny Saturday morning in the City.
Rather expensive average 12 per order, Ramen in Costa Mesa is an average of 8.  if you want egg you have to pay extra
The soup broth is a ok. Noodles al dente. The meat is tasty. 
Will I come back? Maybe.
author: Carolina H.

description: 3 stars for the mediocre Ramen. Minus 2 stars for the poor service and rude staff. Don't come here expecting the best experience and Ramen you can find in SF. There are much better places for both. I was caught off guard by the rating before coming here because I have heard great things. Now I understand why. What happened to the amazing Ramen that used to be known as Ramen Underground?  Orenchi Beyond is way better and worth actually waiting for. My recommendation: spend your money and time elsewhere.
author: Justin P.

description:
I wouldn't wait in line for this place, but they have solid ramen and it's easy to get in if you come on the weekend. 

I got the tonkatsu ramen which is my fave (I heart ramen). Annoying that it cost $11 and you have to pay $1 extra for each additional item (egg, corn, spicy green onion) and it adds up quite quickly. Nonetheless, it hit the spot and I'd happily go back.
author: Aggie N.

description: Though the original location across the street was a tad cuter than the current one, we absolutely adore Ramen Underground.Their ramen is right on the mark in taste, has good optional spice additions, and perfect noodles. We had the vegetarian miso which is the best vegetarian ramen we've had to date. Though the restaurant can get a bit crowded, you usually don't have to wait too long due to the nature of fast ramen. So though you might be squished, you'll be sure to warm up during winter here, inside and out, ready to enjoy the night. It's a great place to take friends!
author: Thom And Vicky H.

description:
Not sure if I'm just really picky when it comes to ramen, but this place didn't blow me away or anything like that. I've heard a lot of things about this place, mostly mixed reviews too. So one cold sf night, I decided to finally give it a try. 

We went in around 5:30ish and there was only one other party in front of us. Our party of 3 didn't wait very long to get seated(~15mins), which was nice considering we were freezing and getting hangry. Service was pretty prompt, they took our order right when we were ready. 

As for the menu, the broth you pick comes with the basic toppings of chicken, spinach, mushrooms, and green onions for a base price of around $10 depending on what flavor you pick. Before this I actually have never had just plain chicken in my ramen before. It wasn't bad, it just seemed...unconventional? So did the spinach. Everything else is an additional add on with fee, and I don't know about everyone else but I get overwhelmed when I'm given too many options so as amazing as customization is, it was a little overwhelming.   

As for my order, I got the spicy miso and added chicken dumplings and a boiled egg. The broth was delicious enough to warm me up from the cold. The ramen noodles were thin and nothing special. The chicken dumplings were an interesting add, the flavors were subtle but nothing amazing. The boiled egg was soft boiled and just salty enough. 

Overall, this wasn't the best ramen ever. It was kind of unconventional/americanized if anything. I'm glad I got to try it at least.  PS, cash only and also a very small seating area which explains why there's always a wait.
author: Erika M.

description: Legit my favorite ramen place in SF. I don't know what their secret is but they have some magical ramen noodles because I have not tasted better ramen in my life! I usually like to pick up because the space is small and is always really crowded, so if you can deal with that then eating there is fine. Staff is nice, but usually swamped with customers. Every time I do a walk in pick up though I literally wait 5 minutes and then I have my food. That's great. It's not cheap, only thing that's kinda not great but quality is so on point. I will gladly pay $15 for my sensational spicy miso ramen.
author: Jessica Lilly R.

description:
Spicy miso - all ramen comes with mushroom, spinach, 1-2 pork slices. Try putting all of it in your mouth at once - amazing. Great for a cold day but doesn't seem to be anything too extraordinary.

Extras were quite pricey which made me sad, I love corn and pork belly and it was a good couple bucks extra. Place is cash only.
author: Elissa L.

description:
Not legit Japanese ramen,
I don't understand why there's always a long line outside. I was so disappointed, they failed on two most important criteria: soup base and noodles!! The chicken broth tasted weird, the ramen itself wasn't good. I admit its hard to find good ramen place in the bayarea.
author: Natasha L.

description:
Delicious. We both had the spicy miso ramen with egg and 1/2 extra noodles, the chicken gyoza, and edamame. Such good ramen. Was happy that it was chicken base because I avoid pork in my diet. Unusual but delicious find :)

Friendly, attentive service!
author: Nikki O.

description:
This is my first review for this place but previously had this as a 3-4 star place in my mind. Not amazing, but the most tasty solid Ramen I can find in fi-di.

This week I tried them at their new location across the road from where they use to be. As others mention there is a bit more raw mushroom and spinach filler. My noodles were also kind of clumped together. 

The biggest problem, and the deal-breaker change is they

CHANGED FROM JAPANESE PORK TO DRY STRINGY CHICKEN as standard meat. It's awful and reeks of cost cutting and time saving even thought prices are up.

I'm not a traditionalist either; the chicken is just so wrong in terms of both flavor and texture. Would probably adjust my review to 3 stars if they go back to the pork. 4 stars if they improved the noodle/broth quality back to what it was when they first opened.
author: David P.

description:
Sad, terrible excuse for ramen. Don't go here! 

This place used to be legit, before they moved across the street. New owners perhaps? Because now the ramen comes with stringy chicken and chicken bones instead of pork, the broth isn't flavorful, and the noodles have been downgraded to spaghetti. Actually, everything has been downgraded.

What's happening here is that the owners are looking to maximize profits by offering cheaper ingredients and capitalizing on their long-term positive reputation to keep customer turnover high. Older customers are coming to Yelp and giving poor reviews since June 2015, and RU is hoping new customers don't notice or care enough to know they're getting sub-par fare. 

You've been warned.
author: Viviane V.

description: First time was pretty good, I got tomato ramen which turned out actually pretty good. Second time was meh, the broth was too salty (same for the whole group), I wish they could just add some more hot water to the broth. The basic ramen had spinach, mushroom and one slice of pork, which was less than what I usually get for ramen. Waited for about 15 mins both times during dinner hours, weekday and weekend. If not being in the area, I probably wouldn't come back again just for the ramen.
author: Jaclyn C.

description: Great place for Ramen when you're just looking for a quick and cheap bite, just beware of the long lines during the evening!
author: Ken H.

description:
Strange Ramen.

Broth was tasty.  Noodles had a decent bite.  Chicken based soup stock and chicken meat as the default protein is quite a bit non-traditional.  The meat was seasoned ok, not too salty.

They load up with some green leaf vegetable (Not sure if it was raw spinach or something else).

Non traditional, hipster Ramen to be sure.

I enjoyed it, but overall, Ramen Underground won't be able to crack my top 10 ramen list.
author: I K.

description:
Pretty mediocre ramen made with poor ingredients. They use raw white button mushrooms and spinach as filler to compensate for flavorless broth quality and improperly cooked chasu (traditionally slow-cooked slices of pork that top your standard Japanese ramen). At an additional $2.00 a pop, the chasu was disappointingly dry, tough, and not slow-cooked in anyway shape or form to properly render the fat leaving you with a hard block of translucent, gelatinous mess that will get stuck in your teeth. And as of the beginning of June 2015 they have replaced pork with shredded chicken. I didn't notice this until I started digging through my bowl and saw bit and pieces of mystery meat floating about making me wonder if I should redefine my tonkatsu as a bastardized pho ga. 

The bathroom situation wasn't any better. When I opened the door, they were stashing their black garbage, blue recycling, and green composting bins (full size) in the same space where employees are supposed to be washing their hands and returning to handle food. When I sat down on the toilet, my face was literally 5 inches away from rotting trash. I damn near puked.

2 stars for effort. 0 for everything else.
author: Linda T.

description: Finally try this ramen place today.  The tonkatsu ramen is about 3 stars at max.  The soup is really oily, doesn't feel quality.  There is no egg (the semi cooked egg).  Service is ok, but it is cramped.  Price/reward ratio is lower than average.  Not recommended.
author: Stanley H.

description:
Came here after hearing people rave about how great this place is, and that it's the best ramen they ever had. I was waiting for my car to be fixed in Chinatown, so I headed over here. I was surprised to see that this was such a small, cramped restaurant. 

Its not your ordinary set menu, rather, you build your own bowl of ramen. Therefore, they charged for all the individual toppings/add on. Ramen underground also only accepts cash, so that was a bit inconvenient. Their service here isn't even great, we had to keep calling the waitress to get our order, to get drinks etc etc. Terrible service, and she wasn't even busy.. she was just standing in the front cash register. 

I had to use their restroom, so I walked through their kitchen to get to the tiny cramped bathroom, and boy was the kitchen dirty. That made me feel very unappetizing to the food that was going to come out. I wonder what their rating is for cleanliness. 

Overall, the ramen broth here isn't very heavy, as you usually see from cooking pork bones for 20+ hours. Everything else in the bowl was just ordinary.... especially for the final price we had to pay. I don't think this place is worth it.
author: Cindy D.

description:
We were in the mood for Japanese food that day so we headed to this tiny place close to Chinatown. 

The restaurant was quite tiny but the flavor was huge! Service was a bit slow that day but it was worth it. 

We had spicy Ramen and all was well in the world. It's basically a huge soup with noodles. You can add a number of items to create a personalized Ramen. 

I think next time I'll buy it to go...
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Visited this spot while in SF for Salesforce Dreamforce. Came here by fluke with my coworker. We had intended on going to another spot but learned they were closed. After walking around we found this spot.

The food was nothing to die for but it wasn't as bad as I'm seeing some other reviews are stating. It was busy enough that we had to wait and ended up getting seats at the bar. 

My coworker had never had ramen before so for her, it was amazing. For me, it was good. I don't see how you can mess up ramen and they did a good job. 

The wait staff was very friendly and quite accommodating to our requests. Maybe we were just happy to sit down after a long day or maybe we were just overly hungry, but I'd recommend this spot to anyone. It was good.

Fair warning though, they don't take AMEX, so I couldn't use my corporate card here.
author: Sathya B.

description:
Cons: the ramen doesn't include egg, there was barely any meat (pork in my case), servers weren't very friendly. 

Pros: it's ramen. 

The ramen here isn't traditional (doesn't include egg, sea weed), which I wouldn't mind if the ramen was better. Instead, slurp had substituted mushrooms and spinach which I didn't care for. The broth is only average as are the noodles. 

I wouldn't come here again considering there are better ramen places near by.
author: Bodie A.

description: I have been here 2 times and tried their Miso Chicken Ramen. The second time I ordered the Spicy version and found it much more tasty! The place is small and you will have a wait during peak lunch times.
author: Kapil K.

description:
Definitely not the same in their new space.  The ramen is pretty similar, but the service has definitely gone down.  The new space is definitely bigger, but it has totally lost it's charm and it's cool/funky decor.

Hopefully things will improve as they settle in, but I'm not holding my breath.
author: Yan L.

description: Only in SF can you find a organic Japanese ramen shop. To be honest I don't even know what that means. Maybe the MSG they use is derived from the essentials of pesticide-free mushrooms grown in the norwegian forests. Or maybe the chefs are tie-dye shirt making tree huggers who want live the "pure" life but cannot live without ramen and thus created this place. Who knows. The ramen is good. Pork Belly is also good. Price is ok. Cash only. Hard to get a table.
author: Anni D.

description:
What happened to this place?
It used to be my favorite SF ramen spot, at least in the FiDi area. Now I won't be coming back.

Came on a Saturday for lunch, it wasn't terribly packed as they just opened at noon. First Ramen no longer includes chashu (sliced pork) by default, it's now "organic chicken". Okay that's just odd, but fine.  I ordered my usual Habanero miso ramen, my bf got the tonkatsu ramen with extra chashu since he's not fan of chicken in the ramen soup.

Well order came - first I got entirely the wrong bowl, instead of Habanero, it was spicy Miso, wtf? The chicken that came in the broth had bones/cartilage in them, maybe okay in a rice dish, but not in a bowl of ramen, absolutely sloppy. Then my bf's ramen had extra kakuni, not chashu, and the kakuni was basically cold, like not heated through enough.  2 wrong orders.  They also only brought one of us a water glass even though there's a pitcher on the table. When asked about the wrong order, the waitress looked at me and said "oh." and then just moved on.  Really????

End up just paying the check and left no tip, but won't be coming back. Total disregard for its customers, and the quality has been going straight down hill. I miss the time when even though the line was long, the food was good and service half decent. Yikes.
author: Wei Z.

description: The best ramen I have EVER had in my life. Incredibly tasty, lots of meat, service is super friendly, even the beer was good!!
author: Borja N.

description:
My favorite ramen place and probably the only place in SF I have visited over 3 times. I did visit the place during lunch time, over a weekday, so this place was busy. Found myself seated in 15-20 min which is expected while dining in FiDi.
I like to stick with the basics when it comes to ramen. Me and my friend opted for miso base and veggies (mushroom, green onions). I have eaten the seaweed salad here before which I adore, but i skipped it this time as I wasn't too hungry. 
Quick service. Great ramen. Win for me!
author: Shruti D.

description:
Went here for lunch because my girlfriend works nearby and loves it. Yet, she normally gets it to go. That might be where the issues we came across happened.

First the chicken. Not only was it cold before being added to the hot broth, but it was boiled. Absolutely zero flavor in the chicken itself. To say I was disappointed is an understatement.

Second the egg. We both added a boiled egg. Both the yolks were not cooked, which we both absolutely hate. It does say only "boiled egg" on their menu. This is why I think her getting it to go is better for the egg cooks longer in transit so she gets a hard boiled egg. Either way disgusting.

Third the veggies. While great quality and taste, they were cold before being added to the broth. Nothing like eating a hot bowl of ramen only to get a cold crunch of mushrooms and green onion. 

Fourth the ramen itself. It was still crunchy when I took my first few bites. 

This ramen is nothing special. While the service was friendly, and since we got there around 11am there was no line, the food itself is absolutely terrible. I do not think either of us will be returning after this experience.
author: Harrison J.

description:
I usually don't post any review but my lunch experience made me want to vent out my frustration. I guess there's always a first time :)

My coworker and I decided to have lunch at this place.

I was curious about their Habanero Soy Sauce ramen and asked the server (sorry - I didn't get her name but she was a short Asian woman) how spicy it was. She said it was really spicy but she recommended that I just order the Spicy Salt ramen and said that she considers it just medium to mild spicy. I trusted her recommendation and ordered the Spicy Salt Ramen with boiled egg additional.

I can handle hot and spicy food but when our orders came, I found out that my broth was too spicy for my liking. I asked if I can have additional broth just to dilute the spiciness. The server said that the additional broth would cost me an additional $2.

Personally, I thought the additional broth was too expensive for $2 so I asked if I can just have some hot water instead. The server said that they do not have hot water but they only have tap water. I asked if I can have hot water from the faucet (tap) and she said that they do not have hot water, only cold water.

I was perplexed with her responses. A restaurant that doesn't have hot water?!?! Not even from the faucet?!?! 

Anyway - I asked if I can speak with the manager. She then told me that she would just give me a $2 discount for my order to cover for the spicy paste they used.

At this point, my coworker and I were looking at each other and asking - why wouldn't you give me a $2 broth so I can eat my too-spicy ramen but you would rather give me a $2 discount on my order?

............. SERIOUSLY?!?!?!


No tip for you and I will NEVER go back to this place for their lousy and unreasonable customer service... EVER!
author: Darwin T.

description:
I've never been more pleased with a bowl of ramen than I have at Ramen Underground. The spicy soy and chicken broth with shredded organic chicken and mushrooms had an intense amount of flavor. Even the noodles had a distinct savory taste. The chicken was tender and white, and for lack of a better example - none of the meat seemed like "filler" meat (if you know what I mean).

If you stop by and there's a line, it's worth waiting for a table. Treat yo' self!

*CASH ONLY*
author: Jay C.

description:
I finally made it here after months of working down the street! This place is the bomb diggity! I had spicy miso which comes with chicken, spinach, and mushrooms then I added kimchi and chicken dumplings. YUM!! This definitely satisfied my ramen craving. I came during lunchtime so it was incredibly busy but the service was still spot on. 

Pro tip: take an early lunch to beat the line!
author: Teresa C.

description: I typically go to this restaurant for lunch during work, their service is fast during the lunch rush but I recommend calling in before going. The ramen both was too salty and viscous however their noodle egg quality is amazing. This is a go to place for a cold windy day.
author: Michael T.

description:
DON'T GO HERE!!!

two bones to pick with the Capitalists at "ramen underground."

first, the ramen is average, at best. they capitalize financially by charging you options, such as egg, that is a basic staple of any ramen shop.  also, they don't use pork belly anymore as the protein base. now, you have to pay for pork belly as they substitute white meat chicken, really?

i'm sensing a theme here

second, i'm a fairly regular patron who recently broke his jaw. i walked in on friday night to order miso broth  as i'm only able to eat liquids from a straw.  they ACTUALLY charged me 15 dollars for two cups of miso broth only. no noodles, chicken, nothin'.  seriously?

really dismayed by the pretentiousness and line out the door to eat at this place. i can only reason that it must be the only ramen shop around.

the ramen is nothing special and service is deplorable. devoid of any true sense of dignity and respect for its patrons.......
author: Aaron Michael D.

description: I liked it, the spicy miso ramen was good, you could tell the egg noodles were home made. I really liked how they use organic chicken for their base.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Amazing ramen! I had the miso soup ramen with corn and chicken dumplings. The portions were large and for a decent price. Be careful because each topping is a dollar or two extra! Expect to spend about $15 per person, not including drinks. I would definitely eat here again, but I would skip the chicken dumplings! I thought they were gross. 

There's about a 10-15 minute wait to be seated and another 10 minute wait for your food to be served. However, the employees are quick and competent, which makes the service faster. 

This restaurant deserves a solid 4-stars!
author: B K.

description: Just visited. I always see this huge line outside the door and assume that this place is awesome. After the most recent visit, I will just say it's ok. I tried the cold spicy ramen with chashu added. It was not that great. The spicy is definitely there, but the chashu is bland and no flavor or color. Unlike other ramen places we tried. Maybe the hot ramen is better? This place is also cash only. The waiter that served me is friendly enough, but when it came to change, he asked me whether I wanted my money back? The food didn't cost that much and I gave him a $20. Even if I really enjoyed everything and tip him above 20%, I should still have change coming back...
author: Lisa X.

description:
I tried to stay away from Ramen Underground given the negative reviews I had seen, but on an unfortunate rainy and flu-like day, I needed some soup noodles stat.

I ordered the miso chicken ramen.  Upon first sip, the flavor was strong and tasty. But after going sip after sip and finishing my noodles, every taste after the first lacked any umami flavor and was just salty.  You know that feeling you get in the back of your throat after swimming around in the ocean and swallowing one too many gulps of it?  Yes, it was that salty.
author: Trish M.

description:
meh, I've had better.  Friend and I went here because I've wanting to try it since I've been to the one in J-Town.  It's alright if you're looking for a quick bite.  Your basic ramen toppings, with no extra charge, only comes with bbq pork (chashu), spring onions, and mushrooms.  Additional toppings are $1 and other non-basic broth base are $1 - $2.  While chashu is my favorite ramen topping, I did hope the soft-boiled egg and/or corn would be included.  Guess that's why the basic ramen is $9.95, and a "fancier" one comes out to roughly $12 - $15, which I think is a kinda pricy.

It's not bad, but there are better quality ramen shops in SF.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I don't understand why this place doesn't have better reviews, I love ramen underground!! My review is based purely on their vegetarian ramen which is AWESOME! A lot of places don't have veggie ramen and the places that do, most of their broth is water-y and taste-less. Ramen underground's broth has so much flavor and their noodles are the right texture. I like that you can pick whatever toppings you want in yours, but the veggie one comes with tofu, mushrooms, green onions and a little bit of spinach. 

This place looks kind of like a small shack so I would recommend take-out. And be sure to remember CASH, because it's cash only!!
author: Malika R.

description:
Stumbled upon this restaurant after having it on my yelp bookmark for months (maybe even years) now. And I'm glad I finally had a chance to try it. 

My first impression was that it's a tiny hole in the wall restaurant with a few tables and a counter/bar area. So going here with a group might be difficult. I came here on a Wednesday night right before 6 pm. There was another party before us, but my party of 2 only had to wait about 15 minutes to get seated at the counter.

The menu is simple and straight forward. I love tonkatsu ramen, so I already knew what I wanted. I added a boiled egg for an extra $1. 

The food came quick, which is expected at ramen restaurants. I thought my bowl looked rather boring compared to other restaurants' ramen. Maybe because it was the spinach and how it didn't completely wilt into the broth. 

But remember how to never judge a book by its cover? The same goes with ramen. Once I took a sip of the broth, it was game over. The broth was flavorful and not watered down. It was the full pork flavor and nothing short of it. As I made my way through my bowl, I realized it came with a pork belly. Don't know if it usually does, but I can't complain. I love pork belly in my ramen and was glad to find its deliciousness swimming in my tonkatsu broth.

I definitely plan on coming back whenever I'm in the area. Just sucks that it's cash only, but next time I'll remember to stop by an ATM so I can try their appetizers too!
author: Liezel D.

description:
I'm not sure why I always see such a long line here. I finally got the chance to try it and had the miso ramen. It tasted very bland. On top of that, the ramen was served with a small overcooked piece of pork (extra pork is 2$/piece), green onions (good amount), mushrooms and spinach (...these two toppings tasted and looked so wrong with my ramen), and very tough noodles. After eating at this place for lunch (didn't even finish the soup), I was very thirsty for a few hours. Sorry, I wouldn't recommend the miso ramen here and probably won't go out of my way to come back to try the other items on the menu. 

Note: This place is cash only.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: I've always wanted to try Ramen Underground because of the instagram photos. I eat with my eyes. The ramen was mediocre. It looked better than it tasted. I've definitely had better ramen elsewhere. This place is pretty small so expect a wait during the normal lunch/dinner times.
author: Michelle O.

description:
Ramen Underground gets a solid 5 stars for being the best ramen in Downtown SF. I used to live in San Mateo, aka. land of ramen, and this place definitely holds its own against the likes of Ramen Dojo, Ramen Parlor, and Santa Ramen. The soft-boiled egg is delicious but not added by default so make sure to request it!

They're also very vegetarian friendly here. Other ramen places will disparage our vegetarian friends with signs like "real ramen isn't vegetarian", but 1) they offer vegetarian ramen here and 2) it's so good. I personally stick with the tonkotsu ramen, but my vegetarian friends adore this place, and I've tried their broth a few times; it's by far the best vegetarian ramen I've ever had. Adding spinach leaves to all types of ramen by default is a nice touch too and a nice little nod to the value they place on their vegetarian customers.

I haven't tried the sake here, but the Japanese soda is good, and I have no reason to think the sake wouldn't be good. Everything else here is perfect! Except make sure to have cash! I've had to run to the corner store ATM to grab cash at least a few times, and the other customers waiting in line for my table didn't appreciate it!
author: Nikhil S.

description: The ramen was pretty decent for ramen in the city. The real thing that bugs me is that they nickel and dime everything. We ordered a house sake for $13 thinking it was a normal bottle but it was $13 for a shot of sake...... which makes no sense...... That bothered a lot.. Because normally a house sake should be a small bottle but this is a shot...
author: Johnny L.

description:
Update: 7/12/15
This place has become quite a bit more pricey now. They've replaced BBQ Pork with shredded chicken as a default topping, added Spinach and raised prices on most toppings. The quality of the chicken isn't too good either... too much cartilage and even a piece of bone once. The quality seems to be dropping quite rapidly. Need to find a new ramen place.

======
Spicy Miso, Egg, Chashu, and Chicken dumplings and a diet coke! The perfect lunch... provided you can come a lil early (read 11AM). Its a really small place, and gets full pretty quick and the wait times can be up to an hour long. But having said that, the food is totally worth the wait.
author: Anand S.

description: We just arrived to the city and we were STRAVING. My bro wanted some ramen and I found this spot. Reviews seemed good so we decided to go. GOOD CHOICE.  Food and service were excellent. They give you plenty of food for the price you pay. We had no complaints and we would definitely return whenever we come back to SFO.
author: Ashley Z.

description:
I went here with a group of 6. As we wrote one our names on their waiting list, we were one the first in line. About 10 People who came after us were seated before already.

Finally, we're seated. The staff here are just regular service, nothing over the top or special. Although, they do not ask how the food is, or how we are doing, and they do not refill your waters. 

Food is the same as their service, nothing over the top or special. You have to pay $1-$2 for just a boiled egg or corn that comes from a can, etc. If you want something spicy, just order the regular soups and add the hot oil on the table. It's not worth to pay extra for a spicy soup because they just put the hot oil in it. Not only that, but their toppings aren't as great since you can taste a little of rawness to it which may not be good since it comes with mushrooms. Some soups come with a super small pork and/or little shredded chicken, not worth the soup price.

As we finished, we paid the exact total amount without tip since we all agreed the service wasn't all that. They just basically made it and gave it. When we left, the lady grabbed one of my friends and forced us to pay an extra $12 tip?! Excuse you, on the bill it said "SUGGESTED". Then the lady tells us that we have to pay it. If we have to pay it, maybe don't put suggested on your bill.

I felt bad for my friends because I suggested us going here and trying it, & now I will never come back here again and suggests others not to. The amount of money you are paying for this place is NOT WORTH IT. There are other ramen places with a better price & better service close by. Don't make the same mistake we did.
author: JenniRae B.

description:
If I had written this review prior to June 8th they would've received a 5 stars hand down, but now that they've switched out the chasu pork for chicken I had to knock down a star.  One of the great things about a ramen place is the chasu pork! Come on now. A for effort for going more healthy, but let's be real when I eat ramen I ain't lookin for a salad I'm looking to indulge. 

But to be fair, their brother and noodles (most of the time) are always on their A game.  Also since they've moved across the street the waits aren't nearly as bad as what it use to be.  

All in all, this is our go to ramen spot in the city.
author: Jess T.

description: The ramen was ok, very skimpy on the toppings. The pork belly was dry and tough. But I overlooked that until I asked for hot sauce and I was informed that they charge for hot sauce! Wtf is that!
author: Myrcka D.

description:
Spent the weekend in Japantown and was craving some ramen for dinner on a Friday night. 

I walked in and stood for about 5 minutes eyeing the servers. One was working at the front desk who looked at me a couple times but was rushing back and forth looking over past bills or something, so he was busy, and I shrugged it off. Another server was rushing around table to table to front desk and I caught her attention. She seated us 2 right away and asked if we wanted water. We said yes, and water never came.

Service was very slow because there were 2-3 people working their way around all the tables. 

We ordered our food, still no water until 10 minutes later when a second server asked, and then got our ramen before the appetizer given by a 3rd sever. It was definitely all over the place, and you could tell how tired the workers were.

The ramen itself was ok. Had to buy the egg separately and there was no seaweed, which seems like a given to me. It also had spinach and mushrooms, which was not what I am used to. 
Also had the pan fries gyoza and that tasted really good especially with the sauce. 

After finishing we sat for a long time until the first server came by and we asked for the check. Again, took a while until we got it. 

Everything was just slow and unfriendly. Others in the room seemed to really enjoy it...the tables in the middle aren't well separated so you will literally sit next to another party. Not fun if you want privacy. 

This place could use a lot of improvement.
author: Mai T.

description: This place is definitely not the same as before they moved across the street! The wait is still really long during lunch hours, but I probably wouldn't come back again. The ramen/broth isn't as good as it was before and just doesn't make me crave it like i used to..
author: Bailey L.

description: This used to be my favorite ramen place, but things have changed. I would always get the spicy miso with the regular toppings, which included generous portions of pork. Now you can only get spicy miso with chicken - who came up with this horrible combo? Did management change ? And why do we have to pay extra for hot sauce / paste? I was sorely disappointed after coming back for a visit in six months or so - wont be back anytime soon.
author: M C.

description:
Dude next to me paid $22 for ramen.  RAMEN!  R-A-M-E-N!!  Just a bunch of noodles with one slice of pork and maybe a dumpling and maybe an egg.  Haha, that guy just got chumped and didn't even know it.  

I'm not a ramen snob.  It tasted like good noodles to me but I'm not paying $13 for noodles again unless it comes with a whole lobster on top.
author: C L.

description:
sigh! my first time in their expanded space and it wasnt impressive! three of us came for dinner last night and were seated immediately at the bar (highlight of the experience because i was expecting a wait and was SUPER hungryface).  i ordered the habanero miso with egg, spinach and corn, and my friends both got tonkatsu.

noodles came out relatively quickly, and..i was sad about the meager amount of broth. i LOVEEEee broth.  after a quick instagram post, i dug in. and was immmediately disappointed by the lack of UMPPHHH in the broth. it was so thin and lacked flavor. wahhh! then onto the noodles...which didnt have the bite that i was expecting. this is all bad news. sigh!  i enjoyed the veggies (mushrooms are included) and the egg...but...will probably not be coming back to underground for a while...sigh.
author: Christina L.

description: Just a picture still looking for the best ramen. I noticed they used real piece of chicken breast.  Nice place on the corner. don't forget to bring cash!
author: Patterson N.

description:
This was my first time at the new location and I was extremely disappointed in how much the quality of the food and service has dropped. I had the salt ramen, which was my favorite at the old location. It was flavorless and bland. It used to be so full of flavor and umami. I added egg, which came completely unseasoned and pale.
