It also was missing big chunks in the white and was broken apart. The slice of pork wasn't cooked long enough so the fat was still hard and chewy. It was also unseasoned and pale.

I'm so bummed cuz this used to be my favorite ramen in the city! Ugh.
author: Jessie L.

description:
What's up with the death metal music during dinner at this place? Are you trying to give me a headache or the impression that this is a shitty punk rock ramen place? My partner and I were here on a Tuesday night at 7 pm. It was full and they only had one busboy who was the greeter, bus boy, food runner and check collector. Way not cool! Poor guy was running around which makes me nervous.

We ordered edamame as an appetizer but you shouldn't do apps if you can't get them out before the ramen. Ours came after the ramen was served so not really appetizing when you have a bowl of noodles waiting for you. 

Speaking of waiting, our food sat waiting to be served to us for at least 5 minutes. My butter had melted completely by that time, and the soup wasn't even hot enough to cook the mushrooms or raw spinach. Something is wrong here!

Hot tea was gross. The soup was bland. There is no Japanese pepper, only red pepper flake. The Kakuni (braised pork belly) was hard as rock and the BBQ was too fatty.

This place got an 80 on the Health Department scorecard. We are not coming back!
author: Jeff K.

description:
This place is definitely fast food ramen. I ordered the spicy miso, with bbq pork, corn, extra noodles and a coke. When I got my food the broth was a perfect temp but they forgot my corn. I had to ask for a side order but they got that wrong too and gave me a side order of pork. 
They also forgot our cokes (was with a group). The spicy miso could have been more spicy. The waiter suggested jalapeño sauce..that was too spicy. wish they has fresh garlic or nori that would have made it better. 
The place is pretty small and they seated us almost in the hallway next to the bathroom. Overall the ramen was decent. I love ramen, I give this place a solid 3 stars.
author: Macybelen D.

description: Very salty and came with a fat gnat/flea/bug in my broth. Veggies didn't look clean or nice. The chashu pork was hard and dry. Worst ramen I've had to date.
author: Gloria T.

description:
The Ramen here would have been excellent 5 years ago.  However, given we have Mensho and Orenechi in the SF, I would just give this place three stars.   It's comparable with Ajisen, which is a chain I like at SF Center.  

I ordered the Tonkotsu just for comparison with other places.  They give you a piece of beef stew, a piece of "chasiu," and an egg.  The booth, which is an important part, lacks the deep flavor at Orenchi and the thick creaminess at Mensho. (The Mensho broth was chicken based, truth be told).   The noodle was cooked exactly right and the egg was soft inside.  The Tonkotsu ramen at Ajisen has more toppings, but the egg is exact there (and hard boiled).

Overall, the experience was adequate that i would not mind going back if I happen to be looking for a place to eat in the area.  However, I would not go out of my way to go there, like I would for Orenchi and Mensho.
author: Will T.

description:
I don't understand the crazy line at Ramen Underground because the food is at best just okay. Perhaps I am spoiled by the authentic ramen at Tatsuya in Austin, but this place is the equivalent of cup-O-noodle with better fixins, and a huge price. I came here for lunch with work colleagues. We arrived before noon but the restaurants, which recently moved to a larger space across the street, was already completely full with 15 groups waiting for tables. I was bemused by their wait list system which consists of a dry erase board at the street where you sign in-- honor system I guess. We decided that we didn't have time to wait so ordered pick-up instead-- lucky!!(?). But unfortunately even pickup is behind all the customers at tables who just ordered, so it ended up taking 20 minutes to receive our food, and that was missing an order. The toppings were also wrong, sadly, on one soup (really just a mixup between 2 soups). 

The cost was $16. For a bowl of ramen. Let that sink in for a second.  My main complaint though was that the broth was not well flavored, not bad, but not the rich flavor you get from cooking pork bones for 20 hours either. The noodles were meh, nothing special there. The choice and variety of toppings keeps this place from the 2-star range, but as noted above, those toppings will add on a pretty penny to your already $8-10 bowl. They have kimchi, which was a plus. 

Overall, I would come back if a work colleague wanted Ramen Underground and was standing his/her ground about it, but I can think of at least 3 other primarily soup serving restaurants that I would rather eat at in the area.
author: Adina P.

description: Terrible service, mediocre food. Don't know why there are such long lines all the time
author: Oscar W.

description:
Already been twice in a week! I am definitely a fan. I haven't eaten a LOT of ramen in my life, but I had pretty amazing experiences in Tokyo so I think I can reasonably rate Ramen Underground as having solid ramen. 
I tried the tonkatsu and spicy miso and I really love the spicy miso. It's not too spicy at all and has great flavor. If you're hungry, I would add a second helping of noodles. I also liked adding extra spinach and hard boiled egg. My only gripe is that once you add more things, it gets a little expensive (for ramen, IMO). $15 for a bowl of ramen is hardly a deal, but it's definitely tasty! The wait can seem long, BUT the turnover is quick actually. I wouldn't go with a big group though (4 tops), cuz the place is small and there aren't many tables that can seat more than 4.
I will be back... probably again this week :P
author: Corrina S.

description: Not a ramen expert but I do know my Teriyaki. I went here for some good Japanese Ramen. I saw someone eating the teriyaki rice bowl and thought it looked good. It was the Greatest. Definitely recommend the chicken teriyaki bowl with an egg and mushrooms.
author: Rexford H.

description:
I had heard good things about this place and I work in the area so every time I walked by there was always a line out the door so I assumed it was going to be really good. It took me a while to try this place though because they have a high minimum charge for using a credit card (I think it's like $20 or $25, and if it's just you then that's pretty steep to me) 

Anyway, I tried the Spicy Miso Ramen. The broth was good, however the noodles were undercooked and the chicken had no flavor and was dry. I would've given this place 3 stars but there was an issue with the bill that really upset me. There was 3 of us - and 2 of us paid our portions including tip and tax in cash and our third friend put the remainder on her card. She apparently didn't put very much tip (which she realized when she came back from the girls room) but the fact that the waitress actually said something to us about it was really awkward and kind of rude. She asked "did you mean to put this much tip? Because it's not enough" And we were just like uhhhh no? Lol It was just very unprofessional considering tip is optional. Our friend definitely should've left more tip because we did get good service, but after the girl said something about it we definitely didn't feel like giving it anymore...

Overall, I won't be going back. The place across the street has way better ramen and it's cheaper too.
author: Jaclyn L.

description: Best Ramen in SF! The Spicy Miso is so rich and delicious. I added the boiled egg which actually had a soft yolk. Yum! The only thing it it is a bit pricey for ramen. Worth it though when you want to treat yo self.
author: Jane H.

description:
I'm not a ramen person, I didn't plan to come in but every time I walk by there's a line up at the door so I decided to just go in and try.

Service: Good, very friendly server
Food: Love the broth! I had the tonkatsu ramen, broth was excellent and the pork was good too. Ramen I'm ok with, I was never a ramen person though.

They have rice dishes on the menu too. Price is good for a dinner dish.
author: Joey N.

description: The browth was fantastic and reminded me of the wonderful ramen experiences in Japan. Absolutely will revisit it and try different flavors.
author: Sylvia H.

description: It's a shame that the quality of their ramen got worse year after year, month after month. Not sure if it's even Japanese owner any more, it's definitely not Japanese cooks. If they taste their own ramen at least once in a while, they may just notice that the broth is gooey and sour (at least for their miso flavor), it's like they just pour hot water on some pre-made paste. Japanese instant ramen can taste better than that. The meat is cold(unacceptable), the egg is cold, and thus it makes the broth not that hot either. I wish they opt in for consistent high quality food instead of trying to serve as many bowls as possible.
author: Bonnie W.

description: This place is not my first choice in ramen spots. What is usually included in a standard bowl of ramen (egg, tofu, etc.) cost extra here. The portions are average as well as the food. When it's packed, it's packed. You are sitting elbow to elbow with the people next to you. A bit uncomfortable for me. Expect to spend $16-$18 if you add anything. I probably won't be coming back anytime soon.
author: Ashley G.

description:
The food here is GOOD. Service is meh. Annoyingly long wait, but I guess you'll have time to make an ATM run(CASH ONLY!).

I liked their spicy miso ramen.  The broth was flavorful and spicy enough to clear my sinuses but not so spicy that it obliterated my taste buds. Soft boiled egg was nice and the portion was hefty enough for lunch-sized leftovers. 

Unfortunately the scrumptious food was slightly tarnished by the un-or-gan-ized service.  When we were seated, I ordered sake and a beer. I got my beer with my food (which I never like...drinks first please). Then, five minutes into the meal, our server came over to tell us they were out of sake. It's not like I needed two drinks, but it really shouldn't have taken 20 minutes to make that announcement.  

It also didn't help that the restaurant stores take-out bags underneath patron seating. I know this place is casual, but I don't think I'm alone is saying that I really don't love stranger hands reaching into my lap multiple times during a meal. No thanks.

Ramen Underground, your ramen was yummy enough for me to give you another shot, but I really hope my next experience is better.
author: Grace F.

description: Delicious! The food was superb. Get the boiled egg on top of any ramen you get -- I mean duh! The waitress made us close our bill in the middle of schlopping up soup so she could leave, which was rude, but not enough to dip to 4 stars. The grub was just perfect on this cloudy San Fran summer day.
author: Jeannine R.

description:
How do you call a vegetarian who loves ramen? By his first name of course! Well that was an anti joke, but you know what is not? The veggie ramen they serve here. This ramen is what single handedly, or should I say, single bowl-dedly got me into ramen (ok, that seriously is the last bad joke of this review). It is not some hastily put together token vegetarian broth, it is very flavorful and sure packs a wallop. It is slightly on the spicier side, but I always ask for extra spicy with a few more chilly flakes. But be warned, the bad part is not the burning tongue or what happens the next day. Every so often a rogue chili flake would go forth to irritate your throat and make you cough up ramen broth through your mouth and nose embarrassing you in front of the girl you were trying to impress. You thought a pebble in your shoe was irritating? You have obviously never had spicy ramen broth in your nostrils. 
But if you discount the human deficiency of breathing and eating through the same pipe, this place is a must try if you are around financial district. I used to go to this place ever since it was the size of a glorified closet. They have since moved to a bigger place but have started skimping on the veggie toppings and have jacked up the prices which makes me knock off a star. Oh! I should also mention that they still follow the pagan ritual of accepting only cash.
author: Shrihari M.

description:
one-two stars for their great service. 
The ramen def needs more improvement:
 there's no seaweed with the order?!  an authentic Japanese  ramen always have seaweed!  they charge $1 for every additional veggie toppings and $2 for every additional meat.. not to mention that there's only mushroom, spinach and ONE PIECE of chashu.
def not recommend this place if you are looking for an authentic Japanese ramen place in sf.
author: Pauline Y.

description: I snagged the last seat at the counter last night. Sometimes it pays to be a party of one. I had the salt ramen with a pat of herb butter and the pork belly add in's. All I can say is perfection the wait is worth it and don't forget your cash as  they don't take plastic
author: Andy R.

description:
With a name like this, I was expecting something a little less frequented by self proclaimed yelp "foodies". Guess I'm late to the game since people recommend this place, but also I have to keep in mind that "humble people don't say they are humble", because this wasn't as big of a secret as I thought it would be.

They still retain a rather simple menu that a smaller food place would have that doesn't need to meet a high volume of customers. After signing for our spot on the waiting list on the chalk sign, the wait for a table for 2 wasn't too long. I was seated and ordered the spicy miso ramen and WOW that was some of the best broth I've ever had! Honestly, it was better than my last Orenchi experience...

The bowl was filling and delicious, but may have been a little on the simple side in terms of what it came with. A small, solitary piece of meat, a little garnish, and with my extra side of bbq pork I left the meal full. But for an extra side of meat for $2 that only brought me 2 extra pieces??? Steep....

The short and sweet: Nice small ramen shop with some seriously talented cooks and extremely nice wait staff. It is just it was kind of expensive, and I could have saved $5 elsewhere on ramen that wouldn't be far behind this bowl. And $5 is a lot when that's already 33% of the cost..
author: Kevin S.

description: This place has gone downhill a bit over the past 3 years.  Not sure what has happened.  Still a great ramen place if you are in the area.  I would order the tonkotsu and add some extra pork and an egg - you should be all set with that.
author: James P.

description:
I would only come here out of convenience. Actually, on second thought, I would walk farther to get ramen elsewhere. When they were in their original location, their ramen was pretty good, flavorful, big portions, fairly quick service, reasonable prices. Not the best ramen I've ever had, but still convenient and I would have given them a 4 star rating then. Since they moved to their new, bigger location (across the street), the only improvement I've seen is in faster wait times. 

Their ramen barely has any flavor, the chashu is good, but they only give you ONE tiny piece, barely the size of my pinky finger (they used to give you 3 pieces). If you order the additional kurobuta pork belly (for $2!), you get two tiny pieces of that. I'm fine with their soft-boiled eggs. And all that came out to be $16. Um, so you've raised your prices and downgraded the amount and quality of food? No thanks.
author: Alice W.

description: Rainy Friday night, there was still a line outside. Ordered a tonkotsu ramen, spicy chicken miso ramen, and a seaweed salad. The salad was nothing special. They padded the bottom of the seaweed with plenty of mixed greens. The ramen was average at best. The pork ramen noodles were mushy. The pork tasted more Chinese than Japanese. The broth was thin and flat. The chicken ramen was the same. Also a handful of spinach and raw mushroom. Totally out of place. The boiled egg was overcooked and flavorless. The worst part. After handing the waiter my credit card. We waited for a while before I went to the cashier and asked what's going on. They tried to play it off but apparently they charged another table with my card and are trying to figure out how to refund it. Anyway. Bad food. Bad service.
author: Ray H.

description:
Pros:
+Habanero broth (only for the brave)
+Different permutations of broth and topping
+Spinach
+Corn
+Big portions

Cons:
-Long and disorganized waiting system
-Pricey with the addition of toppings
-Soup and noodles were mediocre
-Cash only
author: Minnie M.

description: This location is pretty small but so worth coming for the fact that there broth is amazing. I always get the spicy miso with add on corn, a lil taste of heaven. Definitely worth the wait but if you're in a rush don't come during peak hours. Aka lunch time with a group more than 3.
author: Ruthie V.

description:
I was a fan of Ramen Underground when they were across the street in their closet sized location so I was weary of expansion.  I was pleased that very little has changed as far as the ramen goes. It's still a great bowl of ramen with a ton of options. For those people who complain about ramen prices being high this is not the place for you because you pay for nearly every ingredient added to the base bowl.  Even I have to put the brakes on at times as I see the dollar signs grow in my head.  

Though it can get very busy they turnover tables very quickly.  That service tradition that usually hampers divey Chinese restaurants is glaringly obviously here as they are waiting for you to finish to move in the next guest. You almost feel like they are watching your every slurp.  It's a fine place for lunch but to relax and have dinner I can't imagine it being very enjoyable.  I will also note one time we came here we split the tabs and change was wrong on both of them so keep an eye on that. 

In the end if you are looking for quick and solid ramen for lunch. If you are looking for dinner I'd go elsewhere.
author: Joco F.

description:
Ramen! Ramen! Ramen! 

Everyone has their own ideations and opinions on ramen. Everyone is an expert, mainly through self proclamation. To college students, it's a staple because you can eat it through the week and save some money for the weekend. For younger kids, it's just good. For adults, the sophisticated, refined type it has become a delicacy. 

For me, I just like it. There are days I want cheap maruchan packets. There are days I gourmet the crap out of those same packets. Then, there are days I feel overly sophisticated and somewhat refined and want something authentic. In Japan, ramen broth is art and is passed down. It is meticulous and intricate, it is delicate and balanced. I have sampled many variations of it and I think I know what is good, what is excellent, and what should be fed to your neighbors' dogs.

So Ramen Underground...

It's actually above ground, and nothing mysterious about it so the name doesn't suit it. It's seating capacity is probably 20 - 25 and you sit casually with other people at any open chair. For groups, this can present a problem. For singles, who cares? 

I like that they let you write on the paper menu and use that as your actual order. Who would mess up that order? I don't like that their blackboard tells you to enjoy edamame while waiting when they don't give you any edamame while waiting. Where's my edamame???? Argh!!!!!

Base price for ramen with noodles and broth, limited toppings is $10.95. Every add on is anywhere from $1 to $2.50. I like that you can add on extra noodles and broth. I don't like that for you to have the toppings of traditional ramen you would bring your price to about $15. So here is my problem with this place. I am fine that they charge $10.95 but this should have onions, corn, mushrooms, the normal stuff. Otherwise, just charge me $15 for my normal bowl and don't play mind games with me. I deserve more than that. 

The broth was delicious. I had spicy miso and yes it was good. It wasn't ramen dojo good and the pork wasn't buttery delicate but good nonetheless. The additional pork belly I asked for was dry and over cooked. Other than that it essentially just came with a couple mushrooms and about 3 spinach leaves. 

Hence, they get and deserve three stars. Don't mean to poop the party but c'mon now. With Pabu ramen house nearby you cannot go on like this. My bowl with kimchee, and pork belly came to $19.95. That just isn't right for a B grade joint. 

At the end of the day, I satisfied my ramen fix but I wasn't pleased. I was disgruntled. I may read this again and decide that even a 3 was generous. Hmmm????
author: Ryan C.

description: The Ramen was ok this time around.  I've been to this place many times at their old location right opposite to where they are currently.  The service could be a bit better.  Still a very popular lunch place.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Terrible service and they don't do anything to make up for mistakes that they admit is their fault. Seems to be a common pain point among other people. I will not be going back and I encourage everyone not to until they actually realize what customer service is.

On a rainy day last Thursday I ordered to-go, opting for the spicy miso ramen with the following add-ons: extra chashu, chicken dumplings and corn, and paid accordingly (~$15). After a 30, 35 minute wait (to be expected, it was rainy and they were very busy), I got my order. When I got back to the office and transferred my broth and ramen into the bowl, I thought it was a little light on the toppings but I started eating. A few bites in, I realized that none of the extras I ordered were in my ramen -- they gave me the spicy miso ramen with standard (note: skimpy) toppings.

After several unanswered phone calls going straight to voicemail, I finally reached someone. I told her what happened, she took down my name and phone number, and she told me to come by and she would give it to me for "free" next time.

Fast forward a week, I return to Ramen Underground. I make the exact same order and tell the cashier (who is the same woman I spoke on the phone with) my story. She marks the toppings off and then asks me for $12. I was surprised I even had to pay for my ramen and expressed as such. She said "I gave you free toppings" to which I replied "so... I paid for the toppings last time and didn't receive them so I'm coming out... even?" Her response again was "you're getting free toppings." I tried to relay that I actually had to go through the trouble of going back to Ramen Underground (15-20 min. walk from my office) to get something I should've gotten the week before... and the best I get is "I'm giving you free toppings" (toppings I already paid for and didn't receive).

OH BY THE WAY... THIS ORDER WAS MESSED UP TOO.

Listen. You are in the restaurant business. You make a mistake that is obviously your fault, you own up to it and try to make up for it. I wasn't asking for anything extreme, just what I heard over the phone ("free") when I first relayed the mistake.
author: Clark H.

description: So disgusting!  Do not put those big trash cans in your bathroom. You go in bathroom and it's filled with flies. It's absolutely filthy.
author: Becca L.

description: 5 stars for Ramen ! We ordered Tomato ramen and enjoyed every spoon of it :) the place itself is pretty small, but it's a good one to stop by to eat alone or with  friend /partner.
author: Iryna P.

description: A place for hipsters based on the line. I wouldnt wair for this ramen...ever! Seated me quickly as I was on my own. Great service. Tonkotsu broth average. Noodles store brought and almost over cooked. Mushrooms thrown in and of the button kind, not japanese shrooms. Added baby spinach? No seaweed, no bamboo. Weak attempt at what could easily be made awesome. Kimchee also below par. Dissapointed.
author: Loz J.

description: Service was reasonably friendly and rather quick. The ramen chicken broth base though was ok, but nothing to rave about. Noodles were decent, and all-in-all a decent meal.
author: Alex L.

description: Should've stayed underground... T____T extra star because our server was super nice and service was quick after we sat down. Got the tonkatsu miso and habarnero ramen and both were meh. If you dont do any add ons the tonk came with spinach and the mushrooms with a piece of dry chashu. My habanero ramen was worse-  tasted like nothing but hab. It came with spinach, mushrooms, and one piece chicken jerky. JERKY, I SAY. Worse than the standard ramen.
author: Amster L.

description:
Oh yeah  Ohhhh yeah.  First time, I had the Tonkatsu.  Lotta meat, egg, buttery soup.  Killer.  But so fatty.  So the second time, I got the plain old soy ramen soup with a little meat (and an egg).  Still cray-cray yummy, but I didn't feel so guilty.

Totally down with that.  Only reason I didn't give it 5 stars, is, I'm not learned enough to know what the best ramen is.  But this was pretty insanely good!
author: Chet M.

description: Good comfort food but would not come here again. The mushroom are uncooked. Do they think we should eat mushroom uncooked?! Unlikely, if you want to get sick! And who put spinach in ramen? It's so weird. Only accept cash so remember to bring enough cash with you.
author: Julie M.

description: The braised pork belly is worth the extra star. Sadly they don't have the soft boiled egg.
author: Han Teng W.

description:
Ramen - Is there anything that could compare? Go ahead, I'll give you a minute to think of something else....... nothing? that's what I thought. 

I think it's a sin to say Ramen is Ramen, it's all the same, CAUSE ITS NOT! Ramen Underground isn't bad, but its not the best i've had, it does the job though. 

I expected a little more though to be honest for how long the line always is and how long we had to wait, plus how many people said we need to try this place. 

I ordered the spicy miso ramen with egg. Good portion, but it lacked the spice I was hoping for. Flavors were all there though, and I finished it all, so in terms of quality I give it an A-, just wish the spice had been there. 

Service was friendly considering how incredibly busy it was. Despite 2-stars, i'd probably come back again. Everyone should get a second chance to WoW.
author: Laurens D.

description: Really good noodles and broth (add the spicy paste!), and huge portions. The pork was a little chewy/overdone, knocking it from 4 stars to 3 in my book.  Still worth a visit, but maybe try a different protein.
author: Sandy B.

description: Absolutely WORST customer service experiemce, similar to the asian version of the soup nazi. We ordered rahmen with 3 different vegetarian toppings and received a bowl including that and a heaping helping of shredded chicken. As we asked the server if we could have one w/o chicken we were told to "just take it out". There was absolutely no indication she would budge, so we paid 33$ (btw cash only)  for a meal not eaten and drinks not drank, and ventured on to friendlier establishments like for example the Banana House across the street. Rahmen Underground should stay just where it's name indicates! Never again!!!
author: Heidi W.

description:
Slightly hungover after a disappointing game 3 loss to the Cavs, I desperately needed some soup as a remedy. We got there around 11:30 and were lucky to avoid their usual insane line and sat pretty quickly. I checked off my usual toppings and split the beef bowl with my bud. Beef bowl came out pretty quick and was a good portion for the small. I was surprisingly pretty happy with that. 

Now comes the shitty part. Without much notice (besides the writing on the wall right behind me) Ramen Underground decided to swap out their pork for chicken!!! WHO DOES THAT???  I'm not quite sure if their broth was originally made from chicken, but this time around, their broth was more bland that usual and they swapped out their Chasu Pork for Chicken Breast pieces. WTF??? To be honest, RU was a quick fix when I worked in the city, but no where near San Mateo's ramen joints. Sadly to say, won't be back for their Chicken Noodle Soup, maybe their beef bowl.... maybe.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Got there at 11:30 for lunch on a Thursday and the line was out the door. I added my name to the chalkboard for my party of 2 and was seated in about fifteen minutes. 

We checked off what we wanted on the (very efficient!) slip of paper (black sharpie = dine in / pink sharpie = togo -- how clever yet so simple!). I loved the no-nonsenseness of the place.... just simple, yummy ramen. With lots of options for broths (miso/ salt / spicy) and lots of options for toppings and even other extras on size and amount of ingredients.

Price was fine and we were in/out in less than an hour.
author: Nicha K.

description:
Came here for a late lunch. Not too many people were waiting in line so the wait was not too bad. 2 min after being seated, they came by to take our order (we were not ready). 5 min after being seated, they asked us to move to another table so we can give the bar seats up to table for 1s. I get it, they are busy and it makes sense for us to move but i found that to be distasteful. 
on to the food.
the soup was good - maybe 4 stars
but everything else was subpar. i ordered an extra egg which came out really cold in my lukewarm soup. the pork belly was just salty and didn't have much flavor otherwise.
as far as the price goes, it was on the steeper end. ramen should be ~10. i think mine came out to be 16 or 18 with the same ingredients i would normally get in san mateo. 
im willing to bet their poor food safety has something to do with storing everything (including the recology trash cans) in the bathroom.
author: Tiff J.

description: Pretty delicious, had the tonkatsu ramen. The broth is silky and the noodles were perfect. Their soft boiled egg could be a little more "soft," I enjoy a bit of some run in the yolk. I would recommend this spot when you have time for lunch.
author: Kat M.

description: My friend and I came here just for a quick bite. And she wasn't hungry at all, so I just ordered for myself.  But they made me order another $12 of food because there's a minimum order per customer. And the restaurant was close to empty. Horrible. I spent $33 for extra food that I didn't wanna eat. Thanks for charging my friend to sit there and breathe air. That's the dumbest policy I've heard of. These people suck ass
author: mark b.

description:
More meat please!! This place has good ramen, but just not enough stuff in it. 

I got the Salt Ramen, apparently the least salty of all their ramens, and it wasn't bad at all! Despite the simple name, the soup is very flavorful, has a thick chicken broth base, and the spinach and mushroom were fresh. I just wish there was more pork. One slice..really?

I would come back again if I was really craving ramen.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Finally got around to trying this place! My coworkers and I called in our order to-go, walked over and picked it up! I suggest if you're ordering for lunch to do the same, the line looked crazy long.

I got spicy miso with an egg. Egg was cooked perfectly, nice and soft. The broth was awesome, just how I like; maybe comparable to Santouka (#1 in my mind). The noodles were a little too soft in my opinion though, but it also might have been that it had been sitting in the container for some time while I was walking back to the office. The pork was just okay, a little dry and chewy in my opinion.

I would recommend for anyone looking for good ramen downtown. Though, probably not the best idea for lunch (definitely had a food coma in the afternoon that coffee couldn't even help).
author: Camille A.

description: Terrible! Hostess said they serve wine there which was not the case. We had miso ramen and regular ramen soups alone with chicken teriyaki over rice. Everything tasted super ordinary except it was exceptionally salty. When we were done and one of the waitresses saw the tip on our table, she came over and told us that "every American from San Francisco gives 15% tip. It's a rule." Well, we typically leave 20%, but I regret we left any tip at all at this place, they really deserve 0 % gratuity.
author: Victoria K.

description:
Ramen is still good and ordering takeout can help with the long lines.
However each time we've ordered takeout, the bottom of the bag has given out and the ramen soup spilled all over the place. Carry the bag from the bottom to avoid this - or better yet, Ramen Underground please get sturdier bags!
author: T. B.

description:
Broth: taste watered down
Egg: perfect (marinated in broth)
Noodles: good
Ingredients: meh (spinach/mushroom/green onion)

Definitely not coming here again unless I must have ramen and nothing else close by is open.
author: Drew R.

description:
This could have been a 5 star review... but it's not. I probably would have given it to them and ignored some minor flaws if their hostess was not such a wench. First of all I tried to ask her if I could see a menu while I waited outside (people were blocking the one in the window) and she blatantly ignored me and acted like I didn't exist even though she wasn't doing anything. Also, half the restaurant was empty (plenty of seats at the bar and two tables open) and she just let about 15 people wait outside and didn't come look at the list for a good 20 minutes. It was beyond rude. When I finally got seated, I asked her for a beer and she acknowledged me but went back to her stand behind the bar area and just stood there and didn't pour it. She brought it to me about 5-10 minutes later.

Pros:
-The broth is absolutely delicious the spicy miso had the perfect amount of spice
-The noodles were cooked perfectly
-It was a large portion that definitely filled you up
-The pork was amazing - not too fatty and cooked really well.
-The Sapporo was really cold (was actually really surprised by this because the beer is usually not really cold at japanese restaurants.

Cons:
-Not enough chashu
-mushrooms and spinach are not cooked 
-the hostess is completely obnoxious
author: Jessie L.

description: Authentic Ramen in the city!  Now I am not Japanese, so I don't really know what authentic Ramen is.  But the proprietor and chef here IS of Japanese descent or at least he LOOKS like he is of Japanese descent.  And the Ramen is GOOD!  The place gets packed at workweek lunchtime, but that's when I'm here and I will stand in line any time...  And sometimes it's 20 minutes to wait...  Enjoy!
author: Daniel K.

description:
Was craving ramen so my boyfriend and I walked over from our hotel since it was nearby.  Pretty random being in the financial district kind of away from everything but whatev.

I thought it was gonna be a long wait but we got seated immediately.  Ordered the spicy miso ramen and it was surprisingly good and super spicy.  I love spicy food but geez, my mouth was on fire.  Of course, I still devoured it ;)

Fast service, small joint but nonetheless I like this place.

Don't forget, CASH ONLY!!
author: Criselle O.

description:
I have tried the Tonkotsu and soy milk broth. I must say the soy milk is my fav right now, and is pretty tasty. I'm a big broth person when it comes to ramen, like I'll finish the broth and not finish anything else. So with that said, I think the broth can be more rich with flavor, and seems pretty watered down. Also, I noticed yesterday they replaced the spicy powder that usually goes in ramen with red chili flakes (the kind you put on pizza) and I'm sorry but that just doesn't work and I hope they switch it back.

However, I don't think I would go out of my way just to get ramen here. There are definitely better ramen places, but it's conveniently located a couple of blocks from my work.
author: Fiona W.

description:
the first time i had ramen underground at its old location across the street, it was SO good. the second time at its new location, it was pretty good. the last two times, i have to say it's declined to just good. i've been through their original menu (aka written on the chalkboard walls in the old location), their "here's a slip of paper, check off what ingredients you'd like!" menu, and now just a regular menu that boosts a slightly higher priced bowl of ramen than what i remember.

i don't know if it's just me, or merely just discovering a bowl of ramen i like better, i just know for damn sure my first bowl of ramen here did not have these ordinary mushroom slices that you can buy from safeway. what happened to the enoki mushrooms being included? i'm not trying to pay an extra $2 per topping added! it almost felt not as authentic as other bowls of ramen i've had.

the tonkatsu broth is still good, the egg is still pretty damn good, and it's still a pretty solid sized bowl that will fill you up, but i am sad to say it's slowly moving down my list of top ramen joints in the city. luckily the service/customer food consumption rate is pretty fast at this restaurant, so don't be intimidated by the large crowd of milling people outside!
author: Caitlin C.

description:
I heard so many good things about this place...and yet I was extremely underwhelmed.

First, there was a huge line for it (which I don't understand why). Me and my friends waited for about 20-30 mins to get into this tiny resturant.

When we were seated it took awhile for service, although they were busy I'll give them that. But they seemed very understaffed.

I had the spicy miso ramen I believe with pork...it was so mediocre...
The broth was good, but everything else was so meh...espically for the price...

I walked about paying like 15 bucks, for this ramen bowl -___-

Definitely not worth it imo...

Basically...
-small resturant
-long waits
-basic food
-meh service
author: Timothy N.

description: It was good and always a long waiting line. I'm not sure have they changed owner and chef. Usually the chef behind bar was Japanese old man, but now they r Mexican and the restaurant starts accepting card, it was cash only.
author: James C.

description:
Probably not the best ramen I've had in the Bay Area. I've had delicious ramen in San Mateo and even in the city, but I would not put this as one of them. 

The broth was not savory and the portions were tiny. The noodles were also thick and chewy - not great.

If you are looking to try ramen, I would not choose this place. Has potential, but not quite there yet.
author: Ena Y.

description:
Average bowl of ramen. Overall taste is decent. Nothing that blows my mind.  

Unfortunately, certain ingredients cost extra when they are standard I some of my favorite spots. 

I will give it a second go, but I'm not rushing to.
author: Rodney Lee D.

description: Loved it. Entire family did. Maybe other negative reviews are from the greasy spoon atmosphere, but the food was terrific. It's not a gourmet experience, but I don't think that's the point. It's kind of like the ramen joints you find in a train station in toyko - fast, efficient and good.
author: Samuel C.

description: Food was mediocre. I don't understand them making everyone order something over a certain amount of money (can't remember, probably over 10 dollars) even if they are NOT that hungry. I went with my boyfriend because he was starving and we were in the neighborhood, I was not hungry at all. But I guess because of their store policy I ended up ordering a ramen noddles dish that I barely touched so that I could sit there. Ridiculous. And they did not put a sign at the door to make that ridiculous policy clear. Don't even get me started with the extra fee they charge if you use credit card and the mandatory 18% tips. People pay good tips, if  you deserve it.
author: Sum S.

description: A good ramen joint for lunch or a quick meal. Good atmosphere and decoration. Service is decent, although the restaurant has several rules, like a minimum purchase amount. Slightly overpriced. Broth is rather rich, and the noodles were well cooked.
author: Nilay K.

description:
Came here after drinks and I have to say it does satisfy the ramen craving but that's about it.  I had the Spicy Miso ramen and the one thing I was sort of struck by was the amount of spinach included.

Yes I know I SHOULD be eating healthier but with stuff like ramen, there are certain things to be expected.  Large amounts of veggies are not one of them.  Other than that , it's a pretty basic bowl of ramen with anything more costing you extra (egg? more than 1 slice of pork?).  This can definitely add up and I feel that for the quality of the ramen, the price should not be what it is.  Also felt that price-point should be lower simply because it's cash-only.

I would probably come back if choices for the night dwindle but it probably would not be my first choice of ramen joint or dinner in general.  To be fair though it also would not be my last choice.
author: Chris C.

description: Great Ramen Noodle.  Ask for extra spicy.... if you dare!!!!
author: Edward M.

description: I was quite disappointed with Ramen Underground to be honest. Spicy ramen was not spicy, broth was quite watery, and over all in SF you can find many much better places. Especially paying $13. Extra star for organic.
author: Natalia M.

description:
what happened to this place, it was way better when it was across the street.
-Luke warm ramen
-watered down miso
-so disappointing!
author: Hugh G.

description:
Ramen Underground has moved across the street from their original place. More room different vibe. I still do not see how they are now considered " China Town" They are still in " FiDi".
Anyway went there yesterday the first day they were open in their new location which has more seating.
You will notice that in the 3 years i have been a regular and loving RU I now sadly give it your average 3 stars.
I have seen in this last year their quality go down and their recipe for their spicy soy ramen change, they have not been consistent in taste.
Some days it will be utterly fantastic other days okay and other days it will not taste like RU at all.More of the latter is making me pack up and leave my noodle mistress.

While I have given then the benefit of the doubt ( different cooks, bad days, terrorist, ran out of ingredients etc) it has now  gone on so long i can no longer turn a blind eye.   
I have to now sadly say good bye to my 12$ a pint ramen habit.
Sayonara tomodachi , ramen kun. I wish you well in your new spot.
author: Lost B.

description: Came here for lunch while I'm working in the city today! Friendly service, good broth and fast service! Got the soy sauce ramen with chicken
author: Tormain H.

description:
So disappointed , this was my best spot for ramen in San Francisco, but it seems that the quality and the service is not important anymore.
They are now in their comfort zone .not a recommendation anymore
author: Lorenza L.

description:
DUDE. The ramen was yummy. It had a western mixed taste into it. I think it was the addition of extra spinach that definitely made the ramen taste americanized. But, it still had that effect to warm the soul. Kind of sucky how they only give one piece of chashu with the order unless you pay $2 extra. But overall, the ramen was pretty decent. I got the tonkotsu, and it was a rich broth. The noodles texture was enjoyable as well. 

But, oh man, the service... I felt so ignored while I was in this place. I felt like I could have done a better job if I had just stood up and put my service skills to action. First thing when we walked in, no one really told us where to go or what to do. We just cluelessly wandered about and chose a random table to sit at. Then, it took like 7 - 8 minutes to receive menus.. when we were like only the third table in there? Isn't it common sense to give a customer the menu as soon as they walk in? We just ended up sitting there looking around for a while. BUT! That's not where it ended! They took a while to come get our order! They forgot to give us waters. And at the very end, they didn't even notice us sitting for 15 - 20 minutes without eating waiting for the check. Like, we couldn't even flag anyone down for the check because they just never looked at us. Each time, we needed something, we had to get up out of our seats. The workers are nice though! They are friendly! Just not very.. focused? Or, concerned about what the customers were doing? Like, it wasn't just us. There was another lady waiting to be helped for a pretty long time at the bar. And there was also another lady to the right of us who received pretty slow service too. The man next to us also didn't have napkins or anything or something. I don't know. The service seemed very unprofessional here, unfortunately. I really just didn't know what to do when we were not eating ramen. Twas a rather awkward and bitter experience... 

Also, I would not pay $1 for the corn again... maybe like $0.50? or $0.25? Why $1 for corn that just sinks to the bottom?! In the end, I don't really know how I felt about this place. It was A-OK.
author: Kim N.

description: Just ok...pretty sure those are not ramen noodles but actual Italian pasta. Try the place down the street on the left up the ally a few blocks from here. Sorry I don't know the exact location....Way better!
author: Anna M.

description: I think I had the last straw when the waitress demanded I tip her 15%. I thought I was being civil by even leaving a tip she did not deserve. She sat us down and brought our food out. Never filled out water. Didn't care if we wanted anything else to eat. Then brought the check and said we must pay now since she was "closing the register" yet they were still open until midnight that day and it was only 5pm. Once she brought back my change, I left $5 which was too nice for the service I received. Then she quickly came around to get the tip and handed back to me to tell me it wasn't 15%. I left and never looked back!! It was the most awful experience I've ever had.
author: Marisol C.

description: Food great. Service bad. Hang up the phone if you try to call in takeout so don't bother trying. They are always busy and treat customers accordingly.
author: Jack M.

description:
It's simply okay. Nothing exciting or unique, just okay ramen.

We were there on a weeknight around 7pm and waited for about half an hour before a table opened up. It's a relatively small establishment so there aren't many tables for large parties. Service is decent although it is obvious that they are understaffed. 

The ramen can be customized the way you want, which includes choosing your own soup base, ingredients, and extra toppings. Everything costs an additional few dollars so your ramen can range anywhere from $10 to $20. I don't have a specific recommendation because honestly, nothing was that memorable. Do ask about the level of saltiness though because my soup was definitely on the saltier side.
author: Yanni L.

description: I used to love this place but they no longer serve white meat chicken, only dark meat-- no option to upgrade. The waitress said they simply don't do that anymore so when you look at photos, make sure you check the newest added due to this as the dark meat they use is fatty, tendony, and chewy. Ick ick ick!
author: Desiree P.

description:
Yum. Came on a Saturday around 12PM with 5 people and it took us about 45 minutes to get seated. The smaller groups were seated much more quickly. After reading all the yelp reviews, I got the spicy miso with the pork belly. And just like everyone else says- it is delicious. Thanks yelp reviewers! I also added spinach to mine to get my greens in. 
The service was quick and the food came out about 10 minutes after we ordered. The portions are generous, two people could definitely share. If you're close to China town, definitely try it out. It is perfect for a cold San Francisco day.
author: Prianka K.

description:
I think the ramen here is great and would definitely recommend it for anyone into great miso ramen. My only issue with this restaurant is the price. It's seems super high for basic ramen when other places have more variety yet cost 20% less. 

Overall good wise, you can go wrong with ramen underground.
author: Jimmy W.

description: Habanero Ramen. Spicy AF, but soo delicious! This will keep me coming back for sure. A bit too expensive, but I guess so is everything else in SF. Hole in the wall, but probably easier to eat it there than take out. It is taking credit cards now!
author: Neha H.

description:
4 stars for the food, 1 star for the bathroom.

Been here quite a few times now and I can say confidently that I am a fan of this place! Definitely the tastiest ramen place around, and you can tell by the line ups at this place! If you are looking to go during peak lunch/dinner hours be prepared to wait 10-30 minutes for a table. If there's anything I can say it's that you can't go wrong with the spicy miso ramen with an egg, yum.

Now, for the bad. The bathroom is quite foul, management has decided to place all of their garbage bins right there across from the toilet. The addition of the garbage bins with the fact that the bathroom door is usually closed leads to one stinnky smellin' bathroom. If you feel the need to go, you probably should just run home, do the deed then come back :P.
author: David C.

description:
If you're coming for dinner, expect an agonizing and frustrating time in the "line," which is not even truly a line, but rather a blob hovering around the doorway. In the mean time, expect to see empty tables mock you from inside the window. The employee in charge of the door is no better. He is mysteriously absent half the time, wiping tables that don't need wiping the other fourth, talking with people in line instead of making order out of aforementioned blob, etc. You get the picture. To further add one more level of irritation, we were deliberately ignored while he took other people's orders. We had literally said nothing nor done anything to receive this sort of disrespect. 

That being said, if you manage to get through that hell of a line, the ramen is solid. I got the spicy miso with extra chasu pork and spinach. It's a good balance between spice and salt. The chasu pieces are also not too fatty, so it's good if you need a fix of protein.
author: Andrew L.

description: Only reason I give this place a four star is because it's cash only,  I came here and signed in during lunch time for a 15 min wait which was not bad at all! there's so much going on in this area that the 15 min went by real fast. The staff is really accommodating and attentive. The Ramen is really good!  Make sure you order a side to go with to your broth,it'll compliment it real good. I had the vegetable ramen and the kimchee tofu don, definitely going back to try the rest of their menu!
author: Jennifer R.

description:
They just moved across the street to a much more spacious location.  Now you can enjoy a little more space between yourselves and other customers.   

Ordered the tonkatsu broth (very good) Ramen (also good and al dente). Added egg (soft center but no flavor from the marinade), Kakuni (stewed pork).  Pork tastes like the Cantonese pork stew in black sweet rice vinegar and ginger. 豬腳薑醋。Wondering if the chef is Cantonese......
author: Kelly N.

description: Bomb! I luckily went on a weekend in winter for my first experience so it wasn't as busy as I heard it usually gets. Holy Cow. I love Ramen sooooo much and was recommend this place by a coworker who also loves ramen. I had no idea. As an SF native I don't usually mind the hustle and bustle of waiting in line for food if it is worth it. The broth is worth it! Not many places can get it right but this place does. Check it out! Cash only is kind of a bummer but well worth the wait.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I love ramen! It's probably one of my all time favorite foods to have. Let me tell you...I had the spicy miso ramen and it was possibly the worst ramen I have ever had. I will never be reordering from here again. It lacked flavor and texture. I would never order from this place if you are looking for good, authentic ramen.
author: Niki S.

description:
A decent ramen place considering it's one of the farthest areas from J-Town in the city. The prices were pretty high, but considering what part of town it is located, it's the usual fare. Me and my friend got Tonkatsu Ramen, his with additional egg and soup. The service was great. After being seated, they proceeded to deliver our menus and glasses of water. The ramen came out quickly and was hot. 

The soup was not as expected though; it was thin as noted by others. The taste was a bit plain as well. I was disappointed to see that they topped the ramen with normal button mushrooms, sparse amounts of spinach, and a small piece of pork. The true highlight of the dish was the pork belly though. It was well layered, tender, meaty, and soft. The noodles were as expected.

While I will probably not return to this restaurant, for those in the district without a budget, this is a decent place to eat ramen.
author: Kaiden T.

description: "Bullshit" is the most appropriate description for this sorry excuse of a Ramen shop.  First, they deceitfully substitute the allegedly included pork with dry, overcooked, flavorless, poor quality chicken.  The "extra" slice of pork that I added for $2 was minscule.  I don't know what the noodles are, but they weren't ramen noodles and they can probably be found in the pasta aisle at Safeway.  I can't believe people line up and wait for this place.  I assumed it had so many bad reviews due to the relatively high price, but unfortunately the failure runs much deeper.  AVOID.
author: Will H.

description: Last night a one inch bug crawled out of our chicken and rice bowl.  I have uploaded a picture. So gross!
author: Becky S.

description:
I happened to stop by for lunch and decided to eat here again.  They moved to a new location.  Its is now a bit bigger with more seating  3 stars

The broth is decent.  I usually order spicy and its not that spicy. 2 stars

They charge for extras but give so little, ie onions, corn - 1 stars

Noodles was soggy.  2 stars

The service was not that great.  The lunch line was long.  The workers were not happy to be there.  They barely smiled. The food also came out slow.  2 stars

Overall 2 star experience.  The price has increased from the last time I was here. The portions and service needs to be increased if they are charging more.
author: S F.

description:
They earned one star for pretty good broth.

Came for lunch on a Wednesday. Party of 2, friend put our party down at around 1pm and I showed up a few minutes later. We weren't seated until 1:40pm and I didn't actually receive my order until like 1:55. Not exactly the best place for a lunch hour.

I ordered the spicy miso with extra chashu. Broth was amazing, but I don't understand the need for all the bay area ramen places to include heaps of greens in their bowls. Noodles were undercooked in spots.

As it is, the ramen and service aren't worth the wait.
author: C F.

description:
Decent ramen, but they were pretty much out of everything (especially pork belly) by 1:45 pm on a weekday afternoon.  Crowded, tiny and had to wait on line just to get in.  Probably worth it when this place was still "undiscovered," but not so much now.  

Staff is friendly and efficient, but I don't see why it's worth the hype to wait on the sidewalk to find out that they are out of their most popular items.
author: Doug M.

description: Great spicy miso ramen.  The shredded chicken makes it even better.   Really enjoyed eating there twice while on a business trip.
author: David M.

description: $14 bucks for a couple bites of spicy miso ramen and 3 chicken dumplings. The slice of pork they include is chewy and over cooked. Not really sure I understand the long line that's always there during lunch times? Fast service though if you go at 2pm!
author: Rose R.

description: Succulent meats layered intense flavors and gorgeous noodles. Love this place so much we tried to go two days in a row.
author: Dawn P.

description:
Tried Ramen Underground for the first time today. I work just down the street and have been meaning to...and I'm glad I did. I went at 3 pm because I didn't have time between clients to wait in a long line. I got the spicy miso Ramen with chicken and a boiled egg. It's the perfect amount of spicy. The broth is creamy but not oily. The chicken was super tender and my egg was perfectly cooked. My noodles were aldente but not the crunchy aldente wich was perfect. My co-worker and I ordered ours to go...and while $15.95 ( price due to we are downtown/fidi and the restaurant is #trending aka hipster) is a little pricy for for some noodle soup...but we'll be back when we want a treat. 
I suggest cheking out the menu and reading yelp for suggestions before you go because the staff definitely seemed annoyed that we were not Ramen oficianados and needed help ordering. But all in all super yummy!
author: Loren S.

description: I decided to stop in for dinner here while in the city for work. It had been jam-packed the night before, which seemed to be a good recommendation for it. The tonkotsu miso ramen I ordered was rich and quite good. The service was relatively attentive too. But the counter is too high to be comfortable and I was disappointed to learn at the end of my meal that they don't accept American Express, which was how I had intended to pay. Overall, I left extremely full but a little disappointed. Given how salty my soup was (duh... ramen) I don't know that I'd hurry back. There's lots of other truly great food in SF.
author: Michael F.

description: This place is tasty, but I probably won't come back. I bought the miso ramen (standard) with dumpling (extra $2). I got it and saw that I only had two dumpling, so I start to dig around the noodles for more, NOPE, no more dumpling. I'm a little on the cheap side, so I don't think this place is worth the money I spent on it. I mean come on 1 dollar per dumpling NO!
author: Kaitlin V.

description:
Disappointed.  Normally, I only complain when the food I order don't come out as spicy as I requested, but in this case, the spiciness of habanero completely overpowered the miso broth and I couldn't enjoy the ramen at all.  The noodle was also slightly undercooked.  My ramen came with mushroom, spinach and a piece of bbq pork but everything else is add-ons which seemed expensive.

No complaint about the service though I stopped in on a slow evening so I don't know how things are like during lunch time.
author: Angel W.

description: This ramen place shits on any other ramen place in the city. Facts are facts. After years of searching I've finally found the one. First of you get a huge bowl of flavorful broth (not bland and not salt af), then there are these delicious noodles that I can only imagine is made by a magical being. It was full of veggies and some sauce which was good but I forgot to get the name of *eyerolls*
author: Candice B.

description: This place is always packed during lunch.. ALWAYS... Expect to wait 20 mins or so to be seated. Every time I passed by this restaurant, I always wondered how good this ramen shop is since it is always packed.. So I tried it one day and I have to say.. it was pretty disappointing.. Don't get me wrong, the food was okay.. nothing wrong with it but wow.. it is not worth the wait.. I don't know.. maybe I was just expecting so much more..
author: John L.

description: This place never fails. The vegetable soy sauce ramen is DIVINE. Top it off with corn, kimchi, and some of that chili oil they provide and BOOM. Absolutely fantastic and the portion is great!
author: JaclynElizabeth A.

description: Very average, ordered Pork Broth Ramen.  Greasy , ingredients were not fresh.  Staff was not attentive.
author: Hachi P.

description:
Worst ramen I have ever tasted (and I have been to way too many ramen joints between Cali and Japan...) and definitely by far the most expensive place of all.  Long story short, $15.27 before tip for a fake "tonktsu" ramen with pork belly.  The tonktsu soup base tasted like it was made from manufactured paste, like those stuff you get with the frozen packs you can buy from any of the Japanese/Chinese super market.  Want Cha-su and boiled egg that should come standard in any ramen place? Sorry, thats $1 each add-on!  In fact, my "tonktsu" bowl comes with chicken pieces and uncooked mushroom?! Both first in a tonktsu ramen for me...

Worst of all, the waitress is simply clueless, to a point of being extremely annoying.  I went in when the store was almost empty (late Friday afternoon).  The waitress saw me, told me to sit anywhere.  I asked if I can sit at one of the tables by the window, she said sure, so I did.  She then came to me and asked me to move to the bar because she needs to wipe the table, so I did.  She then came back and asked me to sit at the far end of the bar against the wall!  I was like, you just told me to move so you can clean and now I can't sit at the table?  And on top of that I have to sit in a tight corner by the wall? When there is no one else at the bar area?  She then said fine so I moved to the table.  After the meal I walked to the counter to pay, she looked at me and said "Welcome you can sit at any table..." WTF??!!

Anyway, so $17 ( with tip...for the non existent service) for a bowl of weird ramen that's worse than the frozen instant ramen packs.  This is one experience I don't ever want to have again.  There are plenty of great, and reasonably priced ramen joints in the Bay Area, namely Orenchi, Ramen Dojo/Parlor, Yamadaya, Waruku etc to name a few.  In fact, the place across the street that used to be Ramen Underground's old place served better ramen!!
author: Richard S.

description: They changed their base meat to chicken...not even ajisen at Westfield mall does that!
author: Jay T.

description:
Tried spicy salt ramen (sio ramen) chicken. The broth was so good. Probably, the best ramen I had so far.

Previously tried veg based ramens which were just OK.
author: Dipesh S.

description: My favorite ramen place in the city! Love it's soy milk ramen with spicy green onion. Simply the best ever!!!
author: Yawen H.

description: Stopped by here as I was walking down to Market St. I ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen which I had read about on reviews here. First of all, the ramen was overcooked and the broth was not spicy at all. It was okay-I could have had a better experience with a cup of maruchan noodles. Not to mention, I was halfway done with my ramen and the server came with the check. I was going to ask to have the rest of my ramen to go but I really wasn't gonna eat it. Next time i'll take my $13 elsewhere and have something good.
author: J P.

description: Finally came in to see what all the hype was about. Not too impressed to be honest. It was good but not great. I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and I feel like the toppings that are free everywhere else, here you have to pay for... Like my favorite, the soft boiled egg. The flavor of the broth was just ok, it felt as though it was not complex enough. Across the street has way better broth.
author: Sveta C.

description:
Not terrible, but solidly mediocre and expensive for what its worth. A bowl of ramen (with 1 piece of pork and a sprinkle of mushrooms) runs for $10.

The line wasn't bad on a Monday night, waited maybe 10 minutes during dinner time. Why this place is so busy is beyond me though, maybe because there aren't other ramen places around?

Won't be coming back anytime soon.
author: Julie C.

description: Ramen is on point. I would say that their braised pork slices were slightly thinner than what I can get at orinchi's in the south bay, but overall very well put together. Broth was so good, I almost drank all of it. I got pork tonkatsu ramen. Egg was cooked just enough to keep the yolk moist. Noodles are good. Price point was good. I think I paid 10 or so for the bowl, an extra for the egg and pork.
author: Michael M.

description: Fresh ingredients, delicious flavor, broth not too salty like some places, excellent service, and no wait time (I arrived just after 11 on a Monday). Truly great ramen.
author: Zachary H.

description:
Limited seating, and usually a line outside, but turnover is really fast! There were 4 names ahead of ours on the waitlist but my party of 2 was seated within 7 minutes (around 1pm on a Saturday).

Got the tonkatsu broth with extra braised pork belly. The broth was meaty and creamy-colored, albeit a bit too salty for me. Healthy portion of noodles. My only complaint is that you only get one piece of chashu. The piece of pork belly was incredibly savory and hearty, with a hint of sweetness. The corn was crisp, juicy and light, a perfect counterpart to all the savory/heavy flavors.

Overall, a great experience!
author: Gabby Y.

description:
Wow this was worth the drive and wait. I had the miso ramen with braised pork belly and soft boiled egg. The pork belly was tender and the portion was appropriate too. The soft boiled egg was amazing! Boiled to perfection it added such good flavor to my soup. The broth had lots of flavor too. 

My bf had soy sauce ramen with chicken and i tried that broth and i thought it was good but lighter than my broth. I might try that with bbq pork next time! 

Minus one star for being cash only. Limited in cash kept me from adding tofu and corn to my soup! However, we will be back!!! 

Street parking is easy if u have time to look. Luckily i am familiar with this area. I was wondering how long this place has been around becuase i used to work around the corner for almost four years and I had never heard of it til now! (Two years after i stopped working in sf!)
author: Karla C.

description: We decided to try this place out, because we always see a line here.  After waiting for about 30 min, we finally got in!  The place is pretty small and CASH ONLY!!!!!  Taking a look at the menu, the place is definitely $$.  I had the tonkotsu ramen and my GF had the habanero miso ramen.  What I didn't realize was that the food is hipsterfied and not traditional.  The ramen came with spinach, organic mushroom, and sliced white mushrooms and no egg.  The broth was also bland.  Overall, I didn't like the ramen, I prefer traditional.  This place uses organic chicken which I guess could be a plus.  My GF did like hers.  It was spicy and had more flavor.  The dessert tiramisu was very good however.  They did a good job on it, tasted like matcha and very smooth, soft, creamy, and fluffy.  It gets my approval!
author: Kevin N.

description: The wait is a little out of control so get there early if you can. Or do takeout. I basically only go if I think I'll manage to wait less than 20 minutes. The ramen is yummy, at least to this white girl (I go for spicy miso with added kimchi and an egg)...but it's still just ramen...
author: Jessica H.

description: This used to my favorite ramen place of all time , but i haven't been back for a while . so i decided to go for dinner yesterday 7/17/15 . i got the miso ramen with kakuni and corn, my sister got spicy ramen with kakuni and egg. The reason I'm giving them a 3 star is because i agree with some yelper, their quality has def been dropped. spicy miso was too spicy , kakuni wasn't as good as before(so good it used to melt in ur mouth), noodles was a bit too hard. OH AND the nasty organic chicken ramen underground is still good dont get me wrong, ill still def go back. but that bowl of ramen isn't worth $15-20 a bowl now.
author: amy l.

description: DO NOT COME HERE. Worse watered down ramen ever. Made a mistake of not reading the reviews and health department warning. Also, they have minimal charge per person, charge for more than one takeout box, charge for using a credit card.... Basically the place gave you very unwelcome feeling. Menu is really small.
author: Johnny N.

description:
We stopped here for a bowl of ramen on our way back to Denver from the NorCal Wine Country.  We did some research on good ramen spots in the Bay Area, as we had a craving for a good, authentic bowl of noodles and decided that this looked like a good place to try.  

My wife got the spicy miso (chicken-based broth) with an addition of kakuni (two nice-sized chunks of braised pork belly in addition to the chicken that comes with the dish) and a boiled egg.  

I got the spicy salt ramen (also chicken-based but with a more pure chicken flavor without the miso), with extra noodles and also with kakuni.  

In short, this is one great bowl of ramen!  Broth was flavorful, the meat was delicious and the noodles were done perfectly, with just the littlest bit of 'chew' to them.  

Both of the bowls were garnished with fresh spinach and mushrooms and the amount of food was plentiful.  

4.5 stars, because the prices were a touch on the high side and you had to buy the boiled egg separately.  

That said, we will definitely be back as time permits.
author: Chris R.

description: First time and this soup was cold and the chicken even though was cooked and soaked on soy sauce prior, it tasted like it was cooked a month ago. Awful experience and the waitress was not cordial and they kept my debit card. I'm so not coming here again.
author: Diana M.

description:
Ramen Underground left me pretty disappointed, especially when I had high hopes for this place.

Compared to other ramen spots (which have been popping up all over the place around the Bay Area), upon first look, it was a pretty lackluster bowl. Just spinach, mushrooms, green onions, and (literally) one slice of chasu pork... meh. They do have extra toppings available for an additional charge, but for $10.95 I was honestly expecting more. The broth was flavorful - I suggest trying the spicy miso, and the noodles were neither too soft or too chewy. Also I suggest adding the braised pork belly, an extra $2, but quite delicious. According to my friend who ate at their previous location before, they upped their prices. All of us left the restaurant feeling full and satisfied, but also ripped off...

Keep in mind, they have changed locations recently. Now across the street from their previous spot. Be prepared to wait and have cash ready.
author: Michelle C.

description: Service ok , but the ramen was bad . I order tonkatsu ramen taste salty . Using credit card they additional charge 35 cent , for card processing fee .
author: tang c.

description:
My cousin and I came here on a Tuesday afternoon, not to busy but I hear it does get packed towards dinner. 
The food was good for what it is. The ramen portion is small and they give a little Chashu. If you're just looking for a place to get some quick ramen that you can't cook at home, then this is the place to go.
author: Noel I.

description:
2.5 Stars for the food! They get an extra half star because the wait staff are nice!

I ordered the spicy miso with pork belly & egg. The broth did not come out hot and the flavors were just meh.

The pork belly wasn't tender like you'd expect and the seasoning on the side of pork we ordered was too salty. That's saying a lot because I prefer my food with a decent amount of salt!

Skip this place unless you're looking for a VERY mediocre meal with soup that doesn't come out hot enough to warm the soul!
author: Lyle D.

description: Don't eat at this place.  The service is awful.  My friend and I were totally ignore.  The waitress tend to other tables before us.  We waited for 20 mins.  Don't come here if you're hungry.
author: David C.

description:
I've been to Ramen Underground a few times since they first opened and they've been consistently disappointing both in service and more importantly, soup. Their meat has improved by offering traditional chashu, but the price ends up being very high compared to others around town and the ramen itself just isn't great. Warning: The lunch rush doesn't die down, even around 2 you'll have a wait.

Meat: 3/5 - I'm glad they started using chashu
Broth: 3/5 - the tonkotsu is almost chunky and doesn't taste quite right
Noodles: 4/5
author: Matt R.

description:
Fantastic ramen at good prices; I grabbed the pork broth, pork belly and soft boiled egg.

People are complaining about pricing, but the base price is $8 or so, and this place is entirely eclipsed by at least one place in the mission which has a $16 base for regular ramen, and $26 duck ramen; this place was cheap and awesome (for SF)
author: Donald C.

description: Horrible, horrible HORRIBLE!!! Staff is incompetent, accepted online order and then when I arrived  acted as if I was completely crazy. The "manager", said that they didn't except online orders and when I asked why the website showed that they do he looked at me with a blank stare and said "we don't receive online ordering at all." So rude, so unprofessional. I will not ever step foot in this establishment ever again!! Smelled bad in there also, and looked filthy. Yuck!
author: Amelia B.

description:
Great ramen! 

I waited 50 minutes for take-out at 1:30pm on a Tuesday. Literally, it would have been faster to get a table.
author: Tre S.

description:
The ramen here was decent and better quality than ajisen and ramen bar which are both nearby and we were excited to see that they moved to a new location across the street with more seating. 

Unfortunately their lease expense must have gone up cause the prices were increased for everything. The base soup now went up $2 and the cost to add-in meat has doubled. They are now as expensive as the fancy Ramen Bar :(
author: David W.

description:
Talk about a place that lost its soul with a move.

They upgraded to a larger space across the street at some point and I don't know if the cost/rent pressure is to blame or if it's a new owner but I won't be coming back.

I'm not sure if their broth was always only chicken or not, but after asking four times and then finally in Spanish they still didn't understand and as of now it is just chicken.

The noodles were gummy, not firm or soft but gooey/chewy, the broth was overly greasy, the pork was without flavor and tough, the spinach and mushroom was hardly present. The habanero wasn't as spicy as it should have been.

All in all a severe disappointment. Eat anywhere else
author: H B.

description: Im fairly new to the ramen world. So I can only say that I really enjoyed this spot! Everything was fresh and steaming hot! I ordered the Miso Ramen, good stuff! If you go during the day it's easy to get a table. Not as easy at night, you may have to wait 10-20 min. It Depends on the night i guess. It's a really small restaurant which is the case for most SF restaurants. Especially downtown. Again im new to the ramen world. Im sure once I try different places ill have a broader perspective. In regards to what's good ramen and average ramen. But I liked this spot, very tasty.
author: Black Frankenstien ..

description: Changed the sliced pork to chicken but charge the same price. Bad broth taste, bad bad bad. No way Imm coming back. This is not a good ramen place if you're looking for one.
author: Olivia J.

description:
I went here last night and ordered the spicy miso ramen with tofu instead of BBQ pork. The soup was quite good, but after I had finished about 75% of it, I discovered a piece of pork in the broth. 

My friends alerted our waiter, who we learned is also the manager, and he apologized and offered me a free beverage. My fiance informed him that I do not eat pork for religious reasons and asked him if he would take the item off of our bill. 

The manager reacted incredulously, as if the idea of him removing the item from our bill was ridiculous because I had already finished most of the soup. I informed him that was because the piece of pork was at the bottom of the bowl, but he continued to insist that it was unreasonable for us to ask him to take the soup off of our bill. 

I was surprised and disappointed by his response, especially considering that he is the manager of this restaurant. I understand that mistakes can happen at any restaurant, especially one that is very busy, but when those mistakes do happen the staff should find a way to make it up to the customer.

At any other restaurant I have been to, that type of mistake has always led to an offer to take the item off of the bill. If the manager had been more apologetic and said that he couldn't take the full item off of our bill, but could discount our bill by x amount instead, I would not feel compelled to write a negative review. But it was his indignance and self-righteousness about our request that convinced me never to eat at this restaurant again.
author: Zaineb M.

description: This did not taste like real ramen. For the price, it's not worth it at all. I'll have to keep hunting for a good ramen place in SF.
author: Lina L.

description:
i really dont get why there are lines outside the restaurant like everyday?

the noodle is OKAY,
but the soup is very watery and theres only one piece of meat, spinach + mushrooms - uncooked inside the soup.
not considered a bowl of ramen at all.........
the service is just ok.

CASH only.
author: Miffy L.

description: I felt like I had to update my 2-star review only to, surprise, surprise lower it to a 1-star review. This place changed owners and the ramen tastes like how fast food ramen would taste like. I am also getting Yelp's Poor Food Safety Score warning, which I wish I had seen before I came back.
author: Jake M.

description: They have ramen for vegetarians ( That itself counted for 3 of the 4 stars ! ) and the spicy ramen was so good. Would definitely recommend this place for a quick bite.
author: Archana A.

description: Came here for lunch yesterday and ordered their Miso Ramen.  At around $12, you would expect a lot of ingredients. Unfortunately it only comes with Ramen in Miso Soup with some Spinach, Mushrooms and ONE piece of pork.  I added $1 for a hard boiled egg.  The only thing I can taste is the very saltiness of the bowl of noodles.  Also, part of the noodles were uncooked and still stick together.  Not sure all the rave about this place.  There seems to be a lot of young kids waiting outside for a table all the time.  Don't think I'll come here again.
author: Angela T.

description:
There are only a few things in this world comparable to the sheer delight of slurping a bowl of hot ramen on a cold, windy, San Franciscan afternoon. I'm a big fan of Ramen in general, but as a vegetarian, it's hard to find Ramen dunked in veggie broth. But in Ramen Underground I finally found my solace. I come here quite regularly and invariably end up getting the same thing - Ramen with veggie broth, corn, tofu and spicy green onion. Corn adds some fiber and the spicy green onion adds the zing. I once got Ramen without those two, and it tasted pretty bland. A word of caution is that the Ramen is pretty salty - not salty enough to ruin the taste, but salty enough to test your daily value sodium requirement (but I guess, that's just the very nature of Ramen, isn't it?) While the place is a bit pricey (comes out to ~$15 for that combo), the Ramen quantity is very sufficient. And oh, the place is cash-only.

There is always a big waiting line for lunch, so if you want to dine in, then be prepared to wait a while. The place isn't too huge (it has a very undergroundy hipstery hole in the wall feel to it)...it probably seats about 15 people.
